**Dayr Darmalis (Monastery of Darmalis)**
This monastery is in the Raqqa of Bab al-Shamasiyah in Baghdad, near the house built by the Daylamite Ahmad bin Buwayh at Bab al-Shamasiyah. Its location is excellent. It is a pleasant place with many gardens and trees. Nearby is a reed thicket. It is large, populated with its monks, priests, and those devoted to worship within it. It is one of the places bustling with revelry, intended for picnics and drinking. The feasts of the Christians in Baghdad are distributed among known monasteries, including the feasts of the Fast (Lent): The first Sunday of it is the feast of Dayr al-Asiyah, which is a mile from Samalu. The second Sunday: Dayr al-Zurayqiyah. The third Sunday: Dayr al-Zandaward. And the fourth Sunday: this Dayr Darmalis. Its feast is the best feast; the Christians of Baghdad gather at it, and no one who loves amusement and licentiousness remains except they follow them. People stay there for days and visit it at times other than feasts. Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun the Boon Companion has [poetry] about it: 'O Dayr Darmalis, how beautiful you are... and O gazelle of the monastery, how enchanting you are. If you inhabit the monastery, O my master... then in the core of my heart is your dwelling. Woe to you, O heart, will you not cease... from the intensity of passion for one who saddened you? Be gentle with him, by Allah, O my master... for from his time he has enabled you.' The story of this poem is what Ahmad bin Khalid al-Sarifini mentioned. He said: We were with Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun at the time when Al-Mutawakkil exiled him. We discussed monasteries, their pleasantness and beauty during feasts, and the gathering of people there. He said: 'By Allah, you have made me desire to attend these places, watch within them, and find solace in them. So which monastery's feast has arrived?' I said: 'Dayr Darmalis, and tomorrow is its feast!' He said: 'So with Allah's blessing.' I prepared everything needed and suitable for such an occasion, and we went early to the monastery. We looked at the gathering of people and their celebrating. Those who left, left, and I stayed with him in the monastery that day and the next. We sat in a place overlooking those gardens and farms. He drank, his soul was pleased, and he was delighted. Some of the youths of the place attended to us, fulfilling our needs and bringing us novelties and greetings. He became fond of them and found his time with them pleasant, and he recited the aforementioned verses. The reason for Al-Mutawakkil exiling him was that Al-Fath bin Khaqan was in love with Shahik, Al-Mutawakkil's servant, and the matter became famous until it reached him. He has poems about him, among them: 'O Shahik, my night since you abandoned is long... and my eye sheds blood after tears. And I have from you, by the Merciful, what I cannot bear... and there is no way to complain to you. O Shahik, if a lover were rewarded for his affection... I would be rewarded, but loyalty is scarce.' Abu Abdullah used to strive for what Al-Fath loved. Al-Mutawakkil learned the news, summoned Abu Abdullah, and said to him: 'I only wanted you and brought you close to be my boon companion, not to pimp for my boys!' He denied that and swore an oath which he broke [pertaining to divorce and freeing slaves], so he divorced whoever was free of his wives, freed whoever was a slave, and obligated himself to Hajj for thirty years, so he used to perform Hajj every year. He said: So Al-Mutawakkil ordered his exile to Tikrit, where he stayed for days. Then Zarafa came to him at night by post. When that reached him, he thought—meaning Al-Mutawakkil, when he drank at night and got drunk—he had ordered his killing, so he surrendered to Allah's command. When [Zarafa] entered upon him, he said: 'I came for something I would not like to come for the like of!' He asked: 'What is it?' He said: 'The Commander of the Faithful ordered the cutting of your ear!' And he said: 'Tell him: I am only treating you as youths (fityan) are treated!' He saw that as easier than what he thought of killing. So he cut the cartilage of his ear from the outside, not completely, put it in camphor with him, and left. He remained exiled. Then Abu Abdullah was brought down to Baghdad, to his house. He stayed there for a period. Abu Abdullah said: I met Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Mawsili after he had become blind. He asked me about the news of people and the Sultan. I informed him and then complained to him of my grief over the cutting of my ear. He began consoling and comforting me, then said to me: 'Who is the prominent one today with the Commander of the Faithful and the special one among his boon companions?' I said to him: 'Muhammad bin Umar al-Baziyar.' He said to me: 'And who is this man? And what is the extent of his literature and knowledge?' I said: 'As for his literature, I do not know, but I will tell you what I heard from him recently: We attended the palace on the day Al-Mutawakkil arranged the covenant for his three sons. Marwan bin Abi al-Janub bin Abi Hafsa entered and recited his Qasida in which he says: "A white one, in her cheeks... are roses, so how can we smell them?"'

Al-Mutawakkil was extremely pleased with that and ordered a purse of dinars to be scattered over him, and that it be picked up and thrown into his lap. He ordered him to sit and assigned him the governance of Yamama and Bahrain. [Muhammad bin Umar al-Baziyar] said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I have never seen the like of today, nor will I see, may Allah keep you as long as the heavens and earth endure!' Before that, [Al-Mutawakkil] had said to him: 'What do you say about his literature?' He said: 'Is it more than Kathir says?' Ishaq said to me: 'Woe to you! You panicked over your ear and its cutting grieved you? Why? To hear such speech? Then he said to me: Woe to you! If you had a measure (makkuk) of ears, what benefit would it be to you with these people?' He said: Al-Mutawakkil returned him to his service. Whenever he called for him, he would say jokingly: 'O Abu Ubayd.' When he was pleased with him, he said to him: 'Would you like a slave girl I gift to you?' He considered that great and denied it [modestly]. So he gifted him a slave girl called Sahib, from his own slave girls, beautiful and of perfect manners, except that one of the servants had pushed back a blowpipe against her mouth when she wanted to shoot him, cracking one of her front teeth so it turned black, which marred her in his eyes. He sent with her all that belonged to her, which was a great deal. When Abu Abdullah died, Sahib married an Alawite. Ali bin Yahya bin al-Munajjim said: I saw him in a dream saying to me: 'Abu Ali, do you not see the wonders... My body has become absent in the dust. And Sahib has replaced me with a companion (Sahib) after me.' Abu Abdullah has good poetry. Among his poetry reproaching Ali bin Yahya: 'Who will excuse me from Abu Hasan... when he shuns me and cuts me off? He was a friend to me and I to him... like the mixing of the soul with the body. But a slanderer slandered, so he changed him... and he used to envy me over him. He will only increase in knowledge... of my affection when he loses me.' He said: It reached Najah bin Salama that Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun mentions him and makes jokes about him in front of Al-Mutawakkil. Najah met him one day and said to him: 'O Abu Abdullah: I have heard of your mentioning me in the presence of the Commander of the Faithful with other than what is beautiful, and your saying is not hidden from me! Would you like me to convey to him your saying when you were alone with him: "Do you think I love him, when he has done to me what he did? By Allah, I never put my hand on my ear except a hatred for him was renewed in my heart."' Ibn Hamdun said: 'Divorce is binding on him if he ever said this, and his wife is divorced if I ever mention you with other than what you like!' He said: Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Mudabbir used to play backgammon with Abu Abdullah. If he won something from him, he gave it to Kurdiyyah the singer, the slave girl of Muhammad bin Raja. One day he won twenty dinars from him, took them from him, and gave them to her. Abu Abdullah wrote to him after that: 'You pay rights with my money... while you know my condition. If this continues against me... you will impoverish me and my family!' His father Ibrahim, and I think he is the one nicknamed Hamdun bin Ismail, was a boon companion to Al-Mu'tasim, then Al-Wathiq after him. He used to joke with Al-Mutawakkil at that time. He came to him once with a snake in his sleeve and brought out its head, alluding to his mother Shuja' (Snake), and Al-Wathiq liked that. He said: When Al-Wathiq died, Hamdun became a boon companion to Al-Mutawakkil. He said: One day, Al-Mutawakkil ordered the presence of Farida, the slave girl of his brother Al-Wathiq—and she was of beauty and proficiency the likes of which had not been seen. He said to the servants: 'If she does not come, bring me her head!' She was brought against her will. A lute was given to her, and she sang a song resembling wailing and elegy. He listened to her and ordered her to sing something else. She wept and sang a sorrowful song with sadness. That increased the goodness of her singing. Hamdun was struck dumb by the pity that entered him! Al-Mutawakkil got angry and saw that he did that because of his brother Al-Wathiq, out of grief for him, and he hated everyone who leaned towards him! So he ordered his exile to Sind and that he be flogged three hundred lashes! He asked that the flogging be over the clothes due to his weakness, and that was granted. He remained exiled for three years. Al-Mutawakkil married Farida after that, and she bore him his son Abu al-Hasan. He said: Ibrahim invited a group of singers, including Jahza and Qasim bin Zarzar, and his uncle Abu Muhammad bin Hamdun was among them. Ibrahim began imitating the singers one by one. His uncle said to him: 'Do not imitate Jahza, and let there be no action between you and him!' He did not accept and imitated him. Jahza kept plotting for something to write about him until he found a note, on which he wrote: 'I obtained the imitation of one who sings... He imitated for us the old woman when she sang. And he imitated for us Labib when he came to her... and gave her the strong [penis] as she wished.' His uncle said to him: 'Did I not tell you: A scorpion, do not approach!'

Jahza narrated from Ibrahim bin al-Qasim Zarzar that Lakuhkayfi was a good, proficient singer, and he used to envy Ibrahim bin Abi al-Ubayyis for his singing and the pathos of his voice. When Ibrahim died—and his death was in the days of Al-Muktafi—Lakuhkayfi entered upon me with tears in his eyes. He said: 'What is the matter?' I said: 'Ibrahim died!' He said: 'With peace! By Allah, if he hadn't died, I would have killed him!' 

**Dayr Samalu (Monastery of Samalu)**
This monastery is east of Baghdad, at Bab al-Shamasiyah, on the Mahdi Canal. There are water mills there, surrounded by gardens, trees, and palm trees. The place is pleasant, well-constructed, populated by those who visit it and by the monks within it. The feast of Easter in Baghdad is a wondrous sight there. Because no Christian remains but attends and offers sacrifice there, nor any Muslim lover of music and amusement but heads there to picnic. It is one of the famous parks of Baghdad and mentioned places of revelry. Muhammad bin Abdul Malik al-Hashimi has [poetry] in it: 'How many a day in Samalu was complete for me... in joy, and its sorrows were absent. And a brother who mixes his speech with sweetness... his boon companions delight in the return of his speech. Pure nectar of wine is his drink... and beautiful, friendly women are his affair. The visit came early to me with him, so he went... in delight to me, and his coming pleased me. So I ordered our cupbearer and said to him, give us drink... the time of our drink and its moment has come. Its intoxications played with our minds... and its fires ignited in our cheeks. Until I thought the carpet was a ship for us... and the monastery's walls were dancing around us.' Khalid the Writer has [poetry] in it: 'O abode of revelry in Samalu... I have no departure from your goodness. Hail to your past days... and life is pure in them, clear water. That is truly the life of souls... and for you, anything less is impossible.' He is Abu al-Haytham Khalid bin Yazid the Writer. He had beautiful, delicate poetry, speaking only of love (Ghazal), not exceeding four verses, nor increasing upon them. He had no poetry in praise or satire. Maymun bin Hammad mentioned, saying: Abu Abdullah Ibn al-A'rabi entered upon me one day. I said: 'O Abu Abdullah, have you heard anything of this little boy's poetry?' He said: 'Who is he?' I said: 'Khalid bin Yazid.' He said: 'No, and indeed I would like that!' So he called for him. He came and stood. I said: 'Recite to Abu Abdullah something of your poetry.' He said: 'I only speak of the sorrows of my own soul; I neither praise nor satirize.' I said: 'Recite to him.' So he recited: 'I say to illness: Return to my body... out of love for something that is from your cause.' Ibn al-A'rabi said: 'Enough, O boy! For I imagine that delicacy has been gathered for you in this verse.' Jahza said: Khalid the Writer told me: 'I was at Dayr Samalu, when suddenly the messenger of Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi came to me. I entered upon him, and behold, a black man with thick lips had sunk into the mattress. He asked me to sit, so I sat. He said: "Recite to me something of your poetry." I said: "O Emir, I am a boy who speaks of the sorrows of my own soul; I hardly praise or satirize." He said: "That is stronger for the causes of tribulation." So I recited to him: "My eye saw two sights from him as it saw... from the full moon and the sun illuminating the earth. In the evening he greeted me with a rose as if it were... cheeks added some to some. And he handed me a cup as if its saliva was... my tears when my sleep was barred from my eye. He turned away, and drunkenness did to his movements... from the wine, the action of the wind on the tender branch." He crawled until he was in the two-thirds of the prayer rug. Then he said: "O my son, people likened cheeks to roses, and you likened roses to cheeks! Give me more." So I recited to him: "I reproached my soul regarding your love... but I did not find it accepting. And I answered its caller to you... and obeyed not him who blames. No, by the One who made faces... exemplify the beauty of your face. I did not say that patience from you... is more beautiful than youthful passion." He crawled until he was outside the prayer rug. Then he said: "Give me more!" So I recited to him: "Live, for your two loves are quickly my killer... and wasting away, if you do not join me, is my joiner. Love won a heart sick... with you, and illness a wasting body. So between depression and wasting... they left me like the withered branch. And the blamer wept for me out of my mercy... so my weeping is for the weeping of the blamer." He shouted and said: "O Balayq: How much gold do I have with you?" He said: "Six hundred and fifty dinars." He said: "Divide it between me and them [the women/singers?], and give the fraction completely to the boy."'

Ahmad bin Sadaqa the Singer mentioned, saying: I passed by Khalid the Writer one day, and said to him: 'Make me some verses that I can sing to the Commander of the Faithful'—meaning Al-Ma'mun. He said: 'What luck is there for me in that? You take the prize, and I get the sin!' So I swore to him that if he rewarded me with anything, I would share it with him. He said to me: 'You are too base for that! But remind him of me, perhaps he will give me something.' I said: 'I will do it.' So he recited to me: 'She says: He forgot. Then who is the sick one... and from whose eye are tears always flowing? And who has an anxious, beating heart... over you, while his guts tremble?' I memorized the poetry and composed a melody for it. We attended Al-Ma'mun the next day with the singers. There was an estrangement between him and one of his favorites. She sent him an amber apple with 'O my master, I have forgotten' written on it in civet. Allah knows I knew nothing of the news. The turn came to me, and I began to sing Khalid's poetry. When I sang it to him, Al-Ma'mun's face turned red, his eyes rolled in his head, and anger appeared on his face. He said: 'Do you have spies on my harem?' I stood up out of reverence for what I saw from him and said: 'I seek refuge for the Commander of the Faithful with Allah that he thinks this thought of his slave, and I declare his house far above having a spy upon it for anyone!' He said: 'Then from where did you know my news with my slave girl when you sang about what is between us?' So I swore to him that I knew nothing of that, and told him my story with Khalid. When I reached his saying: 'You are too base for that!', he said: 'I testify that you are like that,' and his face brightened. He said: 'How amazing is this coincidence!' He ordered five thousand dirhams for me, and the like for Khalid. From Khalid's beautiful poetry: 'How does the lover's liver melt... [from] what hearts endure from eyes? How do you see the lover's body... a sorrow that has no doctor but him? Where, where is sleep, O my eye, from... the heat of his guts, a watcher over it? O place of love, you are devoid of patience... so solace has no share in you.' From his beautiful poetry: 'I did not know the strain of love and its trial... and its intensity until I found you in my heart. My glance obeyed you regarding my heart, so it possessed it... for your glance, until it became in the grip of love.' From his poetry, which has a melody: 'Beauty borrowed from his face... and the soft branch from his stature. We reproached each other with our eyes... regarding what the breach of his promise committed. Until we wounded each other by our repeating... of the glance in my cheek and in his cheek.' He also has: 'What would it harm the angry one if he were pleased... and pitied me for the prolonging of my illness? He said to me when I complained of love... Praise Allah, thus it was decreed. I said: Allah forbid that He decrees this... rather the owner of the radiant face decreed it. You chased away my sleep unjustly... so make justice a substitute for it.' He also has: 'You departed, so how many a moan after a sigh... clarifying to people my longing for you. I had freed the eyelids from weeping... but my sadness over you returned them to slavery.' He also has: 'He visited me in a rosy [robe] like his cheek... and a necklace whose beads are camphor. A night in which there was no fault... nor shortcoming except the shortness of the night.' Jahza said: I was with Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz one day, and I looked for my sandal but did not find it. So I began to say: 'O people, who is for my sandal... or in a copy (Mushaf) a Na'l (Sura/Verse)?' This verse traveled until children recited it. He said: Ubaydullah invited me one day, and I was slow to come to him, so he wrote to me: 'Do not abandon the Emirs who have gone far on... a horse of al-h[aqq?] qirat [unclear phrase].' So Jahza wrote back to him: 'Whoever is a servant of your likes, his horse... is the horse of barefootedness and his religion is a Tassuj (fraction of a dirham/small measure).' Jahza said: I used to love a girl among the singing slave girls called Sherwin. She got drunk at my place one night and defecated in my pail and my bathing vessel and left. Al-Hadahidi wrote to me: 'A friend visited me whom I am pleased with... sweet of character, outweighing in intellect. So by the right of Sherwin who defecated... in the basin and the pitcher and the pail. Unless you come hastening quickly... and relieve from distress and delay. So that I see you when you get drunk and have... shared with her in that deed!' Jahza wrote to Ibn Tarkhan inviting him: 'We have, O my brother, a plentiful meal... and a pot hurried, present. And whatever you wish of good news... and a rare joke after a rare joke.

'And wine that shows you, when purified... the flash of lightning on a rainy night. And a proficient [singer] whom correctness has not betrayed... and a flute player, what a flute player! So you missed out, and if you were, O son of the noble... and God forbid you from that, in the Hereafter. Do I not know where the heart resides... O place of the heart, where is the heart? The guts pushed it away from what is next to them... so burning and kindling melted it.' He has: 'You went far, but wasting did not go far from him... and you returned, so he returned to his relapse. And patience parted from him in his day... due to what he missed of you in his yesterday. And a lonely one, familiar with weeping... over his heart and over his intimacy. His passion pities his guts... and longing mourns for him from himself.'

**Dayr al-Thaalib (Monastery of the Foxes)**
This monastery is in Baghdad, on its western side, at the place known as Bab al-Hadid (Iron Gate). The people of Baghdad visit it and picnic in it, and it is hardly devoid of a visitor or passerby. It has a feast which no one, Christian or Muslim, misses. Bab al-Hadid is the most populated place in Baghdad and the most pleasant, due to the gardens, trees, palm trees, and aromatic plants in it, and its central location in the city and proximity to everyone. It is not devoid of idle people, nor do people of revelry and pleasures neglect it. Its spots are always populated, and its grounds are filled with picnickers. Poets have spoken about the Monastery, Bab al-Hadid, and Qabruniya extensively, and described the beauty of those places. Ibn Dihqana al-Hashimi has [poetry] in it: 'Dayr al-Thaalib is the haunt of errors... and the place of every gazelle (female) and gazelle (male). How many a night I revived in it, and my boon companion... in it is heavy-hipped, distinct of limbs. Generous, giving his soul, so when he passed... and died, I was generous to him and gave my wealth. And excellent is the religion of the Son of Mary as a religion... coquetry mixing his licentiousness with pampering. I gave him drink and drank the remainder of his cup... so I drank pure water from sweet taste.' This Ibn Dihqana is from the descendants of Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Abbas, known as Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Umar. He has beautiful poetry. Jahza mentioned that he recited to him: 'Is it when I cut off those who connected for you... and was generous to you and not miserly? You betrayed and showed me cruelty... and wronged me and were not just? Should I hope in another who loves you... when you did not observe the sanctity of the first for me?' Jahza mentioned that he was the governor of Basra during the days of the Zanj, and that he took thirty thousand dinars from the Najim (rebel) there and surrendered Basra to him. Jahza used to stay with him frequently and not miss him. He said: 'I was late in visiting him at one time due to an obstacle that occurred to me. He sent for me inviting me. I wrote to him: "I am, by Allah, ill! And it is not the decoration of the tongue and its crafting... but it has mixed with the flesh and blood." He sent me fifty dinars and a robe, and said: "This removes the illness, so by my life, come to me!" So I went to him.' Jahza mentioned that he used to be a boon companion to Al-Mu'tamid and Al-Muwaffaq. He was large in build, heavy in body. When the Caliph stood up and returned, and the boon companions stood up, he would sleep and say: 'This is the compensation for standing since I was unable to do it.' He was a glutton, so he used to say: 'I have eaten until I became chronically ill, and I want to eat until I die!' From his poetry: 'If there was rest in my panic... I would have been the most panicking of those who panic. I will be patient with my effort upon what you see... and if my patience is exhausted, what shall I do?' Al-Nashi' mentions Bab al-Hadid and Qabruniya: 'The sturdy one is not sturdy on the day of dew... you went far, though the shrine is not far. Tears informed of her conscience... becoming a helper against the lovesick heart. O nights of pleasures, by Allah, return... between Qabruniya and Bab al-Hadid. Between those hills, when the rain has woven... with the hand of spring the sheets of robes. His cheek is opposite his temple just as the promise... when you test, is the opposite of the threat. The drum demanded benefits from the flute... and joy returned when my oud returned.' From his delicate poetry: 'I did not forget you, nor betray you, nor was there... in the heart of mine a place for solace. But I saw you had tired of my affection... so I knew that your medicine was abandonment.' 

**Dayr al-Jathaliq (Monastery of the Catholicos)**

This monastery is near Bab al-Hadid. It is a large, beautiful, pleasant monastery, surrounded by gardens, trees, and aromatic plants. It parallels Dayr al-Thaalib in pleasantness, goodness, and the population of the area, because they are in one spot. It is intended and visited, never devoid of picnickers and those seeking it. In it are its monks, youths, and those who frequent it from the people of licentiousness and idleness. Poets have spoken of it and described it. Muhammad bin Abi Umayya the Writer has [poetry] in it, with a light Ramal melody: 'My sorrow for a moon imprisoned in the monastery... in the form of humans, with the cunning of devils. By Allah, my eye never saw his beauties... except I went out for him obediently from the religion.' He also has in this monastery: 'I remembered Dayr al-Jathaliq and youths... with whom joy was complete for me there and aided. Through them the world became good and its joy complete... and the vicissitudes of time made peace with me and were just. O how many a day I enjoyed its shade... rushing to the pure pleasures of my life. I flirt in it with a black-eyed, slender one... and I am given to drink in it a wine of musky taste. So hail to days passed for me in their proximity... they extended to me kindness and sympathy. And woe to days that threw me among them... and a time that demanded repayment for what it had lent.' This Muhammad bin Umayya is one of the early poets, of delicate nature, good conduct in poetry, and strange meanings. Most of his poetry is in Ghazal (love poetry). He and his brother Ali used to write for Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi'. He is the uncle of Abu Hashisha the Tanbur player. From his beautiful poetry: 'I saw you as my ornament, world and religion... life for the bedfellow and the companion. It appeared to me, after my right hand preceded... with abandoning you, that I should atone for my oath.' He has: 'I did not forget you, nor betray you, nor was there... in the heart of mine a place for solace. But I saw you had tired of my affection... so I knew that your medicine was abandonment.' From his delicate poetry: 'O stranger weeping for every stranger... who has not tasted before it the separation of a beloved. Patience overcame him, so he rested in tears... and in tears is rest for hearts. Would that I see you one day as you were... near, so I could complain to a near one.' He has: 'Many a day from you I do not forget... obligated thanks even if you did not do [good]. I cut through time with good thought... and cleared a flood that would not clear. And I see the days do not bring near what... I hope from you, but bring near my term. Whenever I hoped for a good day... abandonment presented itself before the hope.' From his rare poetry: 'I will surely hold a funeral soon... there is nothing after separation but wailing. Calamities have darkened me regarding you, so I was not able... to repel the injustice of calamities. Lord, how painful is love to hearts... no, especially the separation of the beloved. I did not know separation, so I advanced... upon it inexperienced, without trial.' He also has: 'Today my patience has bereft me of your separation... thus is the greatest thing, the loss of a beloved. I was in spaciousness before regarding you... so today I have become, from sorrows, in a strait. And a time I used to trust assassinated me... woe to its treachery after documentation. Indeed, I did not break your affection by covenant... O you who sees breaking covenants as good.' He has: 'The soul has not tasted upon desire... anything sweeter than the affection of a trustworthy friend. Whoever misses the affection of a righteous brother... that is the cheated one in truth of certainty.' He has, and it is of his beautiful poetry: 'O longing do not run out, and O tear overflow and increase... and O longing alternate between side to side. And O my blamer blame me, and O worshiper miss me... I disobeyed you both until I am hidden in the dust. If my Lord is knowledgeable of my secret... then people are not greater in my eye than my Lord.' He has, describing a garden: 'In gardens as if spread over... their soil is a green silk. The eyes of the fresh narcissus are stars... and the greenness of the meadows in them is a sky. For the soil beneath them is sleep, and for the water... is a murmur, and for the branches is singing.' He has: 'So here I am, overlooking for your satisfaction and patient... upon the like of a polished cutting sword. And withdrawing from what you hated, and placing... your satisfaction as an example between my eye and my eyebrow.' He has:

'How many a joy was, and how many a sorrow... suspicions fabricated for me regarding you. If hearts show other than what... they conceal, eyes inform you about them.' He has: 'He raises a breath in the guts... and stays awake if a youth dozes. He remains treating the sighs... whether he sleeps or sits. He fed his soul with longing... and distracted himself with "perhaps". A lover who turned the complaint to his companions into intimacy.' Abu Bakr Muhammad bin al-Qasim al-Anbari used to end his dictations in his sessions with a piece of Ibn Abi Umayya's poetry, admiring it and finding its words sweet, and he would always praise and describe him. 

**Dayr Madyan (Monastery of Madyan)**
This monastery is on the Karkhaya canal in Baghdad. Karkhaya is a canal that splits from the Great Muhawwal, passes by Al-Abbasiya, splits Karkh, and pours into the Tigris. It was anciently populated, and the water in it flowing, then it was blocked and its flow cut off by the breaches that opened in the Euphrates. It is a beautiful, pleasant monastery, surrounded by gardens and buildings. It is intended for picnicking and drinking, and is never devoid of a visitor or passerby. It is one of the beautiful, pleasant spots. Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak has [poetry] in it: 'Urge the wine, for the cup is full... of what stirs the motives of longing sometimes. Indeed, I was delighted by monks answering... in holiness, after the quiet of the night, monks. So they startled a sorrow from me by which I remembered... Karkh of Iraq, and brothers and sorrows. So I said, while the tear in my eye was flowing... and longing ignited fires in the guts: O Dayr Madyan, may you not be stripped of inhabitants... how much illness you stirred, O Dayr Madyana. Does your priest have knowledge to inform me... how the face of patience aids the one who departed? Hail and care to Karkhaya and its inhabitant... between Al-Junayna and Al-Rawha', whoever was.' He said: Abu Ali bin al-Rashid used to stick to this monastery and drink in it. He had singing girls he brought to it, and he would stay there for days, not ceasing from music and revelry. He was excessively dissolute! Those neighboring the place complained of what they encountered from him. The news reached Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Tahiri, who was the deputy of the Sultan in Baghdad. He sent to him reproaching his action and forbidding him from repeating the like. He said: 'What hand does Ishaq have over me? And what command does he have regarding me? Do you think he prevents me from listening to my slave girls and drinking where I desire?' When this saying of his reached him, it angered him, and he waited until night fell. He rode to the place, surrounded it from all sides, and ordered the door of the monastery to be opened and him to be brought down in the state he was in. He was brought down drunk in dyed clothes, smeared with saffron perfume. He said to him: 'Shame on you! A man from the children of the Caliphate in such a state?' Then he ordered a rug to be spread at the door of the monastery, laid him on it, and flogged him twenty lashes, saying: 'The Commander of the Faithful did not appoint me his deputy so that I waste affairs and neglect them, nor so that I let you and others of his family disgrace him and expose him, and go out to what you went out to of indecency, notoriety, violating sanctity, and taking them [women] out to monasteries and taverns. In disciplining you is a preservation of the Caliphate, and a deterrence for you and others from this scandal.' Then he ordered litters that were with him, mounted him in them with his harem, and returned him to his house. That reached Al-Mu'tasim, so he wrote to him approving his opinion and action, and ordering him not to permit anyone of his family the like.

The mother of this Abu Ali is known as Shakl. Al-Rashid had bought her and a companion of hers known as Shadhar on the same day. Shadhar became pregnant and gave birth to Umm Abiha; Shakl envied her, and envy led her to a great matter of enmity, until it became famous. Shakl became pregnant and gave birth to Abu Ali. Their mothers died, but the enmity remained between Abu Ali and Umm Abiha, until the matter reached the point that they satirized each other with poetry, and their affair became widespread among all the family of Al-Rashid! When Al-Amin was killed and Al-Ma'mun arrived in Baghdad, he sat one day with his uncle Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi, his brother Abu Ishaq, and his son Al-Abbas, and they discussed the enmity between these two. He said: 'I have heard the news of their enmity in Khurasan, and I have resolved to reconcile them.' He sent for Umm Abiha and she was brought. He began reproaching her while she looked down, not returning an answer. Then he ordered the presence of Abu Ali. When Umm Abiha saw him, she veiled herself and covered her face. Al-Ma'mun said: 'You were unveiled, then when your brother arrived you veiled yourself?' She said: 'By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, my unveiling before Abdullah bin Tahir and Ali bin Hisham is more obligatory than my unveiling for Abu Ali! By Allah, he is not a brother to me nor a son to Al-Rashid! Allah Almighty said regarding Quraysh: "Who fed them from hunger and secured them from fear." Ibn Abbas said: Secured them from leprosy and elephantiasis. And he, by Allah, is leprous, and he is nothing but the son of So-and-so the carpet spreader!' So Al-Ma'mun ordered his brother Abu Ishaq, and he flogged her a Hadd punishment. She said: 'Shame, O Commander of the Faithful, that you inflict a Hadd on your sister for the sake of the son of the carpet spreader, and establish the Hadd on the daughters of the Caliphs! By Allah, I thought his matter would be concealed, but now, by Allah, the narrators will transmit it and talk about it until the Hour rises!' And she rose. Al-Ma'mun said: 'May Allah curse her! If she were a man, she would have been more entitled to the Caliphate than many of the Caliphs!' Abu Ali used to refuse to pray over the funerals of the Caliphs' children to ward off the defect from himself. We return to mentioning Ishaq bin Ibrahim and present a portion of his news regarding his firmness and control, as much as befits the book. This Ishaq is the nephew of Tahir bin al-Husayn, and his kunya is Abu al-Hasan. Al-Ma'mun had adopted him and appointed him as deputy to Abdullah bin Tahir in his presence when Abdullah was sent to Khurasan. He was the most advanced of people with him and most specialized to him. Abdullah bin Khurdadhbih mentioned that he attended Al-Ma'mun's assembly one day, and Ahmad bin Abi Khalid presented petitions to him, including a petition from people complaining about Ishaq bin Ibrahim. When Al-Ma'mun read it, he took the pen and wrote on its back: 'There is nothing in these rabble but every slandering backbiter! Ishaq is my cultivation by my hand, and whom I planted produced noble offspring and did not fail. I will not help anyone against him.' Then he wrote a note to Ishaq, saying: 'From a compassionate educator to a prudent educated one. O my son, whoever is mighty should be humble, whoever is capable should forgive, whoever observes should be just, and whoever watches should be cautious. The consequence of presumption is not praiseworthy, and the believer is clever and intelligent. Peace.' Ishaq governed for Al-Ma'mun, then for Al-Mu'tasim, then for Al-Wathiq, then for Al-Mutawakkil. He died in the days of Al-Mutawakkil. He established his son Muhammad in his place, who remained a short while and died. Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir was summoned from Khurasan, and what was Ishaq's was returned to him. They mentioned that one of Al-Rashid's children—who had a position of lineage and a place of knowledge and literature—fell ill in Baghdad with a prolonged illness. He could not ride and desired to relax and picnic in the water. He wanted to build a Zallal (a type of boat/structure) to sit in. Ishaq prevented him and said: 'This is something we do not like the like of to be made except by the command and permission of the Commander of the Faithful.' He wrote to Al-Mu'tasim asking his permission for that. The order came out to Ishaq to allow it for him. Ishaq wrote: 'A letter came to me from the Commander of the Faithful allowing the building of a Zallal, but he did not define for me its length or width, so I suspended his matter until I seek opinion on that.' He wrote to him praising him for his caution and defining for him the dimensions of the Zallal. He said: When Al-Mu'tasim moved to Surra Man Ra'a, people used to visit Al-Ma'mun's house on the day of the procession and sit in it according to their custom during his life, out of reverence for the Sultan and honoring his command. Muhammad bin Ishaq returned on one of the hot days, having ridden for a long time. He passed by Al-Ma'mun's house, having twisted his cap on his head, shielding himself with it from the sun. That reached his father, so he beat him, punishing him for passing by the Caliph's door in a casual manner!

Abdullah bin Khurdadhbih mentioned that he went out one day from before Al-Ma'mun following Ishaq bin Ibrahim. When he reached the second vestibule, he stopped, and the commanders and people stopped because of his stopping! Then he said: 'Where is the deputy of Ali bin Salih?' Ali was at that time the master of the house affairs and titled with Chamberlainship (Hajabah). His deputy was brought, so he flogged him one hundred lashes, then said: 'To prison!' Then he said: 'Bring the deputy of the Postmaster.' He was brought, so he flogged him one hundred lashes, then said: 'To prison!' Then he called for Ali bin Salih and the Postmaster and said to them: 'Do you entrust your deputyship in the Caliph's house to those who waste affairs and neglect them? You were more deserving of this discipline than these two!' They said: 'And what was their matter that you disapproved of, O Emir?' He said: 'A postmaster sits in the Caliph's house, laughing and guffawing, and the master of the house is sitting and does not disapprove?' Then he left! He said: I used to enter the house after that, and I would not see anyone laughing in it! He said: Ishaq entered upon Al-Mutawakkil on the day of Nayruz, and the Samaja (masked entertainers) were before him. On Al-Mutawakkil was a heavy embroidered robe. The owners of the Samaja had increased until they came close to him to pick up the dirhams scattered over them, and they pulled his hem! When Ishaq saw that, he turned away angry, saying: 'Uff and Tuff! What does our guarding the kingdom avail with this negligence!' Al-Mutawakkil saw him turning away, so he said: 'Woe to you! Bring back Abu al-Husayn, for he has gone out angry!' The chamberlains and servants went out behind him. He entered while making Wasif and Zarafa hear every unpleasant thing, until he reached Al-Mutawakkil. He said: 'What angered you, and why did you leave?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, perhaps you imagine that this kingdom does not have enemies like it has friends! You sit in an assembly where the likes of these dogs debase you, pulling your hem, and each one of them is disguised in a hideous form. What secures that there might be among them an enemy who has counted himself for religion, having a corrupt intention and bad conscience, so he jumps on you! When could this be rectified, even if I emptied the earth of them?' He said: 'O Abu al-Husayn, do not be angry! By Allah, you will never see me in the like of it again.' A balcony was built for Al-Mutawakkil after that, from which he looked at the Samaja. Musa bin Salih bin Sheikh mentioned that he spoke to Ishaq bin Ibrahim regarding a woman of his family, asking him to look into her matter. He said: 'O Abu Muhammad, who is the story of this woman, and what is her condition, and who is her husband?' He said: By Allah, he did not cease describing her until I was bewildered. Abu al-Barq the Poet said: Ishaq used to allocate stipends for me. I recited to him one day, so he asked me about my family and what I needed for them. Then he said to me: 'Your family needs every month so much flour, and so much of this...' He kept informing me of things about my household affairs that I was ignorant of and he knew! He said: A letter from Al-Mu'tasim arrived to Ishaq while he was sitting drinking, and with him was Muhammad bin Rashid al-Khannaq, who was special to him and favored by him. He did not finish reading the letter before he said: 'Whips, racks, and executioners!' They were brought. He ordered Muhammad bin Rashid, so he was raised from his seat, his clothes ripped, and he was set up on the racks, saying: 'O Emir, what is my condition? What is my story?' He said: 'The jewel box that belonged to So-and-so, of such and such description, you bring it to me now, or else you have finished yourself!' He began to hesitate, so he said: 'Hurt him!' When he felt the beating, he said: 'I will bring it, O Emir.' He said: 'By the right of the Commander of the Faithful, you will not leave your place until you bring it!' So he brought it immediately. When Ishaq saw it, he was relieved, his face brightened, and he said: 'Bring clothes.' A robe was brought, and he dressed him. He returned him to his place. He answered the letter and sent the box immediately to Al-Mu'tasim. Muhammad said: 'O Emir, how far is what is between the two actions?' He said: 'Woe to you! I fulfilled the service and advice, and I fulfilled the affection after that its due.' Abu Hashisha the Tanbur player mentioned, saying: I was in my house one day, when the Postmaster knocked on the door and said: 'Answer!' When he said answer, I knew it was a high matter. I dressed and went with him until we entered the house of Ishaq bin Ibrahim. He turned me to a long corridor with facing rooms, from all of which the smells of food wafted. I was put into one of the rooms, and food of the utmost cleanliness and good smell was presented to me, so I ate. They brought me three rotls (cups), and I drank. They brought me a box with tanburs, so I chose a tanbur from them, tuned it to the mode, and was taken out from the place to a room the likes of which I had never seen better. Behold, in its sitting area were two men sitting; on one was a mulham tunic and a sable cap, and on the other silk clothes; and a curtain was drawn in it. I greeted and was ordered to sit, so I sat. The owner of the sable cap said to me: 'Sing!' So I sang: 'I do not see myself but that I will abandon... one who does not see me capable of abandonment. He bored of me, trusting in the goodness of my loyalty... How harmful is loyalty to a human being!'

I sang it, so he drank a rotl, pecked the curtain, and said: 'Sing it!' The song was sung with the best singing in the world, and I thought the room was dancing! He said to me: 'How do you see?' I said: 'By Allah, O my master, they have made this song hateful to me and ugly in my eyes.' He laughed and asked me to repeat it three times, drinking a rotl each time. Then he said: 'Do you know me?' I said: 'No!' He said: 'I am Ishaq bin Ibrahim, and this is Muhammad bin Rashid al-Khannaq. By Allah, if the story of this gathering appears from you, I will flog you three hundred lashes! Stand up if you wish!' I stood up from before him, and the boy caught up with me with a purse containing three hundred dinars. I strove for him to take something from it, but he refused! Amr bin Bana mentioned, saying: Ishaq bin Ibrahim sent for me at the end of the day. I went to his house and was entered upon him while he was sitting in a pavilion (tarima) lined with silk, overlooking the Tigris. The moon had spread over the window and the Tigris, and it was one of the most beautiful sights I ever saw! All the singers were before him, and Badhl was sitting behind a screen in the pavilion. He remained sitting in his place, and we were before him, until the dawn prayer was called. He stood up and we stood up. The servants said to us: 'Depart!' We went down to the riverbank and called for a Sumerian boat. We all sat, and I said to them: 'My house is closer than your houses, so make your stay today at my place.' They did so. We arrived at the house, and I sought something to eat in it but found nothing! I ordered the table to be brought, so it was brought empty. I threw into its center one hundred whole dirhams and said: 'Let each one of you send and buy what he wants.' It was not long before it was filled with everything! We ate and drank, and a good day passed for us. We dispersed at the end of the day, with lumps in our throats from what Ishaq did to us, and what we missed of that beautiful night in that beautiful place! I went after that to Badhl and asked her about the reason for what he did. She said: 'I asked him about that, and he said: Woe to you! I have desired to drink on a night like this for a year, and I have been putting myself off. When I obtained everything I wanted and desired, I wanted to show my soul my authority over it and my conquering of it and preventing it from what it loves, lest it lead me to what it wants. So I did what you saw.' Despite that, he was of good chivalry, generous of soul. Abu Hashisha mentioned, saying: He invited me one day, so I went to him and sat singing to him. On him was a green silk tunic, the likes of which I had never seen. I kept looking at it, and he noticed my look. He called the treasurer and said: 'They brought us days ago ten green silk garments; this is one of them, so bring me the rest.' He brought nine garments, whose beauty exceeded all description. He gave them to me, and I sold the worst of them for one hundred dinars! He said: Ahmad bin Yusuf the Writer visited Ishaq bin Ibrahim at night. He presented to him every beautiful thing of food and instruments. Curtains were hung, and fruits and wine were brought. A day passed the likes of which had not been. Then he asked Ahmad to stay with him the next day. Ahmad said: 'I will miss the hunt.' So he brought a slave girl, a boy, and a horse, the likes of which had not been seen, and said: 'This is your hunt tomorrow.' Then he prepared for him the next day, and Ahmad saw something the likes of which he had never seen. Ishaq said to him: 'Yesterday was youthfulness (futuwwa), and today is chivalry (muruwwa).' Al-Ma'mun used to go to his house and stay with him for days, he and his servants and retinue, out of familiarity with him and trust in his place. Zubaydah passed by one day on the Tigris in her haraqa (barge). She went up to Ishaq's house for some need of hers. Ishaq offered her food, so she ordered it to be brought. She marveled at what she saw and what he presented. She said: 'By Allah, I had no need for it, but I wanted to test his chivalry. I found him the most complete of people in chivalry, and this was without preparation for me or knowledge of my coming.' 

**Dayr Ashmuni (Monastery of Ashmuni)**
Ashmuni was a woman; the monastery was built in her name, and she was buried in it. It is in Qatrabbul, west of the Tigris. Its feast is the third day of October (Tishrin al-Awwal). It is one of the great days in Baghdad; its people gather for it like their gathering for some of their feasts. No one of the people of music and play remains but goes out to it. Some are in Tayyarat (fly-boats), some in Zabazib (skiffs), and some in Sumerians, each person according to his ability. They compete in what they display there of their attire, boast of what they prepare for their revelry, and populate its bank, its sides, its monastery, and its taverns. Tents and pavilions are pitched for those of means among them, and singing girls play for them. Every person remains busy with his affair, devoted to his amusement; it is the most amazing sight and the best and most beautiful scene! There is also a monastery there called Dayr al-Jarjuth, surrounded by gardens and farms. Whoever finds Dayr Ashmuni crowded diverts to it.

Jahza said: I went out on one of the feasts of Ashmuni to Qatrabbul. When I reached the bank, I stretched my eyes to see an empty place to go up to, or some elegant people to descend upon. I saw two youths of the handsomest faces, cleanest clothes, and most novel instruments! I advanced my Sumerian towards them and said: 'Do you permit me to ascend to you?' They said: 'With welcome and spaciousness!' I ascended and said: 'Boy, my Tanbur and my wine!' They said: 'As for the Tanbur, yes; as for the wine, no.' I sat with people of the best character and most pleasant companionship. We started our affair. Then I took the Tanbur and sang a poem of mine: 'Hail to Ashmuni and its pleasures... and the life amidst its gardens. Hail to days passed for me in it... between its two banks and its taverns. When my morning drink was in its orchards... and my evening drink in its monasteries.' The group shouted [in joy], and drank by the rotls, and I drank. The time was pleasant for us until the end of the day. Then I said to one of them: 'May I be your ransom, I do not see in this gathering anyone softer in nature than you two, nor softer in wine.' He answered me saying: 'My wine is thin [delicate] as you have seen... and a friendship with an arrow mixed with a fly.' He pointed to the group, then said: 'So how can I be equal to them... where am I compared to your intellect, or is this a fart?' Then he said: 'Shall I give you more?' I said: 'No.' And the best and most beautiful day passed for us! Muhammad bin al-Mu'ammal al-Ta'i said: I was with Abu al-Atahiya in a Sumerian, and we were traveling to Ashmuni. He heard singing from some direction, admired it, and was delighted by it. He said to me: 'Can you dance?' I said: 'Yes!' He said: 'Stand up let us dance.' I said: 'We are in a Sumerian, and I fear we will drown!' He said: 'And if we drown, what will we be? Will we not be martyrs of delight?' Al-Tharwani has [poetry] in it: 'Drink to the striking of the bells (Nawaqis)... in Dayr Ashmuni at dark dawn. Do not fear the cup of drink, while the night is in... a limit of bliss, no, nor misery. Except to the striking of bells... or the voice of priests and deaconing (Tashmis). For a thing is by its causes... and precise description is by foundation. So drink like this, otherwise be... neighbor to some tombs (Nawawis).' He said: Yahya bin Kamil wrote to Abdul Malik bin Muhammad al-Hashimi on the day of Ashmuni: 'Today is Ashmuni, O Abu al-Fadl... and it is wonderful, pleasant of shade. And you are a victim to the day, so what... shall Yahya do, O Abu al-Fadl?' He sent him what he rode. Al-Jammash knew the news, so he wrote to him: 'Say to the skilled Abdul Malik... and to the cousin of the pure Chosen One. Do you not see the day, and its conditions... call for your urging of the circulating [cup]? A feast and a cloud visited in our day... so fulfill the right of the feast and the visitor. Today is Ashmuni, so hasten with us... urging it in its radiant day. You gifted Yahya then neglected me... you turned away from your Jammash the poet.' So he sent for him and brought him. And a pleasant day passed for them. Abu al-Shibl al-Burjumi has [poetry] in it: 'I witnessed all the places of pleasures... and roamed their spots by sea and land. I did not see a place like Ashmuni... more delicious to its attendees nor more joyful. In it are two armies of horses and ships... they knelt in its shelter and settled. As if they are crawls of war, but... to pleasures they attacked and fled. Their weapons are jugs and bottles... and cups circulating, drag along. And their striking is the third and second strings... when the striking in war intensifies. And the gazelles of the monastery capture them willingly... when the lions of wars are captured by force. Indeed, war has dragged good for us... if war ever dragged evil.' This Abu al-Shibl was one of the pleasant ones, having beautiful poetry and a delicate nature. He was devoted to drinking, never leaving it, and never found except drunk. He used to throw himself into monasteries, taverns, and places of amusement, never missing them nor delaying from them. There was affection between him and Mahmud al-Warraq, and they never separated. Abu al-Shibl mentioned, saying: I and Mahmud went to Qatrabbul. We called the vintner and said: 'Bring us a daughter of ten [years] whom the heat has matured.' He brought it to us. We said: 'Give us drink!' He gave us drink. We said: 'Drink and give us drink!' He said: 'I am a Muslim'—he was a Jew who had converted to Islam. Mahmud said to me: 'A people with whom the vintner is a scrupulous Muslim, while they are disbelievers in the vintner's view, do you think Allah has a need for them?'

He said: Abu al-Shibl used to joke with Khansa, the singing girl of Hisham the Blind Grammarian. She used to compose poetry. He joked with her one day and went too far. She got angry and said: 'I wish I knew, on what do you rely? I am, by Allah, more poetic than you! And if I wish, I will satirize you until I expose you!' He turned to her and said: 'Khansa has exceeded against us... so there is no protector for us from her. She acted haughty with her poems against us... as if Jarir had fucked her.' She became ashamed until it was visible on her, and she stopped answering him. Abu al-Shibl has [poetry] about a black slave girl he loved, for whom he was reproached, as he was fond of blacks: 'A blamer began with prolonged blame... blaming me for blackness and intense black eyes. Woe to you, how is solace from blazes... tarred of faces like obsidian. They carry between the thighs humps... whose wool flies from the glow. May Allah not punish a believer with them... other than me, nor may my relief come from them. For I am delighted with blackness... and I am not very delighted with whites.' He has [poetry] about a girl he loved named Tibr (Gold Dust): 'You were not fair, O namesake of gold... my soul perishes while you are in play. O cousin of the fragrant musk, and who... were it not for you, would not be collected nor smell good. The musk resembled you in blackness and in scent... so how noble is that lineage.' 

**Dayr Sabir (Monastery of Sabir)**
This monastery is in Bazugha, which is between Al-Mazrafah and Al-Salihiyya, on the western side of the Tigris. It is populated, pleasant, with many gardens, fruits, vineyards, taverns, and vintners, inhabited by people of music and drinking. It is a home of the dissolute. The monastery is beautiful, populated, never devoid of a picnicker in it and a music-seeker to it. Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak has [poetry] in it: 'And young women I approached among gardens... so I deflowered them when they were authentically beautiful. I followed the pricking of that one with the pricking of this one... until I drank their blood as wounds. I brought them out of the boudoirs unveiled... and left the protection of their sanctity permissible. In Dayr Sabir while the morning loomed to me... so I gathered a full moon, and the morning, and wine. So go with your thought however you wish, for all of it... is from what I committed of arrogance and unruliness.' Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak was among the literary poets and people of licentiousness and debauchery, and is known as Al-Khali' (The Dissolute). He was a boon companion to a group of Abbasid caliphs, among them: Al-Amin, Al-Mu'tasim, Al-Wathiq, and Al-Mutawakkil. As for Al-Ma'mun, he did not enter upon him nor mix with him, because he elegized Al-Amin, saying about him: 'Would that you remained to fill our need... among us, and destruction was for other than you. There was in you a successor for those who passed... so today the successor is lacking after you.' When Al-Ma'mun arrived from Khurasan to Baghdad, he ordered that the names of those suitable for his companionship from the people of literature be recorded for him. A group was recorded for him in which Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak was mentioned, as he was among the sitters of Muhammad the Deposed. He read their names until he reached the name of Husayn. He said: 'Is he not the one who said about Muhammad: "And destruction was for other than you"? By Allah, I have no need for him, nor shall he see my face except on the main road!' So he did not gain anything throughout the days of Al-Ma'mun! At the time of his service to Al-Mutawakkil, he became weak with old age, so he wrote to him asking to be excused from service, saying: 'I advanced to your ancestors in the past... of my service, one and sixty [years]. I was twenty-five, and I have... completed some and eighty. I am known for the weakness of powers... even if I endure at times. And if I bear in my old age... the service of the sons of thirty. My powers have collapsed and my bones have weakened... and I have become Azzun in illness. And I feared that a hastener would hasten with me... to that which baffles the healers.' This Azzun whom he mentioned was a boon companion to Al-Mu'tasim, then he drank with Al-Mutawakkil. This Azzun mentioned, saying: We were with Al-Mu'tasim in some of his picnics. We needed to wade a river, and Husayn bin al-Dahhak was with us, and he almost drowned. Al-Mu'tasim grabbed his upper arm and carried him from the saddle until he crossed the river with him, out of pity for him. Al-Husayn was very infatuated with servants (eunuchs/boys), and he did not cease from that until he died. Al-Mutawakkil said: Husayn recited to me his saying: 'If you wished, you would have been easy... as you were named, O Yusr. No, by Allah, I will not leave... until the matter is decided. Either prevention and blame... or giving and thanks. So leave me from your promises... since time has destroyed you. So say: Which of them was it? ... He said: Giving and thanks.'

Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun said: We were with Al-Mutawakkil on the day of Nayruz, and gifts were being presented to him, including statues of amber. Shafi' the servant was standing, wearing rose-colored tunics and a rose-colored cloak, and he was the most handsome of people in them. Al-Mutawakkil began giving Shafi' piece after piece of that amber, saying: 'Give it to Husayn,' and squeezing his hand so he would do that. The last thing he gave him was a red rose with which he greeted him. He [Husayn] recited saying: 'And like the white rose, he greeted with a red... rose, moving in robes like the rose. He has playful gestures at every greeting... with his palms, inviting the empty-hearted to passion. I wished to be given a drink by his palms... reminding me of what I had forgotten of the covenant. May Allah water a time in which I did not spend a night... of time except upon a promise from a beloved.' Al-Mutawakkil ordered that he give him drink, and said: 'We have given you your wish.' Husayn used to drink with Salih bin al-Rashid. He drank with him once in a picnic spot in Babbari, which is one of the districts of Kalwadh. He had there a beautiful, majestic garden, its wall and traces remaining until now. He said describing the garden and their morning drink in it—and it is of his beautiful poetry: 'Did he not whisper to you with eloquent gaze... and groan to you from a wounded heart? I wish you, when you abandon him out of harm... would bestow upon him a restful death. In your beauty was the first good opinion of mine... Does your beauty not forbid you from ugliness? He does not cease accusing my advice... with myself, the soul of an accused advisor. I love the shade of the palms of Babbari... and its pavilion built with tin. And the swaying of its two thickets pleases me... towards me with the scent of calendula and wormwood. And I will not forget the wrestling places of the drunks... and the wailing of the dove on the acacias. And a cup in the right hand of a king's confederate... whose attributes are adorned by the blaze of praise. Pure wine, I loved a pure one... and does the pure one fault the pure? O Amr, do you have a desire for the morning drink... come to the friend of every soul. He stood upon the weakness of his eyes... and chained [the wine] with the Saniḥ and the Bariḥ [omens]. And he followed a drunkenness that passed with another... and left sobriety for the stingy misery.' Amr bin Bana mentioned, saying: We were with Salih bin al-Rashid in this garden of his, and with us was Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak. Around us was a great amount of narcissus, and the moon had risen over the trees and blossoms. Our time was of the best time seen. A servant of Salih whom he loved was serving him drink. He said to Al-Husayn: 'Say something in this gathering of ours that Ibn Bana can sing.' He pointed to the servant and said: 'The moon described the beauty of your face until... I thought that I, while not seeing you, see you. And when the fresh narcissus breathed... I imagined it the breeze of your scent. Deceptions of wishes distracting me with you... by the radiance of this and the joy of that. I will surely continue as long as I live on affection... for this and that since they resembled you.' Amr said: 'So I sang it. And the pleasantest and best time passed for us!' Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak said: I was sitting in my house on the day of Washk (a fast day?), and Al-Ma'mun had broken the fast and ordered the people to break the fast. A note came to me from Al-Hasan bin Raja, saying in it: 'I shook you for the morning drink, as the Commander of the Faithful has forbidden me... from fasting. And I have ten of the daughters of Karkh [wine/girls]... with whom the shaking of wine is pleasant. And from the likes of them, if we get drunk... you see us harvesting the fruit of the forbidden. So be the answer, for there is nothing... more beloved to me than omitting speech.' His note reached me, and Muhammad bin al-Harith bin Biskhannar had sent me a boy of his, clean-faced, whom he favored, and with him three peer boys of beautiful faces, and an open note whose bottom was sealed like decrees, in it: 'Go in the name of Allah, O more beautiful... than a branch of silver. Among three of the sons of the Romans... to the house of Husayn. Send the old man to your master... O cool of my eye. Show him violence if he rebels... and demand a debt from him. And leave words and address him... with the wink of eyebrows. And beware returning from your direction... with the boots of Hunayn [empty-handed].' So I went with the boy of Ibn al-Harith, and left going to Al-Hasan. 

**Dayr Quta (Monastery of Quta)**

This monastery is in Al-Baradan, on the bank of the Tigris. Between Al-Baradan and Baghdad are continuous gardens and successive parks. From it to Balshakar, then to Al-Muhammadiyya, then to Al-Tuluni al-Saghir, then to Al-Tuluni al-Kabir, then to Al-Baradan. All of that is gardens, vineyards, trees, and palm trees. Al-Baradan is among the beautiful places, pleasant spots, and described locations. It has many visitors and picnickers. This monastery is in it. It combines many conditions, among them: the population of the town, the abundance of its fruits, and the availability of everything needed in it. Also, wine is freely available there, and taverns are many. Also, in this place is what the people of idleness and licentiousness seek of beautiful faces and pleasant, refreshing spots, so it is hardly ever empty. Abdullah bin al-Abbas bin al-Fadl bin al-Rabi' has [poetry] in it: 'O Dayr Quta, you have stirred in me a delight... that removed from my heart sorrows and distress. How many a night in you I continued joy in it... when I connected the rounds and selections for it. Among youths who spent in revelry what they owned... and spent in youthful passion money and property. And a fawn to whom my eye saw no likeness... among people, neither Persians of them nor Arabs. If he appeared approaching, I called out: O joy!... And if he passed turning away, I called out: O war! I stayed in the monastery until it became a home for me... for his sake, and I wore the hairshirt and the cross. Its deacon became a companion and brother to me... and its priest became a father and dad to me. A gazelle, whose glances are swords against lovers... so whoever approaches him deceived, he strikes with them. If I ask him for union, he shows cruelty and withdraws... or if I ask him for sympathy, he turns away rejecting and refuses. And if I complain to him of the length of his migration... and what I encounter of his distancing, he frowns. By Allah, if he asked me for my soul, I would give it generously... and I would not be stingy with him regarding what he asked.' This Abdullah was among the witty literati, a man of ghazal and licentiousness, frequently throwing himself into monasteries and taverns, and following the people of amusement and debauchery! He has beautiful poetry which is sung, and he also sings his own and others'. Muhammad bin Abdul Malik al-Zayyat said to him one day: 'Recite to me some of your poetry.' He said: 'And what is the worth of my poetry, O Vizier?' He said: 'Are you not the one who says: "And a fawn aimed, when he passed... on Palm Sunday, at my killing. He says to me: How have you become?... How does the likes of me become?" Whoever says this, says what is the worth of my poetry?' He said: Abdullah fell in love with Asalij, the slave girl of his aunt Ruqayya. Badhl the Elder said to him: 'Show me Asalij, so I either excuse you or blame you!' He said: So he invited her to his house, and Badhl attended. Asalij began and sang: 'Have you betrayed my covenant in absence, so why do you... show the boldness of one adhering to the covenant? Connect and do the deed of one bold in his union... otherwise, turn away and do the deed of one turning away.' She brought every beautiful thing in it. He said to Badhl: 'How do you see, O my lady?' Asalij cut the singing and said: 'O Abdullah, you consult about me? By Allah, I did not consult about you when I loved you!' Badhl shouted and said: 'Yes! You did well, by Allah, O girl! Even if you did not do anything well and had no praiseworthy trait, you deserve to be loved for this word. You did well, by Allah!' Then she said: 'You did well, by Allah, O Abdullah, I excuse you!' From Abdullah's poetry: 'Give me wine, I have cast off restraint... and bore regarding you "he said" and "it was said" (gossip). Give me the expeller of worries and do not mix... of it in the morning except a little.' From his poetry: 'O hail to my day at Al-Daliyah... we drink it Qufsiyya (from Qufs), pure. With every chief wasting his money... no remainder remains for him in the world. So take from the world and its pleasures... for we are but borrowed in it.' He said: Abdullah wrote to a friend of his inviting him: 'May I be your ransom, I and a pen, and you know!' Abdullah used to love a Christian slave girl and was mad about her. He has regarding her: 'An image in a church tempted us... May Allah tempt the one who painted her. The engraver increased in beautifying her... that when he fashioned her, he made her Christian.' He has a melody in it. Masabih, the slave girl of Al-Ahdab the Barber, used to sing this song, and sing much of his poetry. She was the best narrator of it and most knowledgeable of singing it. She was described with beauty and proficiency. Abdullah loved her. Among what she sang of Abdullah's poetry:

'Do give me a morning drink on Palm Sunday... of a coffee-colored wine aged in Karkh. At the place of people whom my heart is fond of... even if they follow a religion other than my religion.' For Abdullah regarding Masabih—and he had said this poetry and sung it while she was present, so she took it from him, and Mutayyam al-Hashimiya also sang it: 'Indeed I loved an enemy... so may God water my enemy. I ransomed her with my relatives... and my family and my neighbors. She was braided like the braiding of bamboo... and bent so she swayed. And she became certain that the heart... loves her, so she acted boldly.' He said: Masabih got angry with Abdullah bin al-Abbas over something she heard about him. He tried to please her, but she refused. He wrote her a note, swearing in it that he did not do anything of what she denied, and invoking against the wrongdoer. She did not answer him anything of what he wrote, but signed under the invocation: 'Against the wrongdoer. Amen.' She did not add to that. He wrote to her: 'As for my joy with the answer... it will not perish as long as we remain. And the most secret letter in it to me is... Amen, Lord of the Worlds.' From his poetry: 'Gold in gold circulated... by a branch of silver. So a delight of an eye came... in the hand of a delight of an eye. A moon carrying a sun... welcome to the two luminaries. A thousand intoxications, two thousand... together, combined. May no bird of separation run between me... nor between them. Rather we remained as long as we remained... forever embracing. In morning drink and evening drink... we did not sell cash for credit.' 

**Dayr Mar Jarjis (Monastery of St. George)**
This monastery is in Al-Mazrafah. It is one of the monasteries and intended places. Picnickers from the people of Baghdad always go out to it in Sumerians, due to its proximity and goodness. It is on the bank of the Tigris. The waterwheels are before it, gardens surround it, and taverns neighbor it. Everything picnickers need is present in it. Al-Mazrafah is among the best populated lands and most pleasant spots, having gardens that no other land has. Abu Jafna al-Qurashi has [poetry] in it—he was of the dissolute, addicted to drinking, throwing himself into monasteries and taverns. He was never without beardless boys, some serving him and some singing to him: 'The birds trilled after their silence... and the cold retreated in its reins. And the rose and spring flower approached... a time of revelry walking with its rope. How good is union if I escape, so... her abandonment does not sting me with its venom. And like the color of blood, pure wine... goes with a man above his ambition. I contended for it with one whose warp is always... in love and debauchery like his woof. In Dayr Mar Jarjis, when the dawn... wafted upon us the spirits of its flower. I want from him, and nothing prevents me... from that thing except his shyness. He fulfilled his promise and his visit... and I was most fulfilling to him in his covenant.' From his beautiful poetry: 'And a groom seeking the morning drink, and I am... a youth whom the morning drink suits early. I knocked pure wines with the water of a cloud... so they produced joy when I knocked them. I drank then gave him drink, as if... I poured camphor over his uvula. And a youth circulating to you in his delights... a wine that generates languor in the bones. And if your lips sipped its saliva... the wine wrote light on your beautiful face. I did not cease drinking it and giving my companion drink... until I saw his tongue broken. From what the merchants selected in Babylon... or what the Jews aged in Sura.' He has: 'And one of turned-away face, the like of whom people have not seen... I circulated the cup to him when he got angry. He blames me if I seek a kiss on the cheek... and turns away from me whenever I say: Welcome. Were it not for what shakes under his waist-wrapper... I would have stung him from me, when he turned away, a scorpion. I circulated to him a Babylonian coffee-colored wine... showing you its potency on the cup as a star. When the cupbearer mixed it with water, it donned... over the mix a shirt of gilded pearls.' Al-Numayri has [poetry] in it: 'I stayed at Mar Jarjis, the best dwelling... I remembered in it days of amusement that passed for me. Joy encompassed us in it and surrounded us... so from below joy comes and from above. Time made peace in it and aided... and the vicissitudes of accidents stood aside. A belted gazelle circulates the cup to us... urging its cups, not falling short. O life, how pure! And O amusement, last for us... and O arrival of pleasures, you are greeted, so dismount.'

He is Abu al-Tayyib, Muhammad bin al-Qasim al-Numayri. He was of the people of literature and virtue, with beautiful poetry and a delicate nature. He had status and wealth. He used to drink frequently in monasteries and taverns, finding pleasure in that. Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz used to be familiar with him and not leave him. There were correspondences, poetic contests, and pleasant banter between them. We mention some of it: Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz said: Al-Numayri wrote to me one day, after I had invited him: 'I saw you inviting me to drink late... and cutting off the drink from me while the night is enjoyable. So either you drink wine all your night... or you drink wine while the sun is shining. Whichever you prefer, I fulfill its right... and that which you desire is a dissolute drink.' He said: I wrote to him on a feast day, and he had not come to me that day: 'By my father, has something become sweet in your eye... that consoled you, O my friend, after me? The taste of my cup is bitter if you do not visit me... and it is sweet if I see you with me.' He wrote to me: 'My master, you did not want me, so what is... my trick since I am afflicted by rejection from you? Allah knows what I endure of my longing... and my heartbreak and grief at my distance.' Abdullah said: I wrote to him once inviting him, and he wrote to me: 'I have people, and perhaps I can get rid of them.' He suspended the promise. I wrote to him: 'O you who delay my promise... if you wished you would come at its time. So fall upon us a falling... and do not flutter for his treachery. For if I seize your two legs... after this time... I will imprison you with me... upon harm and injury.' Abdullah said: Al-Numayri wrote to me at the end of Sha'ban: 'O Abu al-Abbas, Sha'ban has tucked up... his waist-wrapper. And went striving so no human... catches his dust. So go early, let us drink the purity of the jar... and rob it of its dignity. And if reason is mentioned... we drink to its memory.' He said: He wrote to me, when our meeting was delayed: 'With you, death in company is better... than life in loneliness and isolation. Inform me of their meeting on this day of theirs... and they monopolized against me in the appointment. And Al-Hariri is their head, and sufficient for me... is Al-Hariri as the head of every corruption. If he sees a singing girl, he is moved to passion... and loosens his wing for mounting. And he addresses her and moves his sides... and she pleases the desire of the children.' I apologized to him and asked him to come to us, so he came. Abdullah said: He wrote to me: 'If I am absent I am not sought, and if I come I am not connected... and I am more deserving of blame but I am not blaming. I will endure the excruciating longing hating it... and watch for a good day in the consequences. Not everyone you accompanied is like Qasim... so measure him and think about the path of those who went.' He said: He wrote to me on a Thursday I was fasting: 'Abu al-Abbas, O best of mankind... you fast, and this is not a day of fasting. Do you have a desire for the wine of a witty brother... who helps in the lawful and the forbidden?' He said: Al-Numayri wrote to me, finding my messenger slow and apologizing for his delay from me, mentioning that he was busy cultivating his garden. I answered him: 'As for what you mentioned of my messenger's delay from you to ask about your news in these days and check on you, I saw you turned the sayer's saying: "Catch the thief before he catches you!" Otherwise, I did not fall short in asking about you and sending to you. But what do I say to one whose sick friend relapsed and he did not visit him? And he missed him but did not visit him? Busy knocking on taverns and monasteries, riding Zallals (boats), flirting with singing girls, and drinking the daughter of the jars, combining the two ends of his day with an evening drink whose night-talkers do not calm, and a morning drink whose early risers do not slacken, in two armies of amusement: one beating the water with its oars, and another striking the earth with its trot and gallop. You asked about my news in these rains; what can I say about the favor for which thanks is obligatory to Allah Almighty, as it skipped us after it drew its sword and we feared its injustice.' Abdullah said: Al-Numayri wrote to me: 'An Emir I used to hope for my time... if it struck with a grave matter.

I fell ill, but he did not visit me in my illness... and wandered away from visiting and the messenger. I have no need calling for what... I humiliate myself for to the possessor of nobility who gives. Nor to one crowned with kingship who is proud... when I am content with little.' So I wrote him a note, at the end of it: 'In every day obedience and disobedience... and boredom and flattery and abandonment. Characters as if they are ghouls.' He said: I invited him for a day I named, but my messenger was late to him, so he wrote to me: 'You invited us then changed your mind... fuck in his ass whoever is loyal to you.' He said: Al-Numayri wrote to me: 'Longing to drink has exhausted me... with a master who flees from my proximity. I did not know him to be harsh... but he began shunning me without sin. By Allah, I know no sin for me with him... except excess in love. And that I never displeased him for an hour... in present seriousness or play.' He wrote to him: 'O you who shun and is shunned... your accusation is not of wit. You and longing for us are like one who... believes in Allah on an edge. You erased your traces from our affection... except your legends in the pages. And if you took upon yourself a visit to us... one day, you bore it with weakness.' He said, and he wrote to me: 'I came to you happy, so drinking was pleasant for me... and the eye and heart attained their wish with you. But the Cup was unjust to me so I abandoned it... three days as the sin required.' I wrote to him: 'Why did you abandon the Cup when its rule was unjust... and there is no amusement unless you are, so what is the sin? May Allah perpetuate joy for you and perpetuate for me... life and comfort through you, and may closeness connect.' Abdullah said: Al-Numayri sent a messenger to me on Friday, and I said to him: 'Ride with us to the prayer.' The messenger found him having taken a morning drink. He said to him: 'Tell him: I have been praying since the morning prayer.' I wrote to him: 'O you who prays a prayer... in which is obedience to Iblis. If you accept my thanks... then thanks in this is shamelessness!'
