He said: I wrote to him when I was ill, and he did not visit me: 'Praise be to Allah, even you shun me... after purity, a shunning not little. I was expecting this so you brought it... and no creation is safe from treachery.' He wrote apologizing with a business of his and the illness of his mount. I wrote to him: 'Do not apologize! We have known... you will do your deed. You mentioned a business, so why not... make me some of your business? Or did you not have a donkey... so you could ride your sandals?' He said: He wrote to me: 'If I committed a sin... I have trusted in your grace. I have come to you walking... as you decreed with your justice.' And he came to me walking. Al-Numayri said: Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz used to criticize love greatly, to the point of saying: 'It is a side of stupidity.' If he saw one of us looking down or thinking, he accused him of this meaning and said: 'You have fallen, O So-and-so, and your mind has diminished and you have become foolish!' Until we saw him struck by severe absent-mindedness and constant thought, until verses began to slip from him about the meaning of love. Once he says: 'Love captured a prince... who was not a captive before. So have mercy on the humiliation of a mighty one... who became a slave seeking refuge.' And once he says: 'The mind of the lover is absent-minded... in his heart are calamities.' I said: 'May Allah make me your ransom! These are things you used to criticize the likes of from us, and we now deny them from you!' He returns feigning, but it is not long before a slip slips from him. He said once: 'Maktum, O most beautiful of Allah's creation... do not leave me like this, by Allah.' Then he sighed. I said: 'Love has won over Abdullah... and the veil is torn, praise be to Allah.' So say to him: Name to us, by Allah... this one whom you love, by the right of Allah! He laughed and said: 'No, and no honor.' I wrote to him the next day: 'His eye wept and he complained of a burning... from passion in the heart that does not extinguish. I said to him: My master, what is it... I see in you? He said: A hidden illness. I said: Is it love? He said: Limit yourself... to what you see; does it not suffice?' He wrote to me: 'O you who talks about me... with the suspicion of hearing and eye. If you are seeking my secret... then return with the boots of Hunayn.' I wrote to him: 'Far be it, your luck, by Allah... is that you reveal your love.

'Leave the boots of Hunayn... and strive to untie your saliva [speak]. Come let us scheme in what... you desire, with my gentleness and your gentleness.' Then I went to him. He told me his story, so I strove for him with gentle strategy, and he aided me with firm opinion, until he won the victory and attained the desire. 

**Dayr Bashahra**
This monastery is on the bank of the Tigris, between Samarra and Baghdad. It is a beautiful, populated, pleasant monastery, with many gardens and vineyards. It is one of the intended places and famous monasteries. Those descending from Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) and those ascending to it stay there. Whoever makes it a way station spends the night there and stays if it pleases him. Whoever intends it stays for days in the most delicious and good life, and the most beautiful and pleasant place! Abu al-Ayna' has [poetry] in it; he had stayed there, remained for days, found it pleasant, and said about it: 'We stayed at Dayr Bashahra... upon its priest, at noon. Upon the religion of Jesus... so he did not give a legal opinion nor keep a secret. He bestowed beautiful action... that enslaves the free. He gave us drink and quenched us... from the pure virgin [wine]. The time was pleasant in the monastery... so we garrisoned in it for ten [days]. We were given the sun to drink... and served by the moon. The pleasure of the cup revived... but killed with drunkenness. We attained all we desired... of our pleasures, openly. We engaged in youthful passion, sang... and spiteed time with it. We fucked, and were dissolute... and the likes of me tore the veil. Our Lord helped us... willingly from Him, not by force. May Allah reward him for good... with which we met good. I extended thanks to him... as he extended kindness.' Abu al-Ayna' was among the witty. Al-Mutawakkil used to admire his speech, quick answers, and anecdotes. He went blind at the age of forty. Indicating that is the saying of Abu Ali al-Basir about him: 'I had feared the hand of time... upon you when sight went. I did not know that by blindness... you become rich and mankind becomes poor.' He had good poetry, good improvisation, beautiful writing and epistolary style, and a sharp tongue in insulting people and alluding to them. We mention a part of his news, in an amount that does not lead to lengthiness, nor violates the condition. Al-Mutawakkil said to Abu al-Ayna': 'What is the hardest thing you passed through in the loss of your sight?' He said: 'Missing seeing you, O Commander of the Faithful, given the consensus of people on your beauty.' He said to him one day: 'O Muhammad, how long will you praise people and blame them?' He said: 'As long as they do evil and do good.' Ubaydullah bin Sulayman said to him: 'We have ordered something for you at this time, so take it and excuse.' He said: 'I will not, O Vizier! If you apologize in calamity, and apologize in power, when will you not apologize?' He asked Sa'id bin Makhlad for a letter to write for him to Egypt. He began saying: 'To Egypt, O Abu al-Ayna', to Egypt?' He said: 'And why do you consider Egypt far for me, may Allah honor you? By Allah! Reaching what is in your chests is farther for me than what is in Egypt!' He entered upon Abu al-Saqr, who brought him near and seated him close. He said: 'O Vizier! Bringing the friend close and depriving the enemy!' He entered upon him one day. He [Abu al-Saqr] said: 'What delayed you from us, Abu Abdullah?' He said: 'My donkey was stolen!' He said: 'And how was it stolen?' He said: 'I was not with the thief to know how he stole it!' Then he came to him after a period. He said: 'What delayed you from us, Abu Abdullah?' He said: 'From obstacles and the humiliation of the muleteer.' So he ordered fifty dinars for him. He said: Abu al-Ayna' entered one day upon Muhammad bin Abdul Malik al-Zayyat, who did not raise his glance to him nor speak to him! He said: 'Indeed, part of the right of Allah's blessing upon you, when He qualified you for the state you are in, is that you make openness to those in need of you a character trait. For he who is lonely withdraws from asking. By frequent asking with success, joy lasts, and by fulfilling needs, blessings last.' Muhammad said to him: 'I know you as a meddler, talking much. Do you think the length of your tongue prevents your discipline if you slip?' And he ordered him to prison! Abu al-Ayna' wrote to him from prison: 'I knew that the imprisonment was not for a sin that preceded from me, but you loved to show me your power over me, because everything new is enjoyed. There is no harm if you show us of your pardon what you showed us of your power!' So he ordered his release. He met him after a long time on the road. Muhammad stopped his beast and said: 'I do not see you, Abu Abdullah, connecting with us according to our saving of you!' Abu al-Ayna' said: 'As for the knowledge of your care, it is confirmed. But I reckon that what renewed your finding me slow is the emptiness of your prison of those in it, so you wanted to populate it with me!'

He said: He entered one day upon a man who had been removed from a position he held. He said: 'If the blessing was ugly on you, the vengeance has been beautiful on you!' He said: 'Why is that?' He said: 'Because I asked you less than your capability, and you rejected me with uglier than your face.' Then he said: 'Say to Zayd bin Sa'id... Removal came to you with kindness. So swallow the worry and be patient... for upon your Lord is the compensation. You too, if you govern... do not increase in arrogance.' He said: Ibn Badr passed by Abu al-Ayna' while he was sitting at his door. He said: 'Is this your house, Abu Abdullah?' He said: 'Yes! If you wish to see your bad effect in it, dismount!' He said: He passed by the house of Abdullah bin Mansur one day while he was sick and had recovered. He said to his servant: 'What is the news of Abu Muhammad?' He said: 'As you like!' He said: 'Then why do I not hear screaming in the house?' He said: Abu al-Ayna' mentioned Maymun bin Ibrahim, saying: 'If a man contemplated his actions and avoided them, he would dispense with seeking etiquettes!' Abu al-Ayna' said: Muhammad bin Mukram said to me: 'Do you not know me?' I said: 'Yes, but a knowledge I pity you for!' Muhammad bin Mukram said to him one day: 'O Abu Abdullah, everything you have is from people, even your children!' Abu al-Ayna' said: 'I saw Ibn Mukram, and I saw his belly as the belly of a pregnant woman, his soul as the soul of a love-struck woman, his snot as the snot of a bereaved mother, and in his ass is the greatest calamity!' Ibn Mukram said to him one day: 'O Abu Abdullah, are you fasting anything with us this month?'—and it was the month of Ramadan. He said: 'Will the old woman let us fast?' A man said to Ubaydullah bin Sulayman: 'If you see fit, may Allah honor you, to issue a sustenance for me.' He said: 'Who is the man, so the sustenance comes out according to that?' He said: 'From the children of Adam!' Abu al-Ayna' said: 'Preserve, may Allah honor you, this lineage, for its origin has been cut off!' He said: Al-Jahiz and Abu al-Ayna' met at Al-Hasan bin Wahb's. Al-Jahiz said to him: 'I knew that Muhammad bin Abdullah is better than Amr bin Bahr, and Abu Abdullah is better than Abu Uthman. But Al-Jahiz is better than Abu al-Ayna'.' Abu al-Ayna' said: 'Far from it! You came to what is hidden of our affairs and preferred me over yourself in it, and to what is known, and preferred yourself in it. Abu al-Ayna' indicates a kunya (nickname), and Al-Jahiz indicates a defect (bulging eyes)! The kunya, even if ugly, is better than the defect, even if successful!' Abu al-Ayna' said: A woman in Basra fell in love with me without seeing me, but she used to hear the sweetness of my speech. When she saw me, she found me ugly and said: 'May Allah make him ugly, is this him?' So I wrote to her: 'And I was told, when she saw me, she denied... and said: Ugly, cross-eyed, he has no body. If you deny from me cross-eyedness, indeed I am... literary, intelligent, neither inarticulate nor stupid.' She signed on the note: 'O biter of his mother's clitoris, did I want you for the Bureau of Correspondence?' Abu al-Ayna' has about Ali bin al-Jahm: 'Ali wanted to say a poem... in praise of the Commander of the Faithful, so he called the Adhan. I said to him: Do not hasten with Iqama... for I am not in a state of purity. He said: Nor am I.' Abu al-Ayna' said: I came to Abdullah bin Dawud al-Khuraybi and asked him to narrate [Hadith] to me. He considered me too young and said: 'Go and memorize the Quran.' I said: 'I have memorized it.' He said: 'Read from the beginning of the sixties of Yunus.' I read the ten. He said: 'You did well. Go and learn the laws of inheritance.' I said: 'I have memorized them.' He said: 'So which is closer to you: your uncle or your nephew?' I said: 'My nephew.' He said: 'Why is that?' I said: 'Because this one is from my father's children, and this one is from my grandfather's children.' He said: 'You did well. Go and learn Arabic.' I said: 'I have done so and learned of it what is sufficient.' He said: 'So why did Umar bin al-Khattab say'—meaning when he was stabbed—'Ya lillahi, Ya lil-Muslimin (O for Allah, O for the Muslims)?' I said: 'Because the first is a call for help (Istighatha), and the second is a call (Nida).' He said: 'If I were to narrate to anyone of your age, I would narrate to you!'

Abu al-Ayna' said: I entered upon Abu Ahmad Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir. It was a summer day, and people were before him playing chess. He said: 'O Abu Abdullah, we are playing for stakes until our food is ready. In which of the two parties would you like to be?' I said: 'In the Emir's party, may Allah support him, for it is higher and more splendid.' So we lost! Abu Ahmad said: 'O Abu Abdullah, we have lost! And your share [of the loss] is twenty rotls of snow. Bring it, O Emir.' I jumped up and went to Abu al-Abbas bin Thawaba. I conveyed greetings to him from Abu Ahmad and said to him: 'He misses you and wanted to write you a note, but he feared your dodging, so he sent me as a messenger and burdened me with a message, and we will not separate except in his presence!' So he rode with me, and we came. When I stood before him, I said: 'O Emir, I have brought you the mountain of Hamadan as snow, so deduct from it what we gambled, and play with your friends for the rest!' He laughed until he lay on his back! He asked Ibn Thawaba about the story, so he knew the news. When he understood it, he cursed me and left! Abu al-Ayna' said: I entered upon Al-Mutawakkil, prayed for him, and spoke to him. He admired my speech and said to me: 'It reached me that there is evil in you!' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, if evil is mentioning the doer of good with his goodness and the doer of evil with his evil, then Allah, Glorious and Exalted, has praised and blamed. He said in praise: "Excellent is the servant, indeed he was repeatedly turning back [to Allah]." And He said in blame: "A slanderer, going about with calumnies. A hinderer of the good, transgressor, sinful. Cruel, moreover, and an illegitimate pretender." So He blamed, Exalted is His Name. The poet said: "If I do not praise the one of good constantly... and do not curse the mean, blameworthy coward. Then for what did I know good and evil by name... and why did Allah split for me hearing and a mouth?" But if evil is like the act of the scorpion that stings the Prophet and the Dhimmi by a nature that does not distinguish, then Allah has protected your servant from that.' He said to me: 'And it reached me that you are a Rafidi (Shia).' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, and how can I be a Rafidi when my city is Basra, my upbringing in its congregate mosque, my teacher Al-Asma'i, and my neighbors Bahila? People are not devoid of wanting religion or world. If they want religion, the Muslims have agreed on advancing those they delayed and delaying those they advanced. And if they want the world, you and your ancestors are the Commanders of the Faithful; there is no religion except by you and no world except with you. Your father is the desolator of Al-Ayth, and in your hands are the treasuries of the earth, and I am your client.' He said: 'Ibn Sa'dan claimed that about you!' I said: 'And who is Ibn Sa'dan? By Allah, that one does not distinguish between the Imam and the Ma'mum, nor the follower and the followed. That is but a carrier of a stick, a teacher of boys, taking a wage for the Book of Allah.' He said: 'Do not do that, for he is the tutor of Al-Mu'ayyad.' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, he did not tutor him for free, but tutored him for a wage. If you give him his due, you have fulfilled his right.' Ibn Sa'dan stood up and said: 'O Abu al-Ayna', no, by Allah, the Commander of the Faithful did not speak the truth in anything he narrated about me!' Then he turned to Al-Mutawakkil and said: 'What is easier for you, O Commander of the Faithful, than that your session ends as you like, then this one goes out and tears me apart!' He said: So Al-Mutawakkil laughed. Then he said: 'How is this house of mine?' I said: 'I saw people built their houses in the world, and you put the world in your house!' He said to me: 'What do you say about Ubaydullah bin Yahya?' I said: 'A servant to Allah and to you, divided between His obedience and your service, preferring your satisfaction over every benefit, and what returns with the welfare of your subjects over every pleasure.' He said: 'What do you say about the Postmaster Maymun bin Ibrahim?' He knew that I was angry with him for a shortcoming of his towards me. I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful: A hand that steals and an ass that farts! He is like a Jew who stole half his Jizya; so he has boldness for what he paid, and with it hesitation for what remained. His evil is nature, and his goodness is affectation!' He said: 'I want you to sit with me.' I said: 'I cannot bear that, nor am I strong enough for it. I do not say this out of ignorance of the honor I have in this assembly; but I am a man who is screened. The signal of the screened varies, and your gesture is hidden from him. It is possible for me to speak with the speech of an angry one while your face is pleased, and with the speech of a pleased one while your face is angry. If I do not distinguish between these two, I perish. So I choose safety over exposure to calamity.' He said: 'You spoke the truth! But you must visit us.' I said: 'The obligation of a mandatory duty.' He gave me ten thousand dirhams. He said to me one day, when I entered upon him: 'O Muhammad, no one remained in the assembly but backbit you except me.' I said: 'If the noble of my clan are pleased with me... may their mean ones never cease to be angry with me.' He is Abu Abdullah, Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin Khallad bin Yasir bin Sulayman. His origin is from Yamama, from Banu Hanifa themselves. His residence was in Basra. Then he moved to Baghdad, and went to Surra Man Ra'a, met Al-Mutawakkil, and stayed there.

He had good writing, eloquent speech, beautiful poetry, a tongue loose in blame and complaining, quick answers, and present wit; no one could stand against him. Al-Mutawakkil said: 'I desire to have Abu al-Ayna' as a boon companion were it not that he is blind!' That reached Abu al-Ayna', so he said: 'If the Commander of the Faithful excuses me from sighting the crescents, stringing pearls and rubies, and reading the engravings of rings, then I am suitable for him.' Muhammad bin Mukram screened Abu al-Ayna' [from entering], then wrote apologizing to him. Abu al-Ayna' wrote to him: 'You screen me face-to-face and apologize to me in writing!' His stories are many, but we have presented as much as the book can bear and the condition requires, without driving its reader to boredom. Ibn Mukram wrote to Abu al-Ayna': 'I have Sikbaj that terrifies the madman, and talk that delights the sad one, and your brothers the jokers (Mahazun? Unclear). So do not rise against me and come.' Abu al-Ayna' answered him: 'Be driven into it and do not speak to Me.' [Quran 23:108] 

**Dayr al-Khawat (Monastery of the Sisters)**
This monastery is in 'Ukbara. It is a large, populated monastery, inhabited by women who became nuns and devoted themselves in it. It is in the middle of gardens and vineyards, well-located, a pleasant place. Its feast is the first Sunday of the Fast (Lent). Everyone near it from Christians and Muslims gathers there; these celebrate and those picnic. In this feast is the Night of Mashush, which is a night where women mix with men; no one restrains his hand from anything, and no one refuses anyone anything. It is one of the mines of drink, abodes of revelry, and places of amusement. Al-Najim Abu Uthman has [poetry] in it: 'Ah, my heart, from passion, ah... from adorned, beautiful maidens. And a girl like a willow branch... with a face like the light of morning. O people of Dayr al-Khawat, by Allah my Lord... is there any sin decreed upon a lover?' This Abu Uthman was the narrator of Ibn al-Rumi. He had beautiful poetry, a gentle nature, and good meanings in describing wine, songs, and love. From his beautiful poetry: 'Circulate, O Salama, the cup of wine... and match with your singing the singing of turtledoves. And take it aged, tangy... pouring upon the night the robe of day. The cheek disputes its color... and gifts it to the eye on the day of hangover.' From his beautiful poetry: 'Salama bin Sa'id... excels in urging the wine. If he sings, we play the reed [Zamr]... upon him with cups.' He has: 'Atib and her lute never spoke... except we intended amusement and joy. She has singing like healing in a body... wasted by long illness and grief. The wine worships her, so when she speaks... our pitcher is prostrating to the cup.' He has: 'Atib and her lute never spoke... except we remained working the wine. Their strings demand worries with strings... so they do not wake up, killing them.' He has, and it has a melody: 'Longing did not call me except... the eye shed tears. I only weep because... I have become a suckling to love. O most beautiful of people and most worthy of... people for beauty, all of them. I do not see for myself, from my beloved... a pulling away for the eternity of time.' 

**Dayr al-'Alth (Monastery of al-'Alth)**
Al-'Alth is a village on the bank of the Tigris, on its eastern side. Before it in the Tigris is a difficult place, a narrow passage with large stones and strong current, where ships pass with difficulty. These places are called Al-Abwab (The Gates). When ships arrive at Al-'Alth, they dock there. Crossing is not possible for them except with a guide from its people whom they hire. He holds the rudder and navigates them through those places, not landing them until he clears them. This monastery overlooks the Tigris. It is one of the best situated monasteries and most pleasant places, intended from every land, and visited by everyone. It is hardly devoid of a descender or ascender. Whoever enters it does not pass it to another due to its goodness, pleasantness, and the availability of everything needed in Al-'Alth and in it. Jahza has [poetry] in it: 'O two sailors, by Allah, strive... and fix for me the sail and the rudders. Make me reach, may you be guided, Al-Baradan... and bring down for me jars from the jars. And turn me to Al-Qabisa then Al-Zahra... perhaps I can relieve the sorrows. And if I stay a full year... then head with me to the vineyards of Awana. And bring me down to an old wine... its Jews have aged it for eras. And lower the sail for me at the monastery in Al-'Alth... perhaps I may associate with the monks.

And gazelles reciting a book of the Gospel... they went early at dawn for an offering. Wearing clothes of haircloth... Allah made willow branches beneath them. Shy, until when the cup circulated... they uncovered throats and crosses. Thin, until I thought it the cheek of one who... exchanged my union for abandonment. Al-Mu'tamid has: 'O length of my night at Fam al-Sulh... I followed my loss with profit. My sorrow for a time of ours that passed... at the Palace, Al-Qatul, and Al-Shalh. At the monastery in Al-'Alth and its monks... between Palm Sunday to Epiphany.' Al-Mu'tamid had good poetry and unmeasured poetry. Perhaps he said verses, some correct and the rest corrupt. He used to give them to singers, who would compose melodies for them, so his defect in scansion and melodies would be hidden except from the elite. Bid'a said: Al-Mu'tamid used to send his poetry to 'Arib to compose melodies for it. She used to say: 'Woe is me! How much shall I sing in the letters A, B, T, Th?' Al-Suli said: Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz recited to me from his measured poetry: 'Praise be to Allah, my Lord... You owned the owner of my heart. So I became a slave to my possession... and he became a master to my love.' From his poetry, when Al-Muwaffaq moved him frequently from place to place: 'I became accustomed to distance and alienation... so every day I tread a soil. And every day I see an event... that brings a distress to my liver. Time is bitter to us in its taste... so we do not see a sweet hour.' This is good poetry, correct in its meaning. From his measured poetry: 'I was afflicted with a fawn like the full moon in beauty... torturing me with types of cruelty. I have two eyes whose tears are abundant... and their sleep is less than loyalty.' Al-Suli mentioned that Al-Muktafi brought out to them scrolls written in gold of Al-Mu'tamid's poetry. Among the measured ones was: 'By Allah, my torment has prolonged... and my concern and my depression. Because of a gazelle from the children of the Yellow (Romans)... who does not care about what is in me. I am fond of his love... and he is fond of avoiding me. And if I say: Connect me... "No" was his answer.' It also contained: 'Love hastened with his separation... so in my heart is a burning from it. Possessing my slavery by love... and I am the king of his slavery. The lover only finds rest... if he reveals his love.' Al-Mu'tamid has poetry sung by Shariya, in the Ramal mode: 'I was deliberate in love for a long time... but I did not see a day of joy in love.' And among what she sang of his poetry: 'O soul, woe to you, what is wrong with you... indeed I deny your condition.' And he has: 'I have become unable to repel what... I am subjected to of eclipse and humiliation. The affairs of people proceed without me and... no paucity is felt of me in their mention. If I desire a thing, they turn it away... from me, and say: Here is a cause.' He said: Al-Mu'tamid asked for three hundred dinars to give to 'Arib, who was present with him, but they were not found! So he asked for two hundred dinars, but they were not found! So he wept and said: 'Is it not among the wonders that the likes of me... sees what is little denied to him? And the whole world is taken in his name... yet nothing of that is in his hands! To him wealth is carried from everywhere... yet he is denied some of what is collected for him!' It was, when he delegated affairs to his brother Abu Ahmad (Al-Muwaffaq), and found rest in his sufficiency to undertake them, and his freeing him for amusement, drinking, and play, and abandoning looking into anything of the kingdom's affairs or asking about it, Abu Ahmad coveted, monopolized the command, and dominated the kingdom. Al-Mu'tamid wanted to change the situation after that, but it was difficult and impossible for him, and he was denied. People coveted him when they saw him overcome in his affair and saw neither harm nor benefit in his hand.

Ishaq bin Ruh mentioned that Muflih sent him to Al-Mu'tamid and said: 'Tell him: I have heard Hazar, the Commander of the Faithful's slave girl, and I liked her and wanted to own her; and I saw Badr al-Julnar and I liked him, and wanted to own him. Let the Commander of the Faithful send them to me.' I delivered the message to Al-Mu'tamid after asking his permission. When he heard it, he got angry, tore his clothes, and said: 'Is this how slaves do to masters, forcing them regarding their harems and boys?' He spoke great things. We left, then he returned us having calmed down, and said: 'The likes of Abu Salih is not turned away from his request. I have ordered Hazar to be carried with her clothing, furniture, maids, and all she has. As for Badr al-Julnar, he has fallen into our service and has a place with us. Tell him to aid us by leaving him.' I returned to Muflih and informed him of a part of the first and of the last. He was about to leave for Basra to fight the Leader of the Zanj. He said: 'O Abu Ishaq, Hazar is secured. When we return from this war, we will take Badr al-Julnar from him, whether he wills or refuses.' He went out, was hit by an arrow, and died. Al-Mu'tamid was one of the most generous of the Abbasids. Comparisons were made between him and Al-Musta'in, and it is said no one more generous than them ruled. He was of good management, understanding affairs. When his command was undermined and his opinion overcome, his status diminished among people. Muhammad bin Ubaydullah bin Yahya bin Khaqan said: My father sent me to Al-Mu'tamid for something. He said to me: 'Sit.' I considered that great and returned the matter to me, apologizing that it was not permissible for me. He said to me: 'O Muhammad, your politeness in accepting from me is better than your politeness in opposing me.' He said: Some associates of Musa bin Bugha wronged Muhammad bin Ali the Scribe, known as Badhinjanah. When Musa died, he satirized him, saying: 'Musa the priest of the monastery died... May the Merciful curse Musa. For he was weak... in the piety of Allah, base. So my joy is released and sad... ness has become a prisoner.' This poetry reached Al-Mu'tamid, so he refuted it, saying: 'The best of people, Musa, died... May the Merciful have mercy on Musa. For he was majestic... of high rank, a chief. He released sadness and left... my joy stopped, imprisoned.' From his rejected poetry is his saying: 'What is with me and this love, what is with me... If I could, I would ransom it with my money. And this beloved does not connect with me... So I am in a fight with his abandonment. It appeared to me according to what I see, so I love him... and, by Allah, I was not what appeared to me.' And he has of this art: 'Whoever says I am in love, if they depicted... Love, it would be a foolish man. I go around the roofs and do not see him... as if I am a piebald cat. I wished from my longing for him... to look upon him, so I be a stork. People's love is gathered at me... and their love is distributed upon them.' He said: Al-Radi wrote in his handwriting under these verses: 'None said this poetry except... one ignorant of poetry, a fool. Or an afflicted one with madness... lost of thought, piebald.' From his poetry: 'I wondered at this love, not... is the beloved matched in it. I see you, O unjust one, not wanting me... This, by Allah, is inverted love. You in your beauty are Yusuf... and I in my harm am Jacob. I do not mean Ya'qub al-Saffar... You are Al-Saffar crucified.' He has: 'I loved a human in Kaskar... his face is like the bright moon. When I complained to him of his love... he lowered his head and thought. He is pure gold in his beauty... and he is the red ruby. Whoever guides me to him, has from me... all he wished and estimated. When I thought him obtained in my hand... no doubt he left me and tucked up [ran].' He said: He entered Al-Jawsaq one day and saw a bird, so he hunted it. Al-Muwaffaq said: 'I have not seen anything more beautiful than it, so give it to me, O Commander of the Faithful.' So he gave it to him. When he got it in his hand, it escaped and began clapping its wings and flying. Al-Mu'tamid laughed intensely and said: 'I entered Al-Jawsaq one day... and hunted a piebald bird. Al-Muwaffaq took it from me... and when he took it, it clapped. And flew from him in fear.' He said: When Abu Ahmad left for Basra with the army, and Al-Mu'tamid remained in Surra Man Ra'a, he said: 'Important, important, important, important... and a terrible matter and a cut matter. Is it good that you all go... I sit in the house as if I am a woman? And Emir Abu Ahmad goes... and strikes the drum Kardam Kadam.' He said: A pimple appeared on the foot of Badr his servant. He was informed of that, so he grieved. When it was after dark, he went out to his room visiting him, and said: 'I visited him after dark... for an illness occurring on the foot. I went walking in the darkness... alone, so no creature knew.' And he has: 'Ramadan has come to you with a piercing nose-ring... so sit behind your doors and break [bread]. For our intention is in the garden of Sarhak in it... he eats the meat cold when he slices. And Al-Rathitha and the soldiers with him pounded... and Al-Tal'la' and the red eggshell.' 

**Dayr al-Adhara (Monastery of the Virgins)**
This monastery is below Al-Hazira, on the bank of the Tigris. It is a beautiful, populated monastery, surrounded by gardens and vineyards, containing everything needed. It is never devoid of a picnicker seeking it for drinking and playing. It is one of the beautiful monasteries, and its spot is one of the pleasant spots. It was named Dayr al-Adhara only because in it are virgin nuns devoted to worship; they are its inhabitants and residents, so the monastery was named after them. Yamut bin al-Mazra' mentioned, from Al-Jahiz, saying: Ibn Faraj al-Tha'labi told me that a group from Banu Tha'labah wanted to cut the road for the Sultan's money. Al-Ma'aniyah came to them and informed them that the Sultan had been warned about them. They marched, then decided to hide. The hooves of horses fell in pursuit of them. When they were safe and the horses passed them, each of them secluded with a slave girl he had who was a virgin. When the priest had finished with them, one of them said regarding that: 'And more sodomitic than a monk claiming... that women are forbidden to him. He forbids a white, slender woman... and a boy suffices him regarding the vulva instead of her. When he walks, he lowers his gaze... but in the monastery at night he has ferocity. Dayr al-Adhara is a scandal for them... and with the thieves is a complete story.' In Baghdad also is a monastery known as Dayr al-Adhara in the Fief of the Christians on the Dajjaj Canal. It was named that because they have a fast of three [days] before the Great Fast (Lent), called the Fast of the Virgins. When the fast ends, they gather at this monastery to worship and draw near. It is a beautiful, pleasant monastery. Ibn al-Mu'tazz has [poetry] in the aforementioned Dayr al-Adhara: 'My friend, rise so we die of drunkenness... in a vintner's tavern, a death without a grave. And drink of a golden Karkhi wine... and pardon the sin of accidents and time. O how many days passed praiseworthy... in Dayr al-Adhara, the cells, and the palace. And how many nights aiding the lover... I dared upon pleasures in them with boldness. My friend, do not seek my success and leave me... for I have no patience against what you blame me for.' Some of them have in it: 'My excuse stood regarding the gazelle of the Monastery of the Christians... when I saw his lovers bewildered. A trial that encompassed creation and over... came their Muslims and Christians.' He said: When Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir went out from Baghdad to Surra Man Ra'a—Al-Mu'tazz having summoned him—he stayed at this monastery. He remained there for two days, found it pleasant, drank in it, then said these verses: 'Do you not see the goodness of our time, O Sa'id... a laughing time and arranged garden. And gardens like robes... every day they have a new dye. As if the anemone in it is a lover... and the chamomile is a love-struck admirer. As if the leaning branches are figures... and the blossoms in them are necklaces. As if the fruits and green leaves... are clothes beneath which are breasts. So give it to me, a wine that relieves from worry... and shows our joy and repeats it. And urge the cup, O Sa'id, for a flute... has urged you to it, and an oud has pulled you. And deflower the virginity of pleasures in Dayr... al-Adhara, perhaps it will not return.' Ubaydullah was among the best of people in literature, poetry, and versatility in all sciences, along with generosity of soul and good character. When Ubaydullah arrived in his mentioned journey to Al-Mu'tazz, he ordered him to stay with him that day, so he stayed. Ubaydullah said: Al-Mu'tazz sent to Shariya to come out. She feigned illness to him. He said: 'I have someone who loves to hear you, and I love that for you and him, and your presence is necessary.' So she came out and sat behind the curtain, then said: 'Were it not for the visitor, we would not have come.' The first song she sang was: 'The dwellings were covered by soft ones... like the curve of the tattoo on the wrist.' Then she sang after it:

Prince Abu Ahmad continues… and he beats the drum with a soft dull sound. It is said that a blister appeared on the foot of Badr, his servant, and when he was informed of this, he became distressed. When the night prayer had passed, he went to his chamber to visit him and said: “I visited him after the night prayer… for a new ailment on his foot. I went walking in the darkness… alone, with no one knowing.” He also said: “Ramadan has come upon you with firmly tied belts… so sit behind your doors. Your jars crackle in the garden of Surhak, wherein… one eats meat cold as it is cut apart, and eats rathitha, jund, daquqa… tallala‘, and the shells of red eggs.”

**The Monastery of the Virgins**: This monastery is below the enclosure, on the bank of the Tigris. It is a fine, thriving monastery surrounded by gardens and vineyards, containing everything one may need. It never lacks a place of recreation sought for drinking and amusement. It is among the beautiful monasteries, and its location is among the pleasant spots. It was named “The Monastery of the Virgins” because it housed devoted young virgins who were its residents; thus it was named after them.

Yamūt ibn al-Muzarri‘, quoting al-Jāḥiẓ, said: Ibn Faraj al-Tha‘labī told me that a group of Banu Tha‘lab intended to attack the royal caravan to seize its wealth. Some informants came to them and warned that the ruler had become aware of their plan. They fled and decided to hide, but the sound of horses’ hooves pursuing them reached them. When they felt safe and the riders had passed, each man was alone with a maiden who was with him, a virgin. When the priest finished with them, one of them recited:

“More debauched than a monk who claims… that women are forbidden to him, yet he forbids a fair, slender girl… and finds sufficiency with a boy in place of intercourse. When he walks, he lowers his gaze… and at night in the monastery his desire rages. The Monastery of the Virgins exposes them… and among thieves this is a complete tale.”

There is also in Baghdad another monastery known as the Monastery of the Virgins, in the Christian district on the River of Chickens. It was named so because they have a fast three days before the Great Fast, called ‘The Fast of the Virgins’. When it ends, they gather at this monastery for worship and devotion. It is a fine and pleasant monastery.

Ibn al-Mu‘tazz said regarding the Monastery of the Virgins mentioned earlier:

“My two friends, rise so that we may die of intoxication… in the tavern of a wine seller, a death without a grave. Let us drink from a golden karkhī cup… and overlook the sins of events and time. Oh how many splendid days have passed… in the Monastery of the Virgins, the cloisters, and the palace. And how many joyful nights for the passionate one… where I dared indulge in pleasures upon the bridge. My two friends, do not seek my reformation—leave me… for I have no patience against the blame you cast on me.”

Someone else said about it:

“My excuse stands firm in the gazelle of the Christian monastery… when I saw the bewildered lovers around him. A temptation that encompassed all creatures… overwhelming both Muslims and Christians.”

It is said: When ‘Ubayd Allah ibn ‘Abd Allah ibn Tahir departed Baghdad for Samarra, having been summoned by al-Mu‘tazz, he stopped at this monastery, stayed there two days, enjoyed it, and drank there. He then recited these verses:

“What do you think of the pleasantness of our time, O Sa‘īd?… A laughing season, and gardens in bloom. Gardens like embroidered garments… each day with new colors. The anemone in them like a passionate lover… and the yellow flowers like a devoted youth. The branches seem like bending forms… and the blossoms like necklaces. The fruits and green leaves… garments beneath which breasts rise. Give me wine that removes sorrow… reveals our joy, and restores it. Urge on the cup, O Sa‘īd, for a flute urges you, and your lute assists. And tear away the virginity of pleasures in the Monastery of the Virgins… for perhaps they will not return.”

‘Ubayd Allah was among the best of people in manners, poetry, and mastery of all knowledge, with generosity and good character. When he arrived at al-Mu‘tazz during that journey, he ordered him to stay with him that day, and he stayed.

‘Ubayd Allah said: Al-Mu‘tazz sent for Shāriyah to come, but she excused herself. He said: “I have someone who wishes to hear you, and I wish it for both you and him. You must come.” So she came and sat behind the curtain, then said: “Had it not been for the visitor, we would not have come.” The first song she performed was:

“I covered the dwellings with gentleness… like the winding of a tattoo on the wrist.”

Then she sang another after it:

'The voice of a dove frightened me for separation... on a willow branch, doves answered it.' Al-Mu'tazz said to me: 'How do you hear?' I said: 'I hear something whose share of wonder is greater than the share of delight.' He approved this speech from me. Then he let me hear the playing of Zanam the Piper, who had become weak, tremulous, and chronically ill with gout. He showed me the instrument made by Ahmad bin Musa the Engineer from copper; water is sent into it, and the playing of the surnay (oboe) is heard from it. Then he took me to a window and ordered the lion and the elephant to be brought together. I saw how they leaped at each other. Then he said to me: 'I remember that I showed you curious things today.' I said: 'Yes, O my master.' He said: 'Which of them is wittiest to you?' I said: 'The singing of Shariya.' He said to me: 'You spoke the truth!' Jahza said: I entered upon Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir one day. Sheikhs came to him, and he ordered them to sit on his right. Middle-aged men came, and he ordered them to sit on his left. Youths entered and stood before him, and he did not order them to sit. I asked him about them. He said: 'These are my sons'—and he pointed to the sheikhs—'and these are their sons'—and he pointed to the middle-aged men—'and these are their sons'—and he pointed to the youths. I said: 'Are your sons from one mother or from various mothers?' He said: 'The mother of all of them is Shaji.' He recited: 'I and Shaji sowed between us in my youth... the plant of love, and it bore sweet fruit. Shaji's sons turned gray while I was alive and matured... and their sons turned gray, and she is the owner of my heart.' He said: 'She has been with me for seventy years. An astrologer had judged my death before her, but she died before me.' So he said: 'O wonder at me and at the one whom I tended... with the strongest causes of love and who tended me. I was hoping to be his ransom... but when the time of death came, he ransomed me.' Ibn Qudama mentioned, saying: I attended Shaji's funeral. When we returned, I entered with Ubaydullah helping and comforting him. He was looking down, tears flowing on his cheeks; I never saw a weeper more beautiful than him. Then he raised his head and turned to us, saying: 'An oath that if I were afflicted by her loss... while I had a pulse of a vein for life and relapse. I would have almost killed myself upon her separation... but she died and my soul has gone.' He said: Then I attended with him to visit her grave. When he intended to leave, he said: 'Whoever visits the abode of loved ones for their life... and is capable of meeting what he hopes for. Let him come to the abode of loved ones who inhabited decay... out of honor and preservation, and the meeting is the Gathering.' He said: A son of Ubaydullah from Shaji died. He visited his grave, then recited: 'O gathering place of loved ones after separation... I see you near, but the meeting is far. O wonder that I visit you compelled... and in you are those I love, and I leave you willingly.' Al-Suli said: When Shaji died, Ubaydullah grieved for her a grief the likes of which was not seen. A group of literati elegized her, and Ubaydullah elegized her with several poems. The best of what passed me in that was a letter from Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz to him and its answer from Ubaydullah bin Abdullah. The text of the consolation was: 'The news of the calamity reached me, may Allah honor you. By Allah, the worry of it has partnered me with you, and what pained you has pained me. So patience, O my brother, upon the decree of fate, rising from the stumble of panic, firmness for the trial, and thanks to the Granter of blessing by sending the harem ahead and obtaining the reward for good patience. Even if she was: Of majestic luck in chastity and piety... and a turtledove cooing at the peak of the branch. She turned away, and even if the earth did not feed other than her... it would have sufficed her, but I do not see the earth satiated. Allah prolonged your enjoyment of her since He gave her to you, and made her loss for your reward which is greater than her since He reclaimed her from you. The likes of you, may Allah support you, is not urged to preserve his religion, because you know it, desire it, and hasten to it. But calamities may storm the anxious one until he remembers or is reminded, so he returns to satisfaction with the judgment of the One who does not wrong, and preempts patience over the calamity by choice, for the solace which he must inevitably come to by necessity. How often a choice is bitter, and praiseworthy in what is disliked. This is Time which we know, and you are not approached from inadvertence regarding it. This is its nature, and thus its custom proceeded, until Allah inherits the earth and whoever is on it, and He is the best of inheritors. Were it not for an illness hindering meeting you, may Allah honor you, I would have come to you instead of every letter and messenger, and fulfilled your right by that and seen it as your due. How often a present one whose affection is not present, and an absent one whose concern is not absent from us. May Allah make your reward great, your recompense abundant, guide your heart to the path of consolation, suffice you your dislikes, grant you success to what agrees with you, have mercy on the one who died, and make what she connected to of the Hereafter better than what she was cut off from of the world. Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we return.'

Ubaydullah bin Abdullah answered him: 'May Allah prolong the survival of the Master hoped for the world and religion, son of the beneficence masters, the Rightly Guided Caliphs, and the noble ancestors. May Allah increase the Master in honor and preference, perpetuate for him glory, happiness, dignity, bliss, and safety, renew for him apparent blessings and successive favors, make me his ransom from every evil and harm, and advance me to every feared and cautioned thing before him. The letter of the Master, may Allah prolong his survival, arrived filled with kindness, virtue, favor, bounty, unique literature, and comprehensive beauties. I received it with its due of reverence, thanks, and knowledge of his high worth, elevated degree, and ascended rank in good composition, agreement of meanings, great correctness, and beautiful address. Allah has raised literature and knowledge and the eyes of their people by the Master, may Allah support him with His care and power. As for sharing, it is known from his kindness, such that even if I said that consolation for this calamity that befell me, had he verbally confronted me with it and consoled for it, the matter would have run its course and placed the intent in its most rightful places. As for patience, it is inevitable, either by necessity or by choice. "If a calamity strikes a living person... he meets it with endurance and patience. It is not far from turning into a blessing... for which praise and thanks to Allah are due." As for panic, what struck, pained, hurt, and frightened, there is no escape from it. If it does not exceed the eye and heart to the body and tongue, its gravity is easier. Thanks to the Master who lightens trials and completes blessings, the refuge in misfortunes and protection in calamities. Even if long enjoyment, may Allah honor the Master, consoles—it consoles from it only for one whom it aided and whose knot it weakened, not for what a distinguishing observer relied upon, even if upon the severest pain, bitterest grief, eternal anguish, and lasting sorrow. I say: "The most joyful matters of time became its saddest... and every new thing became worn after you. So wonder at honey turning into colocynth... and at a laugher who did not return but remained weeping." As for solace, may Allah honor the Master, it is not the act of sincere freemen, neither in life nor in death. It is only seizing the opportunity of reckoning [reward] and continuous earning. I seek refuge in Allah from the loss of consolation and the loss of its reward. By Allah, O my master, the person is humbled, the eye is tearful, and the heart is burning, in pain. This condition encountered a body in which there is no sound limb, prolonged illnesses, and a calamity connected to what remains of time. "While the youth weeps and mourns his grief... and his familiar one, lo, he becomes wept for and mourned." As for what the Master mentioned, may Allah make me his ransom, regarding the matter of the illness—may it not be, nor may mention of it be heard ever—were it not for it, there would have been and been what the tongue cannot unleash mentioning. I seek refuge for him in Allah the Great, who favored him with every noble character, from blaming the action for which the least of it does not suffice the utmost thanks. In what preceded of address and sharing is what reaches the furthest stations of honor and attempts the highest feats of pride. I negotiate with the Master, may Allah prolong his survival, thing after thing of what sadness spoke, and I broadcast it to him. Among that: "I stopped at the loved ones while the dust is between them... by my soul, faces are under those graves. It was represented to me what decay attained of their beauty... so glory be to my Lord, Knower of secrets."' Then he sent him several poems he said about her. He said: When Ubaydullah's condition declined, Al-Mu'tadid sent to him asking him to make room for Shaji to visit him. That was difficult for him, and he argued that she was ill and of disordered appearance. He persisted in asking for her until a threat appeared from him. So he sent her to him. It was mentioned about her that she said: 'I despised myself when I entered upon his slave girls, because of what I saw on them of jewelry and robes. They also despised me until I sang and they sang, so my reverence for them transferred to me from them.' When she left, Al-Mu'tadid loaded with her ten thousand dirhams, clothing, and perfume. Shaji and Ubaydullah's family came. When he saw her, he was relieved. Then he said to her: 'Did you see anything you haven't seen the like of with us and admired?' She said: 'No, by Allah, except an oud of wood (aloeswood/singular piece?), which is carved, not built; I found it novel.' Jahza said: What do you say about one who enters the Caliphate house and does not extend his eye to anything admiring it except an oud? He said: Among what she composed and sang that day for Al-Mu'tadid was: 'What did beauty borrow from his face... and the soft branch from his stature. We reproached each other with our eyes... regarding what the breach of his promise committed. Until we wounded each other by our repeating... of the glance in my heart and in his cheek. So he took revenge and I took revenge... and his turning away from his rejection pleased me.' Among what she sang also:

'It is Time, it gives you only distraction... and takes the gifted only by force. Solace when the demand of a perished one is missed... and patience if practicing patience is more prudent.' Abu Ali Muhammad bin al-Ala al-Shajari said: When Ubaydullah bin Sulayman assumed the vizierate for Al-Mu'tadid, Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir gave me a note, asking me to show it to Ubaydullah bin Sulayman. In it was: 'Our time refused to aid us regarding ourselves... but aided us regarding whom we revere and honor. So I said to it: Your favors upon them, complete them... and leave our matter, for the important is prioritized.' Ubaydullah bin Sulayman admired what he wrote and said: 'Do you not see how he was gentle in complaining of his condition?' Then he took all his notes and signed for him in them with everything he wanted. He said: Abu al-Ayna' said one day to Ubaydullah: 'Shall I be silent, O Emir, or speak?' He said: 'If you are silent, you suffice; and if you speak, I listen to you. Indeed, you settle with us when we need you, and distance from us when you need us.' From his poetry is his saying: 'By my life, if I told myself that... I would miss you, my opinion would be far astray. Because you are to me in the place encompassing me... of the earth wherever doctrines roused me.' Abu Ali al-Awaraji mentioned that Abu Bakr Muhammad bin al-Sari al-Sarraj the Grammarian loved a slave girl from the singers, and spent a large amount of money on her. When Al-Muktafi arrived from Raqqa, people went out to look at him. I, he, and Abu al-Qasim Abdullah al-Mawsili went out and sat on the balcony of Ibn Jahshiyar's house to see him. When he arrived and we looked at him, we all admired him. Abu Bakr bin al-Sarraj was angry with this slave girl and quarreling with her. He said: 'Something has come to me, so write.' So I wrote: 'I compared between her beauty and her deeds... and behold, beauty does not fulfill [balance] treachery. By Allah, I will not speak to her even if she were... like the sun or like the moon or like Al-Muktafi.' Then a long time passed for the story. Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Ismail Zanjy the Writer loved a singing girl. He was then writing for Abu al-Abbas Ibn al-Furat, and used to tell him his story with her without being shy. His meeting with her was every Friday, because it was the day of his turn in his house. Abu Ali said: Zanjy told me, saying: I went early on Saturday to Abu al-Abbas Ibn al-Furat. He said to me: 'What was your news yesterday?' I told him of our meeting. He said to me: 'So what was your song [you heard]?' I said: 'I compared between her beauty and her deeds...' Abu al-Abbas said to me: 'Whose poetry is this?' I said: 'Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz.' Then Abu al-Abbas Ibn al-Furat rode to the Vizier Al-Qasim bin Ubaydullah, told him this story, recited the poetry to him, and went with him to Al-Thurayya, then left him and sat in his office. When he knew his departure was near, he went out and met him. When he met him, he told him that he recited the poetry to Al-Muktafi and that he asked him about its sayer, so he informed him it was Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir. He said: 'So he ordered me to carry one thousand dinars to him. I said: I only told you that the poetry is Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz's, so you attributed it to Ibn Tahir. He said: By Allah, it only occurred to me that you said it was Ubaydullah's. This is a provision Allah provided to Ubaydullah, no one has a trick in it.' Zanjy said: When Abu al-Abbas left, he told me this story and said: 'You take the dinars and go with them to Ubaydullah and say to him: This is a provision Allah sent to you from where you did not reckon!' I carried the dinars to him and told him the story. He praised Allah and thanked Abu al-Abbas. This was of amazing coincidence! Ubaydullah used to say: 'Whoever accompanies the Sultan and serves him needs to enter blind and leave mute.' From his poetry is his saying: 'If you do not favor the one of affection... and you and he are in an equal position. Then do not be haughty over him, for... a youth is punished for the sin, not for the satisfaction.' He also said: 'Indeed my heart, from you after what passed... is full of two different matters. A love from you followed by harm to you, and harm... is the enemy of love; they will never be found in a place.' He also said: 'Suffice you of the lowly world as informant... the richness of its misers and the poverty of its nobles. And that the men of benefit are under its soles... and the men of harm are upon its humps.' He also said: 'And they said: Tomorrow he departs, so what are you doing? ... It is nothing but the eyes overflowing. Nay, sighs between which is breathing... cutting my heart, and worries are pullers.

'And humiliation, looking down, thought, and heartbreak... and greater than them is what the ribs conceal.' Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz said: I wrote to Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir when his son was appointed to the deputy of Yunus over the police of Baghdad: 'I rejoiced at what multiples of it are below your worth... and I said perhaps Time has woken from its sleep. So a Tahirid dynasty returns among us... as it began, and the command after it is the command. Perhaps Allah, for Allah is not heedless... and there must be ease when hardship ends.' Ubaydullah bin Abdullah answered him: 'So we are for you if the injustice of harshness touches us... and from us upon its hardships is patience and excuse. If a dynasty returns from Allah's blessing... to us, then from us at that is praise and thanks.' Ubaydullah has much poetry and interesting news; we selected from it what befits the purpose of the book and does not exit to the limit of lengthiness. The death of Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir was on Saturday night, twelve nights passed of Shawwal, year three hundred. When he died, Shaghab, the mother of Al-Muqtadir Billah, sent Umm Musa the Stewardess to his children and harem, consoled them for him, shrouded him with a Hahiri shroud, gave charity in his funeral of one thousand dinars and one thousand dirhams, and undertook all their affairs. As for his brother Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir, he was generous, noble, bounteous, tolerant, of good character, with literature, good knowledge, mastery in all sciences, control, politics, and advancement in management. Al-Mutawakkil had summoned him from Khurasan when Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Tahiri and his son Muhammad died, and appointed him his deputy in Baghdad. He confirmed his brother Tahir bin Abdullah over Khurasan, and he was the eldest of his brothers. Al-Shah bin Mikal mentioned that a cloth merchant offered Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir two robes of embroidery. He recognized them and knew they were from his clothes. He summoned Ibrahim bin Harun the Christian, his steward, and ordered him to bring the two robes whose description was such and such. He mentioned he did not know them, and that he returned to the inventory and did not find them in it, and returned to the register and found them established in it, bought for one thousand five hundred dinars. He said: I asked about the news, and was informed that the scribe in the treasury sold them and dropped their number from the inventory. He ordered the imprisonment of the scribe. He said to Ibrahim: 'Woe to you! Do you employ as a scribe one who dares such daring?' He swore he did not know such a condition from him nor knew such a slip for him. He said: 'If the matter is so, let him be released.' He ordered five hundred dinars for him and said to him: 'Be chaste with this, for I think poverty drove you to that. Return the two robes to the merchant and release him.' He said: We were one day at Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Mus'ab's. The table was presented. He had ordered Harisa to be made. The Harisa was presented to him. He looked at it and saw a hair. He signaled to some of his servants something we did not understand. It was not long before he came with a tray with a cover. He placed it and lifted the cover. Behold, the hand of the cook with its blood in the tray. We lifted our hands, and our eating was spoiled by what came upon us. We stood up, and none of us could benefit himself. Then we gathered ages later at the table of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir. He had ordered the preparation of a dish he desired. It was made for him, and the cook brought it himself, eager to get close to his heart. When he neared him, he stumbled in his haste, and the tray slipped onto Muhammad. His clothes and the carpet under him became a mess. He stood up immediately, changed his clothes, washed, and returned to us with a cheerful face, unaffected by what happened. He sat at the table, then said: 'Bring me So-and-so the cook.' He was brought, doubting not the descent of vengeance. He said to him: 'I think we scared you. You are free for the sake of Allah, Glorious and Exalted. And So-and-so the slave girl is yours, and I have married you two.' He ordered a gift and clothing for him. We began praying for him, marveled at his action, and mentioned the action of Ishaq. He said: Ibn Abi Fanann, nicknamed Abu Abdul Rahman, was a naturally gifted poet. He had an estate in the fief of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir. The collector used to come to him and harm him, and perhaps summon him. He wrote to Muhammad complaining of the collector and what he encountered from him of harassment: 'O son of Husayn, indeed I... became in the shelter of the Emir. We have livelihoods in his fief... upon the fresh water. I built a house in its middle... I named it the House of Joy. When I sat facing it... and drank of the milk of the juice. I said: Effacement, when I quenched... to Al-Khawarnaq and Al-Sadir. Were it not for the frequenting of a collector... like a dog on a rainy day. Coming early upon me and going... connecting evening to morning.

'When his face appears to me... I am driven out empty of my joy. So is the Emir, by his generosity... from the ugliness of his face, my protector?' When Muhammad read the verses, he signed under them: 'He has protected you, O Abu Abdul Rahman. We ordered the bearing of your land tax'—and its amount was eight thousand dirhams. He sent him one thousand dinars and swore on him to accept it. Ibn Abi Fanann used to not accept anything from anyone, being well-off and independent. Muhammad bin Abdullah has noble deeds whose explanation would be long to mention; in what we mentioned is sufficiency. From his beautiful poetry is his saying: 'She said with her glance: Approach. So I said to them [eyes]... with tears: At your service, O my hearing and my sight. Until when she knew that I was fond of her... she signaled to me with a tear not hidden. O concealer of his love for fear of the slanderer... Indeed I, by your life, read it from the look. Say with your glance what you desire, I will know it... and make my glance speak, it will inform you of the news.' The birth of Muhammad bin Abdullah was in the year two hundred and nine, on the night in whose morning Kaysum was conquered. In it Ubaydullah bin Yahya bin Khaqan, Ahmad bin Isra'il, and Al-Hasan bin Makhlad were born; all of them held the vizierate. Muhammad died on Saturday, thirteen nights passed of Dhu al-Qa'dah, year two hundred fifty-three. His age was forty-four years. His death was from a pimple that appeared in his throat. He died while the moon was in eclipse. He used to say: 'When the eclipse is complete and begins to clear, I will die.' It was so. He appointed his brother Ubaydullah as his successor, so Al-Mu'tazz confirmed him and sent him robes with Muflih, the deputy of Bakyak. Tahir bin Muhammad disputed the command with him, and his clients and the common people aided him until the messengers and robes came, so the command settled for Ubaydullah. Ibn al-Rumi elegized Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir: 'The Emir spent the night [dead], and the full moon of our sky spent the night [eclipsed]... this one bidding us farewell, and this one eclipsing. A moon saw a moon giving up his soul... so a brother, consoling and fair, wept for his brother. Days assassinated him, knowing... that what cannot be replaced will perish from him.' He said about him: 'And I asked about him, it was said: He died of what was in him... I said: Generosity, no doubt, died of what was in him. And as if we....... ... .......... with him. So for whom do I preserve my tears after him... and for whom do you see them pouring from their causes? For his correctness, his speech, his answer... for his youth, for the best of his manners.' Ubaydullah his brother has about him: 'The full moon and the Emir eclipsed together... so the full moon cleared while the Emir is lovesick [dead]. The full moon's light returned to its manifestation... but the Emir's light is what does not return.' He said: 'I remembered my brother without forgetting his memory... but it is a state that increases and decreases. According to the morals of time, and indeed... a life disturbed upon it will accompany me.' When Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir died, Al-Mu'tazz's grief for him intensified. He used to see that the Turks feared him because of him and for his place. He said about him: 'The joy of the Caliphate has gone from us... when Muhammad became in the graves. Shortly there will be events of time... from the light of whose fire the blaze will ignite.'

He said: As for Sulayman bin Abdullah bin Tahir, he was the son of his brother Muhammad bin Tahir. He sent him to Iraq in the year two hundred fifty-five as his deputy. Al-Mu'tazz ratified that and authorized him, so he established him for days. Ubaydullah went out to him, bestowed a robe on him, appointed him over the police of Baghdad, and removed Sulayman bin Abdullah. Ubaydullah entered Baghdad with a great crowd of loyalists and commanders. People received him and rejoiced at his governorship. Sulayman left before his brother's arrival to Al-Baradan, and stayed there until Musa bin Bugha arrived from the mountain (Al-Jabal). He returned the command of the police in Baghdad and Samarra and the command of Al-Sawad to him, and removed Sulayman. That was in the year two hundred fifty-seven. So Ubaydullah received the governorship in the first [instance]. Then the affair of the Tahirids in Khurasan became disordered, and Ya'qub bin al-Layth entered Nishapur. When he approached it, that being in the year eight [258], Muhammad bin Tahir sent to him asking permission to meet him, but he did not permit him. So he sent his uncles and family, and they met him. He entered Nishapur and stayed at one of its edges. Muhammad bin Tahir rode to him and met him in his tent. He began rebuking him for his negligence in his work. Then he put him and his family under guard and wrote to the Capital mentioning that he is hearing and obeying and controlling what he governs, and attacking Muhammad. Al-Muwaffaq rejected him with the ugliest rejection, and informed him that he does not approve of that. Then Ya'qub bin al-Layth advanced to Baghdad. Al-Mu'tamid marched towards him, and they met. Al-Muwaffaq was in the vanguard, Musa bin Bugha in the right wing, and Masrur al-Balkhi in the left wing. That was on Sunday, seven days passed of Rajab, and it was Palm Sunday. A great number of loyalists were killed. The war intensified, and Al-Muwaffaq uncovered his head and said: 'I am the Hashimi Boy.' Then the turn went against Ya'qub, so he was defeated in the ugliest defeat. Al-Muwaffaq and Musa bin Bugha pursued them, killing a great slaughter of them. The water was released upon them, so more drowned than were killed. Muhammad bin Tahir was with him, heavily burdened with iron. He was released from his iron, given a robe, and lodged in the house of his uncle Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir. His work in Khurasan was returned to him, and five hundred thousand dirhams were released for him. Al-Mu'tamid returned to Baghdad, and Al-Muwaffaq marched to Wasit. He contracted Ubaydullah over the two Harams. News arrived of the death of Ya'qub bin al-Layth and the rise of his brother Amr. Allegiance was taken for Amr, and he was invested with Khurasan, Fars, Kerman, Sijistan, Isfahan, and Sind. Amr wrote to Ubaydullah bin Abdullah appointing him to the police as his deputy, and sent him robes and a gold mace. Al-Muwaffaq ratified that and bestowed a robe on Ubaydullah as well. Sulayman bin Abdullah bin Tahir died in the year two hundred sixty-six in Muharram. His brother Ubaydullah stood at his grave leaning on his sword and said: 'My soul ascends in its ascents... and the tear of the eye flows in its courses. For a spot my eye has not seen the like of its scarceness [of space]... nor the like of the multitude of loved ones who settled in it.' Then Sa'id bin Makhlad appointed Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Tahir bin Abdullah bin Tahir as deputy over the City of Peace in the year two hundred seventy, so he arrested his uncle Ubaydullah and imprisoned him. Then Al-Mu'tadid appointed his slave Badr as deputy over the City of Peace, and the affair of the Tahirids ended in it and in Khurasan. Sulayman had pleasant poetry, literature, understanding, and knowledge. As for Abdul Aziz bin Abdullah bin Tahir, he was younger than his two brothers. He had literature, understanding, and pleasant poetry. From his poetry to his brother Ubaydullah—and his brothers Abdullah and Sulayman had imprisoned him: 'I used to think that I, if... one of the calamities befell me, would seek refuge in a mountain [you]. Until when the matter occurred in which... my help was obligatory without failure. You surrendered me to the lines of time playing with me... this was not my estimation nor my hope. If I were in a land of distant place, I would not have... minded the stumble of my days while the likes of you is for me. I am your brother whom you used to be familiar with... I did not change from your covenant one day nor did I cease. I am your brother, and Allah is looking... at the secrets, so cut after or separate.' From his poetry also to his brother when he was imprisoned—he was accused of writing to the Sijistani—so he wrote from prison swearing on the falsehood of that, and wrote at the end of the note these verses: 'Sulayma says, terrified by my imprisonment... as a painful bereavement terrifies a mother of one. Time refused except that its vicissitude befalls you... like its denied habit with every noble. I said to her: Lower your [eyes], for indeed... the striking calamities strike men. And do not wonder at the imprisonment, woe to you, but wonder... at the denial of what I narrated in the scenes.

'I was imprisoned for a war whose struggle I did not witness... and my jailer became my brother and son of my father.' From his beautiful poetry: 'O shining, blooming moon... bright of beauty, splendid, dazzling. Convey peace to your likeness and congratulate her... on sleep, and inform her that I am awake.' Al-Mu'tadid admired this poetry, so he sang it in the light Ramal mode, and it was one of his songs. Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun mentioned that Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Tahir used to serve as chamberlain to Al-Mutawakkil in Surra Man Ra'a for two months, then descend to Baghdad to stay there for two months, and his deputies would succeed him in Surra Man Ra'a. He came once taking his brother Abdul Aziz with him. He had bought a slave girl who had a place in his heart. Separation from her was hard on him. He said: So he asked me to seek permission from his brother for him to return to Baghdad, on condition that he give me a monthly [horse] I had seen under him. I did so, and he permitted him, so he gave me the monthly. Then he recited this poetry to me: 'I say when memory stirred my heart... and Sirius intercepted in the middle of the sky. As if it is a ruby on a horn... How long is the night in Surra Man Ra'a. O Lord, a release like the release of captives... For if You find for me another escape. Make my nearest steps Basra... until I return with mounts weary. As if they are drunk from fatigue... then I live like the life of Khosrow.' None of the children of Abdullah bin Tahir entered Baghdad except these four: Muhammad, Ubaydullah, Sulayman, and Abdul Aziz. As for Abdullah bin Tahir, he was among the masters of people in literature, virtue, politics, management, generosity, and nobility. Al-Ma'mun adopted him and raised him. His birth was in the year one hundred eighty-two. Abu Ahmad Ubaydullah bin Abdullah mentioned that Abu al-Abbas Abdullah bin Tahir left Al-Ma'mun's house one night, after Tahir's departure to Khurasan. Wine had overcome him, so he slept in the Tahirid Dome in Tahir's house in the City of Peace. A corner of the burlap, having dried, caught fire from the candle, so the Dome burned. Abdullah was carried and taken out of it. The news reached Tahir, so he wrote to Abdullah blaming and rebuking him, saying: 'If the news of your death had arrived, it would have been easier on me than its arrival with your scandal, and that wine reaches with you a level where you do not sense the burning of a place you are in.' He ordered him to prepare and come out to him. That worried Abdullah, and he hid it from all people, sealed the letter, and put it under his prayer rug. Worry appeared on him. Al-Ma'mun asked him about his news, but he hid it. Then he asked his intimates, who informed him that a letter had arrived to him whose contents were unknown. Al-Ma'mun swore on him to bring the letter, so he brought it. Al-Ma'mun wrote to Tahir reproaching him for what he did, informing him of his [Abdullah's] status with him and his placing him in the place of a son, and that Tahir has no authority over him except by right of his deputyship; if he removed him from it, he has no right to disturb him from the Presence. Tahir answered with thanks for his favor since this was his place with him. The Dome was rebuilt, and it remained until it was demolished in the year two hundred ninety-three. Abdullah went out to Sham in the year two hundred nine, fought Nasr bin Shabath until he overcame him.

Ubaydullah bin Abdullah said: Nusayr, Yasir, and a group of the sheikhs of our clients told me that Abu al-Abbas Abdullah bin Tahir, when he overlooked Kaysum, Nasr bin Shabath fortified himself in it. He rode the next day, having mobilized his army for the encounter. He met Nasr who had come out of the fortress. He lined up opposite him and stood facing him until night without war. Then Nasr lit fires. Abdullah consulted his commanders. They said: 'This is night, let us return and spend the night in our camp, then go early to him for war.' He said: 'The return of the warrior is retreat, and I will not leave my position.' He dismounted. He had a quartan fever, and it was its turn that night. He suffered a severe fever attack. He sought something to warm him but there was nothing with them. They said: 'Dig a hole with your swords.' He ordered straw to be gathered from the nosebags of the beasts and thrown into the hole. That was done, then he sat in it. The sky brought down rain and severe hail. He said: 'Cover me with your shields.' We remained like that all our night covering him until morning. We prayed and he prayed, put on his weapons again, rode his horse, and went to the edge, and we were with him. He looked, and behold, there was no one outside the fortress. He said: 'The wretch deceived us and made us imagine he was opposite us, entered his fortress, and appointed someone to light fires. Now he will come out against you with his intensity. So take your caution.' He called Al-Aziz and said: 'Go with two thousand knights, rest and relax'—and he named a place for them to be—'and let none of you leave until Tahir bin Ibrahim bin Mudrik comes to him with my message. If he comes to you, if you and your companions can be on the wings of birds until you join me, do so.' He left. He did not finish speaking before Nasr came out and charged at them. Abdullah emerged to him leading his companions. Attacks and fighting continued between them, Abdullah ransoming his companions, promising them, and throwing himself into every target, until the sun was in the middle of the sky. Everyone with him showed weakness and inability. Tahir sent to Al-Aziz ordering him to hasten, so he arrived. When Nasr and those with him saw the black banners and the black lions—and Abdullah was the one who adopted them—they panicked and failure appeared in them. Abdullah said to Al-Aziz: 'You and your companions towards the people!' It was but an hour until Nasr was defeated and took refuge in his fortress. Abu al-Abbas called for the sappers and ordered the setting up of ballistas, mangonels, and ladders. They looked and saw no one in the fortress. Behold, Nasr had dug a tunnel from behind the fortress and exited from it. He ordered the men, so they opened the door. He entered and he and his companions looted everything in the fortress. He was given glad tidings at that time and congratulated on the victory. 'Awf bin Muhallim al-Khuza'i recited to him: 'Thank your Lord for the Day of the Fortress for His blessing... He has granted you the glory of victory and triumph.' It is a long poem. Nasr went and took refuge in mountains that did not protect him, so he sought refuge in safety (Aman). Abdullah wrote to Al-Ma'mun informing him. He wrote back: 'Give him safety on condition that he treads the carpet of the Commander of the Faithful and his judgment be executed on him.' He agreed to that. Abdullah sent him with Muhammad bin al-Husayn bin Mus'ab to Al-Ma'mun's presence. He said: Nasr had grown old. Al-Ma'mun saw him being carried by two of his boys on the saddle. He said: 'Nasr is carried by two!' He said: 'Yes, O Commander of the Faithful, and two hundred cannot bring him down!' Then Abdullah bin Tahir marched to Egypt in the year ten and conquered it. Ibn al-Sari sought safety from him. He stayed there until the year eleven. He came to Al-Ma'mun having reformed the country, collected its wealth, and stabilized its conditions. Abu Ishaq and Al-Abbas bin al-Ma'mun received him. He arrived with those who had overcome Egypt. He said: Al-Ma'mun said one day: 'Do you know a man who exceeds all people of his time in integrity and good conduct?' A group mentioned people and praised them. He said: 'I did not mean these.' Ali bin Salih, master of the prayer place, said: 'I do not know, O Commander of the Faithful, anyone with such a description except Umar bin al-Khattab.' Al-Ma'mun said: 'O Allah, forgiveness; I did not mean Quraysh.' The group remained silent. Al-Ma'mun said: 'That is Abdullah bin Tahir. I governed him over Egypt while its wealth was abundant. He found for Ubaydullah bin al-Sari wealth that description falls short of. He did not touch a dinar or a dirham of it. He did not leave Egypt except with ten thousand dinars, three horses, and two donkeys. But he is the planting of my hand and the graduate of my discipline. I will recite to you verses in his description.' Then he recited: 'Forbearing with piety, brave with death... generous when the pouring cloud is not moist. Strong in the anchor of the heart in the position where... the hearts of the worlds have palpitations. A youth who is noble without affectation... and polite without the discipline of men.'

He stayed before Al-Ma'mun for a year, then he sent him to Babak, who had appeared and whose power had grown great. He stayed facing him for a year. He had stipulated to Al-Ma'mun that if he overcame Babak, he would return to the Gate (Court), so his residence would be in the presence of Al-Ma'mun, and he would choose for his deputyship over Khurasan whomever he liked of his brothers. He stayed at Dinawar for nine months preparing to fight Babak. While he was so, a letter from the governor of Nishapur arrived to Al-Ma'mun mentioning that the renegades (Kharijites) raided a village of it called Al-Hamra on the main road, and that they burned, captured, and killed women and children. This was grave to Al-Ma'mun. He called Ishaq bin Ibrahim—who was Abdullah bin Tahir's deputy over the police—and Yahya bin Aktham, and sent them to Abdullah. He wrote with them a letter in his handwriting to Abdullah swearing on him to move his camp from the face of Babak to the face of Khurasan, for Khurasan is more important than the entire kingdom after the Capital, and to advise him on whom to send to Babak. He complied with what he ordered him, advised Ali bin Hisham, wrote to those in Khurasan what he liked, and sent his brother Muhammad bin Tahir in his vanguard. Ali bin Hisham arrived and agreed with him on the road regarding fighting Babak. He went on his way to Khurasan, until he reached Nishapur. He wrote to Al-Ma'mun that the Commander of the Faithful urged me to this frontier because of what had overcome it of the matter of Al-Hamra, and what the renegades caused in it.
