I arrived in Nishapur and found what is around it to be the nest of the renegades, and found it the most important of districts, and the important is more apparent and more severe (Abda wa Ada). He said: Al-Ma'mun admired the letter because of this phrase, and the scribes kept mentioning it among themselves. His stay in Khurasan, until he died there, was fifteen years. Ibn Jadan mentioned from Al-Juludi, saying: Abdullah sat one day in Khurasan and gave justice to the notables of commanders and emirs of soldiers; he struck necks, cut hands and feet, and contracted contracts. When the sun declined, he entered his house. Al-Juludi said: I was closest to his heart and boldest with him. The servants received him; this one took his tunic, another his boot, and another his legging. He remained in a tunic and trousers. He lifted the tunic onto his shoulder and began saying: 'The scent is musk and the faces are dinars... and the tips of the fingers are anemone.' He said: I spoke harshly to him, pulled his garment off his shoulder, returned him to his state, and said to him: 'You sit today the sitting of Alexander and Dara bin Dara, and do now the deed of 'Allawayh and Mukhariq?' He said: He looked at me the look of the assailant, returned his garment to his shoulder, and said: 'The soul must, since it is directed... move from state to state.' When Al-Ma'mun died, Al-Mu'tasim confirmed Abdullah bin Tahir over Khurasan and Ishaq bin Ibrahim over his deputyship in Baghdad, but he had a bad opinion of him. He wrote to him: 'As for what follows: May Allah heal us both. There were in my soul resentments against you, the change of which is the remaining of revenge against you for you. There remain of them small things I fear for you from them. So do not come forward. Suffice you of what I harbor for you my revealing to you what is in my conscience. Peace.' Al-Fadl bin Marwan said: Al-Mu'tasim mentioned Abdullah bin Tahir one day and criticized him. The group followed him and described him with bad obedience while I was present. I stood up and said: 'Write to him to come; he will not reach evening before he sets out.' He said: 'Sit and write to him with the news.' He wrote a letter to Al-Mu'tasim, which he sent folded in my letter to him. He asked me to deliver it from my hand to his hand, so I did. Al-Mu'tasim read it and began asking me about letter after letter. I opened it for him: behold, he had written swearing that if the letter arrived to him to set out, he would not reach evening before setting out. Abu al-'Umaythal said: I entered upon Abdullah bin Tahir. He said: 'You are indeed looking at the roles (Ad'ur? Unclear) little what you see.' He extended his hand to me, and I kissed it. He said: 'You were more undutiful to me with it than you were dutiful.' I said: 'With what?' He said: 'With the roughness of your mustache.' I said: 'Indeed, the spines of the hedgehog do not harm the lion's paw.' He said: 'This, by Allah, is more beloved to me than the praise of a hundred rhymes.' He ordered ten thousand dirhams for me. The death of Abdullah bin Tahir was in the year two hundred thirty, in the days of Al-Wathiq.

Ahmad bin Abi Dawud mentioned that Muhammad bin Abdul Malik advised Al-Wathiq, when the news of Abdullah bin Tahir's death arrived, to send Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Mus'ab to Khurasan in Abdullah's place. He agreed to that and ordered him to write his letters and oversee his preparation. He said: Al-Wathiq sent for me, so I attended the house. I saw Muhammad bin Abdul Malik and Ishaq bin Ibrahim sitting, and Muhammad writing the letter. When he saw me, he turned it over. I took it as an omen that what they were in would be overturned. I entered upon Al-Wathiq. He mentioned to me the news of Abdullah bin Tahir's death, and that he had decided to send Ishaq to Khurasan, add five thousand men of the army to him, release their stipends, and release five million dirhams to Ishaq as aid. I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, Ishaq is the hostage of the people [Tahirids] with you. If you send him out, you will have nothing of the people in your hand. As for the army, you need to increase them, so how can you disperse them, especially with what is spent on them? Sending out these monies has no justification. Here is what is better than that.' He said: 'What is it?' I said: 'A scroll for two dirhams in which you write to Tahir bin Abdullah offering condolences for his father and renewing the governorship for him. You gain what you would spend, and you would have completed the favor for Abdullah and his child and improved the successorship in him.' He said: 'The right is what you said!' He ordered Muhammad bin Abdul Malik to do that and to abandon what he had decided on. The duration of Abdullah bin Tahir's life was forty-eight years. As for Tahir bin al-Husayn, he was among the masters of people, men of opinion and might. Al-Ma'mun named him Dhu al-Yamanayn (Possessor of Two Right Hands), so he used to write and be written to with it. Al-Mu'tasim asked a group of his intimates about the meaning of naming Tahir Dhu al-Yamanayn, but they did not know. Muhammad bin Abdul Malik said: 'Its meaning is: Possessor of Two Entitlements (Istihqaqayn): entitlement by his grandfather and closeness in the state, for he was one of the Nuqaba'; and entitlement by what he has in Al-Ma'mun's state. Allah Almighty said: "We would have seized him by the right hand (Al-Yamin)," meaning by entitlement. And the poet said: "If a banner is raised for glory... 'Arraba receives it with the right hand (Yamin)."' Jabhan al-Shi'i mentioned, saying: Al-Husayn bin Mus'ab was of good opinion, excellent in hitting the mark with conjecture. He said: I was one day in the house of Ali bin Isa bin Mahan, and he had ordered Tahir bin al-Husayn, so he was tied with a rope to a pillar. Al-Husayn said to me: 'Do you not see this tied one'—meaning his son—'he will surely kill the owner of this palace.' This saying passed with me as a joke. Then what happened between them happened, so I marveled at Al-Husayn's saying. He said: When Al-Amin sent Ali bin Isa bin Mahan with armies to Khurasan to take Al-Ma'mun and send him to him, Al-Ma'mun contracted Tahir bin al-Husayn over four thousand and sent him to Rayy to fight Ali bin Isa. Ali bin Isa wrote to him to establish provisions for him, not thinking he would fight him. Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir said: Abdul Rahman bin Fahm told me, from his uncle, saying: I set out seeking Al-Ma'mun. I pushed to Tahir's camp on the day of the battle. I saw him arranging the rows, going and coming, with a piece of bread in his hand. With a boy of his was a lead pitcher containing water. I said: 'O Emir, this is not a time for eating!' He said: 'An apology to you and to those who do not know my news. No food has entered my stomach for three [days] due to my preoccupation with this matter, and I feared I might need my self [strength] and it would betray me at this time. So I did what you saw.' I said: 'The Emir knows better what he suffers.' Ubaydullah said: A group of our sheikhs told me, saying: When Ali's army approached, their standard bearer was Hatim al-Ta'i. He had been flogged eight hundred lashes until the flesh of his buttocks was gone. He was huge in build, fierce in might. He had four boys lifting him until he sat in his saddle. Once settled in his saddle, he was counted as a thousand knights. Tahir said: I made him my target and charged at him. When I got close to him, behold he was covered in iron, the blow not reaching him. I saw something that appalled me. I said: 'There is nothing but to strike him on the helmet; if the sword works in it, [good], otherwise it is destruction.' I gathered my hands then struck him on his head. I cut the helmet and the head, until the sword got stuck between his teeth. He said: When Hatim was killed, the people were disturbed. Ali bin Isa was riding in a dome (howdah). He came down from it, and a rusty-legged chestnut horse was brought to him to ride. Dawud Siyah stabbed him before he could settle in his saddle, killing him without knowing him. He went to Tahir and said: 'I have killed the Judge of the Army,' then brought his head. Tahir's caller called out: 'Whoever takes something, it is his, and the obligation is clear of whoever sheds blood.' He wrote to Al-Ma'mun and Dhu al-Ri'asatayn: 'My letter [is written] while Ali bin Isa's head is before me and his ring is on my finger. Peace.' Then Tahir marched to Baghdad, and his affair was what it was.

He said: Al-Ma'mun, upon his entry into Baghdad, was angry with Muhammad bin Abi al-Abbas al-Tusi. He sought refuge with Tahir bin al-Husayn, who was his friend, and asked him to ask Al-Ma'mun to forgive him. Fath the servant was the doorkeeper for wine, Yasir handled the robes, Husayn poured, and Abu Maryam, the boy of Sa'id al-Jawhari, went back and forth for needs. Tahir rode to the house. Fath entered and said: 'Tahir is at the door!' He said: 'It is not one of his times; let him in.' Tahir entered upon Al-Ma'mun while he was drinking. He gave him a rotl to drink and ordered him to sit. He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, it is not for the Chief of Police to sit before his master.' Al-Ma'mun said: 'That is in the general assembly; as for the private assembly, sitting is permitted for him.' Then he gave him two more rotls. Al-Ma'mun wept, and his eyes welled up. Tahir said to him: 'Why do you weep, O Commander of the Faithful? May Allah not make your eye weep, when the lands have submitted to you, the servants have yielded to you, and you have come to love in all your affairs?' He said: 'I weep for a matter in whose mention is humiliation and in whose concealment is sadness. No one is free of grief. Speak your need if you have one!' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, Muhammad bin Abi al-Abbas erred; forgive his slip and be pleased with him.' He said: 'I have become pleased with him and ordered his gift and the return of his rank. Were it not that he is not of the people of intimacy, I would have brought him!' He thanked that, prayed for Al-Ma'mun, and left, his heart occupied by his weeping. He said to Marwan bin Jabghawayh his scribe: 'Scribes have subtlety, and the people of Khurasan support each other. Take with you three hundred thousand dirhams. Give Al-Husayn the servant two hundred thousand, give his scribe Muhammad bin Harun one hundred thousand, and ask him to ask the Commander of the Faithful why he wept?' He said: He did that. When Al-Husayn was alone with Al-Ma'mun the next day, and his soul was pleasant, he asked him about the reason for his weeping. He said to him: 'Why did you ask about that?' He said: 'Because of my distress for it and my disturbance for its sake.' He said: 'O Husayn, it is a thing that if it leaves your head, I will kill you!' He said: 'O my master, when have I revealed a secret for you?' He said: 'When I saw Tahir, I remembered Muhammad my brother and what humiliation befell him. Tears choked me, so I found relief in pouring them out. Tahir will not escape from me what he hates.' He said: Muhammad bin Harun informed Tahir of that. Tahir rode to Ahmad bin Abi Khalid, who was the Vizier, and said to him: 'A favor with me is not lost, and praise from me is not cheap. Absent me from the Commander of the Faithful.' He said to him: 'Come to me early tomorrow, for I will do it.' He went to him early, and Ibn Abi Khalid went early to Al-Ma'mun. When he reached him, he said: 'I did not sleep last night!' He said: 'Why, woe to you?' He said: 'Because you appointed Ghassan bin Abbad over Khurasan, and he and those with him are a mere mouthful (eaters of a head). I fear a rebel might come out against him and uproot him.' He said: 'I have thought about what you thought about. Whom do you see?' He said: 'Tahir bin al-Husayn.' He said: 'Woe to you, O Ahmad, he is, by Allah, a deposer.' He said: 'I am the guarantor for him.' He kept at him until he answered him. He called for Tahir immediately, contracted him, and he set out the same day. He camped at the garden of Khalil bin Hisham; that was Friday, one night remaining of Dhu al-Qa'dah, year two hundred and five. When Tahir bin al-Husayn arrived in Khurasan, the Shurat (Kharijites) had increased there and their matter intensified. Al-Ma'mun wrote him many letters urging him to combat them and criticizing his sluggishness in their affair. Tahir wrote mentioning the coarseness of their affair and the strength of their power, and that he needed an increase in equipment and men to meet them. That angered Al-Ma'mun, so he wrote to him harshly, saying: 'I have resolved to return you to where your father is.' Kulthum bin Thabit bin Abi Sa'd, nicknamed Abu Sa'da, who was in charge of the post over Tahir bin al-Husayn in Khurasan, mentioned that he sat on Friday near the pulpit when what happened from Tahir became clear upon the arrival of what arrived to him. Tahir ascended the pulpit and preached. When he reached the mention of the Caliph, he refrained from praying for him and said: 'O Allah, rectify the nation of Muhammad with what You rectified Your allies, and spare it the burden of those who transgressed in it and gathered against it, by mending the rift, sparing blood, and reconciling relationships.' He said: 'I knew I would be the first killed, because I could not hide the news, and my letter would not be hidden from Tahir. I left, washed the washing of the dead, wrapped myself in a waistcloth, put on a shirt, donned a cloak, and threw on black [Abbasid color]. I forced myself to write to Al-Ma'mun. But Allah brought from His work, by the proximity of Tahir's death, what I did not reckon.' When the news of that reached Al-Ma'mun, it was hard on him. He called Ahmad bin Abi Khalid and said to him: 'I had told you about Tahir when you advised appointing him to Khurasan what I knew of him, and you guaranteed what would happen. By Allah, if you do not devise a way to fix his affair as you guaranteed his corruption, I will strike your neck.' Ibn Abi Khalid sent gifts and novelties to Tahir, including poisoned white Kamikh (condiment), knowing his fondness for it. When the gifts reached Tahir, he ate from the Kamikh with roast francolin, and died after two days.

The birth of Tahir bin al-Husayn was in Muharram, year one hundred fifty-nine. His death was in the year two hundred seven. When he died, the soldiers in Khurasan rioted and looted Tahir's treasuries. Al-Ma'mun appointed his son Talha in his place, and sent Ahmad bin Abi Khalid to Khurasan to assist him in restoring order. He went there, fixed matters, and calmed their disturbance. Talha sent him three thousand dirhams and goods worth two million dirhams, and gifted Ibrahim bin al-Abbas his scribe five thousand dirhams. 

**Dayr al-Susi (Monastery of al-Susi)**
This is a small monastery on the bank of the Tigris, at the Qadisiyah of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra). Between Qadisiyah and Surra Man Ra'a are four farsakhs, and Al-Matira is between them. All these areas are parks, gardens, and vineyards. People visit this monastery and drink in its gardens. It is one of the places of joy and spots of revelry and play. Ibn al-Mu'tazz has [poetry] in it: 'O my nights at Al-Matira and Al-Karkh... and the neighborhood of Al-Susi, by Allah, return. You were to me samples of Paradise... but without eternity.' Qadisiyah is one of the best and most pleasant places; it is a mine of drink and a resting place for pleasure-seekers, gathering what the people of idleness and loss seek. In Qadisiyah, Al-Mutawakkil built his palace known as Barkuwara. When he finished building it, he gifted it to his son Al-Mu'tazz and performed his circumcision there. It was one of Al-Mutawakkil's best and most magnificent buildings. The expenditure on it reached twenty million dirhams. He said: When his resolve was firm on circumcising Abu Abdullah Al-Mu'tazz, he ordered Al-Fath bin Khaqan to prepare for it, and to seek in the treasuries of furnishings a carpet for the Iwan in its width and length. Its length was one hundred cubits and its width fifty cubits. It was only found in what was confiscated from the Banu Umayya; it was found in the belongings of Hisham bin Abdul Malik, matching the length and width of the Iwan. It was a silk carpet with gold stitching, sorted and lined. When Al-Mutawakkil saw it, he admired it and wanted to know its value. Merchants were gathered for it, and it was mentioned that it was valued at the average price of ten thousand dinars. It was spread in the Iwan. A throne was spread for the Caliph at the head of the Iwan. Four thousand gold trays encrusted with jewels were extended before him, containing figures of amber, kneaded musk, and camphor made like images; some encrusted with jewels only, and some with gold and jewels. They were made a spread-out carpet. Al-Mutawakkil and the people had lunch. He sat on the throne. The Emirs, commanders, boon companions, and rank holders were brought and seated in their ranks. A gap was made between their trays and the tablecloth. The carpet spreaders came with baskets covered with leather filled with dinars and dirhams, half and half. They were poured into those gaps until they rose high. The boys stood on top of them and ordered the people on behalf of the Caliph to drink, and that everyone who drinks should transfer with three handfuls what his hands could carry of that money. When what gathered in his sleeve weighed one down, he would go out to his servants, give it to them, and return to his seat. Whenever a place became empty, the spreaders brought what filled it until it returned to its state. Three robes were bestowed on everyone present. They stayed until the Asr and Maghrib prayers were prayed. Upon their departure, they were mounted on horses and noble steeds. Al-Mutawakkil freed one thousand slaves on behalf of Al-Mu'tazz, and ordered for each one of them one hundred dirhams and three garments. In the courtyard of the house, before the Iwan, were four hundred beautiful women wearing types of clothes. Before them were a thousand rattan baskets containing types of fruits: citron, bitter orange—despite its scarcity at that time—Syrian apples, limes, five thousand bunches of narcissus, and ten thousand bunches of violet. He advanced to Al-Fath to scatter upon the beautiful women, the house servants, and the entourage what he had prepared for them, which was twenty million dirhams. No one dared to pick up anything. So Al-Fath took a dirham, and the group bent over the money and looted it. Qabiha had ordered dirhams to be struck, on which was: 'Blessing from Allah, for the circumcision of Abu Abdullah Al-Mu'tazz Billah.' One million dirhams were struck for her, which were scattered on the barber and those in his sphere, the boys, the Shakiriya, the house stewards, and the special servants, white and black. Among those who attended the assembly that day were Muhammad bin Al-Muntasir, Abu Ahmad and Abu Sulayman the sons of Al-Rashid, Ahmad and Al-Abbas the sons of Al-Mu'tasim, Musa bin Al-Ma'mun, the two sons of Hamdun the Boon Companion, Ahmad bin Abi Ruaym, Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak, Ali bin al-Jahm, Ali bin Yahya al-Munajjim and his brother Ahmad. Of the singers: Amr bin Bana, Ahmad bin Abi al-Ala, Ibn al-Hafsi, Ibn al-Makki, Salmak al-Razi, Ath'ath, Sulayman the Drummer, Al-Masdud, Abu Hashisha, Ibn al-Qassar, Salih the Tambourine Player, Zanam the Piper, Tuffah the Piper.

Of the female singers: Arib, her slave girl Bid'a, Sarab, Shariya and her slave girls, Nadman, Mun'im, Najla, Turkiyah, Farida, Irfan. Ibrahim bin al-Mudabbir said: When Al-Mu'tazz was circumcised, the sheikhs of the scribes gathered before Al-Mutawakkil. Among them was Yahya bin Khaqan and his son Ubaydullah, who was then the Vizier, standing in the position of servants with a tunic and belt. Yahya did not drink wine. Al-Mutawakkil said to Ubaydullah: 'Take a cup from those cups, pour wine into it, put a napkin on your shoulder, go to your father Yahya, and place it in his palm.' He said: He did so. Yahya raised his head to his son. Al-Mutawakkil said: 'O Yahya, do not refuse him.' He said: 'No, O Commander of the Faithful.' Then he drank it and said: 'Your favor has become great with us, O Commander of the Faithful. May Allah congratulate you on the blessing and not strip us of what He bestowed upon us through you.' He said: 'O Yahya, I only wanted a Vizier to serve you before a Caliph in the circumcision of a Crown Prince!' Ibrahim bin al-Abbas said: I asked Abu Harmala the Barber on this day, saying: 'How much did you get until the food was placed?' He said: 'Eighty-odd thousand dinars, besides jewelry, rings, and prepared gems.' He said: Al-Mutawakkil stayed at Barkuwara for three days, then ascended to his Ja'fari palace. He ordered the presence of Ibrahim bin al-Abbas and commanded him to make a report for him of what was spent in this circumcision and present it to him. He did so. The report comprised eighty-six million dirhams. People used to consider excessive what Al-Hasan bin Sahl spent on the wedding of his daughter Buran, such that it was chronicled in books and called the Invitation of Islam. Then came Al-Mutawakkil's invitation, which made that forgotten. The famous invitations in Islam were three which had no equal. Among them: This mentioned invitation of Al-Mu'tazz. And among them the wedding of Zubaydah bint Ja'far bin Abi Ja'far. Al-Mahdi married his son Al-Rashid to Umm Ja'far (Zubaydah), his brother's daughter. He prepared for her what had not been prepared for a woman before her of instruments, boxes of jewels, ornaments, tiaras, wreaths, domes of silver and gold, perfume, and clothing. He gave her the tunic of Abda daughter of Abdullah bin Yazid bin Muawiyah, wife of Hisham; the like of it and the like of the grains (pearls/gems) in it had not been seen in Islam. On its back and front were two lines of red ruby, and the rest of it was of large pearls which had no equal. Al-Rashid consummated the marriage with her in Muharram, year one hundred sixty-five, in his palace known as Al-Khuld. People were gathered from the horizons, and a great amount of money was distributed among them. Dinars were placed in silver bowls, dirhams in gold bowls, musk sacs and amber skulls and ghaliya in glass vessels. This was distributed to the people, and woven embroidered robes were bestowed upon them. Amber candles were lit before him that night in gold torcheres. He brought the women of Banu Hashim and gave each of them a bag containing dinars, a bag containing dirhams, and a large silver tray containing perfume, and bestowed on her a heavy embroidered robe. The like of it was not seen in Islam. The expenditure in this wedding from the privy purse, besides what Al-Rashid spent from his own money, reached fifty million dirhams. Zubaydah's name was Amat al-Aziz. Zubaydah was a nickname. Abu Ja'far used to bounce her when she was small—and she was chubby—and say: 'You are nothing but a Zubaydah (little butter ball/cream), you are nothing but a Zubaydah.' So this name stuck to her. And among them the wedding of Al-Ma'mun to Buran daughter of Al-Hasan bin Sahl, at Fam al-Sulh. The expenditure on it was a great matter. Al-Ma'mun asked Zubaydah about the estimate of expenditure in the wedding. She said: 'Between thirty-five million to thirty-seven million.' This reached Al-Hasan bin Sahl, so he said: 'It seems the expenditure was by Zubaydah's hand! We spent thirty-five million.' Among the total allowances every day was provision for thirty-odd thousand sailors. His consummation with her was in the city he built at Fam al-Sulh on the bank of the Tigris, on the eighth passed of the month of Ramadan, year two hundred ten. He said: Al-Ma'mun gave Buran a dower of one hundred thousand dinars and five million dirhams. Three amber candles were lit before him that night, and their smoke was abundant. Zubaydah said: 'In the chivalry that has appeared is sufficiency; remove these amber candles and bring the [wax] candles.' He said: When Buran was unveiled to Al-Ma'mun, he scattered large pearls upon her which were in his sleeve. They fell on a gold mat that was beneath him. He said: 'How excellent is Al-Hasan bin Hani (Abu Nuwas), what a great eloquent poet he is where he says: "As if the small and large of its bubbles... were pearl pebbles on a ground of gold."' He said: Those present refrained from picking up anything. Al-Ma'mun said: 'Honor her!' So Zubaydah extended her hand and took a pearl, then those present picked up the rest.

Buran's name was Khadija. Her death was in the year two hundred seventy-one, in the days of Al-Mu'tamid, and she was eighty years old. Buran has [poetry] elegizing Al-Ma'mun: 'Aid me in weeping, O my two eyes... You have become, after the Imam, for worry in me. I used to attack Time, but when... he died, Time began to attack me.' Ibn Khurdadhbih mentioned: That Al-Mutawakkil spent on the buildings he constructed—which are: Barkuwara, Al-Shah, Al-Arus, Al-Birka, Al-Jawsaq, Al-Mukhtar, Al-Ja'fari, Al-Gharib, Al-Badi', Al-Sabih, Al-Malih, Al-Sindan, Al-Qasr, Al-Jami', Al-Qallaya, Al-Burj, Qasr al-Mutawakkiliya, Al-Bahw, and Al-Lu'lu'ah: two hundred seventy-four million dirhams. And of gold one hundred million dinars. The value of the silver as gold at the exchange rate of the time, with what was in it of gold, is thirteen million five hundred twenty-five thousand dinars. He said: Al-Mutawakkil drank one day in Barkuwara. He said to his boon companions: 'Do you see that if it is not the days of roses, we do not make a Shadhkulah (Flower Festival)?' They said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, the Shadhkulah is only with roses.' He said: 'Nay. Call Ubaydullah bin Yahya for me.' He attended. He said: 'Order dirhams to be struck for me, in each dirham two grains.' He said: 'What amount, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'Five million dirhams.' Ubaydullah ordered their striking, so they were struck, and he informed him of the news. He said: 'Dye some of them red, yellow, and black, and leave some as they are.' He did so. Then he ordered the servants and entourage, who were seven hundred, that each one of them prepare a new tunic and cap of a different color than the other's tunic and cap. They did so. Then he chose a day when the wind was moving. A dome with forty doors was set up for him. He drank the morning draught in it, and the boon companions were around him. The servants wore the clothing he had prepared. He ordered the scattering of the dirhams as roses are scattered. They were scattered bit by bit. The wind carried the dirhams so they paused between the sky and earth as roses pause. It was one of Al-Mutawakkil's best and wittiest days. Al-Burj (The Tower) was one of his best buildings. He made in it huge images of gold and silver, and a large pool whose lining, exterior and interior, he made of silver plates. He placed on it a gold tree, containing every bird that calls and whistles, crowned with jewels, and named it Tuba. A large gold throne was made for him, upon which were images of two great lions, and on its steps were images of beasts and eagles and the like, according to what the throne of Solomon son of David, peace be upon them, is described with. He made the walls of the palace from inside and outside covered with mosaic and gilded marble. The expenditure on this palace reached one million seven hundred thousand dinars. He sat in it on the gold throne, wearing heavy embroidered clothes. He ordered that no one enter upon him except in woven embroidered clothes or brocade on the outside. His sitting in it was in the year two hundred thirty-nine. Then he called for food. The boon companions and all singers and entertainers attended, and people ate. He tried to sleep but could not. Al-Fath said to him: 'O my master, this is not a day of sleep.' So he sat for drinking. When night came, he tried to sleep, but it was not possible. He called for violet oil, put some on his head and inhaled it, but it did not benefit him. He remained for three days and nights not sleeping. Then he developed a sharp fever. He moved to Al-Haruni, the palace of his brother Al-Wathiq, and stayed there for six months sick. He ordered the demolition of Al-Burj and the minting of those ornaments into coin. 

**Dayr Marmar (Monastery of Marmar)**
This monastery is in Surra Man Ra'a, at the Bridge of Wasif. It is a populated monastery with many monks. Around it are vineyards and trees. It is one of the pleasant spots and good beautiful places. Al-Fadl bin al-Abbas bin al-Ma'mun has [poetry] in it: 'I exhausted the horses of my pleasures in Surra Man Ra'a... and attained in it the wishes of my soul and my desires. I populated in it the spots of amusement immersed... in revelry between rivers and gardens. In Dayr Marmar when we revive the morning drink in it... and work the cup in it in the evenings. Between bells and holiness at times... and at times between ouds and flutes. And how many a gazelle in it, slender-necked, flirtatious... hunting us with Babylonian glances.'

Al-Fadl mentioned this: He went out one day with Al-Mu'tazz for hunting. He said: I, he, and Yunus bin Bugha became separated from the procession. Al-Mu'tazz complained of thirst. I said to him: 'O Commander of the Faithful, there is a monk in this monastery whom I know; he has good affection and a light spirit, and there are beautiful instruments inside. Would the Commander of the Faithful like to divert to him?' He said: 'Do so.' So we went to the monk (Dayrani). He welcomed us and met us with the most beautiful reception, and brought us cold water which we drank. He offered for us to dismount at his place and said: 'Cool yourselves with us, and we will bring you what is available in our monastery for you to partake of?' Al-Mu'tazz found him charming and said: 'Let us dismount to him.' So we dismounted. The monk asked me about Al-Mu'tazz and Yunus bin Bugha. I said: 'They are two youths from the sons of the soldiers.' He said: 'Rather, they are two escaped ones from the spouses of the Houris!' I said: 'This is not of your religion nor your belief!' He said: 'It is now my religion and belief!' Al-Mu'tazz laughed. Then he brought us bread, condiments, and what is typical in monasteries; it was of the cleanest food, the best taste, and the finest vessels. We ate and washed our hands. Al-Mu'tazz said to me: 'Ask him, between you and him: Who would you love to be with you from these two and not part from you?' He said: I asked him, and he said: 'Both of them, and a date.' Al-Mu'tazz laughed until he leaned against the wall of the monastery from laughter. I said to the monk: 'You must choose.' He said: 'Choice in this is destruction! Allah has not created a mind that can distinguish between these.' Then the procession caught up with us, and the monk was terrified. Al-Mu'tazz said to him: 'By my life, do not cut off what we were in, for I am a master to those there and a friend to those here.' We sat for an hour, and Al-Mu'tazz ordered fifty thousand dirhams for him. He said: 'By Allah, I will not accept it except on a condition.' He asked: 'What is it?' He said: 'That the Commander of the Faithful attends my invitation with whomever he likes.' He said: 'That is up to you.' So we agreed on a day, and we came to him as he wished. nothing was left to be desired; he stood with those who were with him, and brought the children of the Christians who served us with the best service. Al-Mu'tazz was pleased with a pleasure the likes of which I had never seen. He gave him a large sum of money on that day, and he never ceased visiting him when he passed by, eating and drinking at his place for the rest of his life. He said: Al-Mu'tazz was generous in character, broad-minded, possessed literature and understanding, and spoke good poetry. He loved Yunus bin Bugha and could not bear to be without him. He and Yunus bin Bugha were among the most handsome faces and most beautiful of people. There was no one among the Caliphs of Banu Abbas with a more handsome face than Al-Amin and Al-Mu'tazz; they were proverbial for their beauty and comeliness. 'Arib said: 'I was a maidservant for Muhammad al-Amin among the count of servants; I wore a tunic and a belt, stood at his head, and perhaps gave him drink. My age then was seventeen years. He was the most beautiful of Allah's creation; we never saw a male or female like him in beauty and handsomeness, along with good character.' Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Ismail al-Marakibi, who was the son of their client, said: 'Where was Al-Mu'tazz compared to him? For we saw him and did not see Al-Amin.' She said: 'Al-Mu'tazz had a glimpse of him, but as for being his equal, he was not.' He said: Al-Mu'tazz's attachment to Yunus bin Bugha was an attachment of childhood. He would not part from him nor endure his absence. He has many poems about him, among which is: 'I knew the medicine of medicine for my pain... But I did not know the medicine of cunning and deception. I panicked at love, yet for fever I was patient... Indeed, I wonder at my patience and my panic. Whoever is distracted from his beloved by pain... My pain does not distract me from your love.' Al-Mu'tazz was drinking in a garden full of wild thyme (nammam), and among the thyme were anemones. Yunus bin Bugha approached wearing a green tunic. Al-Mu'tazz said: 'I likened the redness of his cheek in his robe... To the anemones in the wild thyme.' Then he said: 'Complete the verse.' Banan the singer hastened and said: 'And his figure when he appears bending... To the branch in softness and goodness of stature.' He said: 'Sing it now.' So he composed a melody for it and sang it to him. He said: Al-Mu'tazz drank one day while Yunus bin Bugha was before him pouring drink, and the companions and singers were before him. He had prepared robes of honor and prizes. Bugha entered and said: 'O my master, the mother of your servant Yunus is dying, and she desires to see him.' So he gave him permission, and he left. Al-Mu'tazz became languid and changed, then drowsy and slept. The companions slept, and the singers dispersed. When it was sunset and Al-Mu'tazz returned to his sitting place, Yunus returned with candles before him. When Al-Mu'tazz saw him, he called for a rotl (a large cup) and drank it, and gave him the like to drink. Then the drinking companions returned, and the singers sang to him, and the gathering returned to better than it was. Al-Mu'tazz said: 'You are absent so I am not happy... I wish you would not leave. Even if you tortured me... by not being generous [with yourself]. So I became between these two... I have a liver that is wounded. Despite that, O my master... your nearness is better for me.'

Then he said: 'Sing to this.' They began to think. Al-Mu'tazz said to Sulayman bin al-Qassar the Tanbur player: 'Woe to you! The melodies of the Tanbur are more fitting and lighter, so you sing it.' So he sang it with a melody. He [Al-Mu'tazz] gave him the dinars of the 'Khareeta' (pouch), which were one hundred Meccan dinars containing two hundred [in value], and written on every dinar of them was: 'This dinar was struck in Al-Jawsaq for the pouch of the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mu'tazz Billah.' Then he called for robes and jewels for the rest of the people. He said: Al-Mu'tazz drank a morning draught one day with Yunus bin Bugha. Two faces more beautiful than theirs were never seen. Three hours had not passed before they became drunk. Al-Mu'tazz said: 'You do not see a sight, if you wish it to be beautiful... Except a fallen one tumbling between two intoxications. The intoxication of youth and intoxication from the love of a fawn... whom you imagine, along with the one who loves him, to be two branches.' Then he ordered, and one of the singers sang it. Among his poetry about Yunus, which has a melody in the Ramal mode: 'Teach me how to shun you... despite the one I banished. And my shunning of you, O Yunus... is coupled with my death. However, Allah may know... what I reveal and what I hide. So may Allah protect me regarding you from Time... lest it comes with a calamity.' Harun bin Abdul Aziz bin Al-Mu'tamid said: Said bin Yusuf, my father's scribe, told me, saying: I was in charge of the clothing treasuries. When Al-Mu'tazz ordered something for Yunus, I would take the finest and best of what was in the treasuries for him. He used to offer me gifts, but I would not accept his gift. Perhaps he entered the treasury, and I would plane wood for him [joke with him] and jest with him. I said to him one day: 'O my master, I am your servant and a saver of your wealth, yet you honor Masrur al-Mu'tasimi with the beautiful greeting from what is before the Commander of the Faithful, while you do not honor me with the like.' He said: 'Tonight is your turn!' When it was night, he sent Wasif the servant to me with a gold tray containing peaches. I said to myself: 'Complete the greatness,' since it was from the Caliph's gathering. I took one and looked at it, and behold, it had been split, its contents removed, and replaced with kneaded musk equal to what was in it. I checked all of them, and it was a great amount. Al-Mu'tazz has regarding Yunus, when he left and returned: 'Allah knows, O my beloved, that I... since you were absent from me, am wandering and distressed. Joy approaches when a dwelling approaches you... And the purity of life disappears when you disappear.' The pledge of allegiance to Al-Mu'tazz was on Thursday, the third of Muharram, year 252, and he was deposed on the third remaining day of Rajab, year 255. He was killed five days after being deposed, and his age was twenty-four years, six months, and fourteen days. He said: Qabiha had incited Al-Mu'tazz against the Turks and said: 'O my son, kill them in every place.' She brought out to him the shirt of his father Al-Mutawakkil, stained with his blood. He said: 'O mother! Put it away, or else the shirt will become two shirts.' Ahmad bin Hamdun mentioned, saying: Al-Mu'tazz built a room in Al-Jawsaq in the Complete Courtyard; his mother designed it for him and modeled its walls and ceilings, so it was the most beautiful room seen. He said: Al-Mu'tazz invited us to it, so we were in the best day seen for joy. Behind the curtain was a female singer singing the best singing I had ever known. He said: We were in that state when a servant entered upon us carrying a tray with a cover. He placed it in the middle of the room. In Al-Mu'tazz's hand was a cup; he drank it and we drank. Then he said to the servant: 'Lift the cover.' Behold, the head of Al-Musta'in was on the tray. When I saw it, I gasped and wept. Al-Mu'tazz said to me: 'O son of a whore, what is this? Is it as if you felt pity for him?' My mind returned to me, and I composed myself and said: 'It was not for pity, but I remembered death!' He ordered the boy to return the cover and remove the tray. He removed it. It seemed as if a languor entered Al-Mu'tazz, as well as everyone present, and we dispersed from the state of joy we were in. He said: While we were like that, we heard a commotion behind the curtain that frightened us. Behold, a woman screaming and another woman cursing the screaming one. The screaming one was saying: 'O people, you took me by force, then you bring me the head of my master and place it before me!' We heard the sound of the oud being used to strike her head. He said: The one cursing and hitting her was Qabiha, and the girl was one of Al-Musta'in's maids. He said: We departed from the gathering in the ugliest departure, and what we were in was spoiled for us. Only a few days passed until the Turks assaulted Al-Mu'tazz and killed him. Then we were called to look at him, so we entered upon him in that room, and behold, he was stretched out in its center, dead. 

**Dayr Marihanna (Monastery of Marihanna)**

This monastery is beside Tikrit, on the Tigris. It is large, populated, with many cells and monks, frequented and sought after. It is never devoid of those seeking pleasure and picnickers, nor of a traveler dismounting at it. For everyone who visits it, there is a standing hospitality according to the guest's status, which they do not neglect. It has farms, abundant yields, orchards, and vineyards. It belongs to the Nestorians. At its gate is the hermitage of Abdun the Monk, a man of the Melkites, who built the hermitage and settled in it, so it became known by him. He is currently the one in charge of the monastery and the caretaker of it and those in it. He built a building beside it for passersby to stay, where he establishes hospitality for them and improves their entertainment. Poetry has been recited about this monastery, describing its goodness and pleasantness. Among that is the saying of Amr bin Abdul Malik al-Warraq: 'I see my heart has yearned... for the monastery of Marihanna. To its spacious gardens... to its singing pool. To a gazelle of mankind... who hunts mankind and Jinn. To a branch of the willow... for which my heart has gone mad. To the most beautiful of Allah's creation... whether he chants holiness or sings. When the morning dawned... we broached a jar between us. When the cup circulated... we circulated a melody between us. And when the night-talkers slept... we slept and embraced.' This Amr was among the dissolute libertines, engrossed in idleness and loss, infatuated with beardless boys, and throwing himself into monasteries. He has much poetry in licentiousness and the description of wine. We have mentioned of it what befits the book. Among his poetry is his saying: 'And a favorite in whom is destruction... I paid dearly for her with destruction. I wasted on her what I earned... and what I collected of property. I did not cease until I attained her... in a house of shaky wood. And a Karkhi wine... red from the water of grapes. I drank it deeply among youths... who are not on the religion of the Arabs. In a company who mastered licentiousness... in pleasure and delight. They made licentiousness a veil... for those who blame regarding ranks. Prayer passes them by... and intoxication is in their nerves. So if one wakes up... he is in pursuit of it. And if their prayers pass... they pray Jumada in Rajab.' Among his poetry in licentiousness also: 'O asker about me... I am not of the people of righteousness. I am a suspicious human... I desire the intercourse of the beautiful ones. I have divided time into two days... for debauchery and for wine. I do not care who blames me... I do not obey destiny when it looms.' And of his licentiousness also: 'If you do not drink wine and do not sodomize... then you, by my life, and the donkey are equal. And if you do not fill a house with whores and your bedding... does not spend the night on the ground without a cover. And if you are not a gambling slave at chess... and at backgammon you fulfill the bet. And if you are not quarrelsome in the game of date pits... robbing money or being a match. And if you do not keep a dog, a bow, and pellets... and a pigeon tower, prosperity will not hit you. And if you do not know what life is and do not find pleasure... then you are a donkey in which there is no doubt. So if you do not realize a life you were ignorant of... then take it as long as there is survival in you. And beware of ceasing from overflowing drunkenness... making your evening morning and the morning evening. And sodomize whoever you meet of the time among them, and let there not be... refusal from you if they give to you.' 

**Dayr Sabba'i (Monastery of Sabba'i)**
This monastery is east of Tikrit, opposite it, overlooking the Tigris. It is pleasant and populated, having a wondrous spacious exterior and farms around it on a river that pours from the Tigris into the Ishaqi, which is a large canal. Those near it visit this monastery during its festivals and the days of spring, as it is then a beautiful sight, containing a large crowd of its monks and priests. A poet said about it: 'The heart yearned for a monastery in Tikrit... between Sabba'i [and another place], and the priest of the monastery is an efreet (demon).' 

**Al-Dayr Al-A'la (The Upper Monastery)**

This monastery is in Mosul, at its highest point, overlooking the Tigris and the waterwheels. It is a large, populated monastery, proverbial for the delicacy of its air and the beauty of its view. It is said that the Christians have no monastery like it due to the gospels and places of worship it contains. It has many cells for its monks. It has a staircase carved into the mountain leading to the Tigris, about one hundred steps, upon which water is drawn from the Tigris. Below the monastery is a large spring that flows into the Tigris. It has a time of the year when people visit it to bathe in it, and they mention that it cures scabies and itching and benefits those with ringworm and chronic illnesses. Palm Sunday (Sha'anin) in this monastery is beautiful; people go out to it and stay there for days drinking. Whoever of the governors passes by Mosul stays there. Poets have spoken about this monastery and described its beauty and pleasantness. Al-Tharwani said about it: 'Give me wine in the morning... a ruddy coffee-colored wine. And drink a morning draught in the Upper Monastery... on Palm Sunday. Indeed, whoever does not drink a morning draught today... will not find success. Then adorn me with olive [branches]... and palm leaves as a sash. In Palm Sunday, even if... I meet disgrace in that. Honor the banners and the monks... and the beautiful crosses. And make the church and the palace... all a resting place. Not like one who jokes with fame... and robes a joke. Or leave fame and stick to... everyone who desires righteousness. And stick to the Friday prayer and the early morning... in it and the evening.' Al-Ma'mun passed by this monastery on his way out to Damascus and stayed there for days. His stay coincided with the feast of Palm Sunday. Ahmad bin Sadaqa mentioned, saying: We went out with Al-Ma'mun and stayed at the Upper Monastery in Mosul for its goodness and integrity. The feast of Palm Sunday came, so Al-Ma'mun sat in a beautiful place in it overlooking the Tigris, the desert, and the orchards, watching from it who entered the monastery. The monastery was decorated that day with the best attire. Its monks and priests came out to the altar, surrounded by their young men with censers in their hands, wearing crosses and sashed with embroidered kerchiefs. Al-Ma'mun saw that and admired it. Then the people dispersed to their cells and offerings, and those with them of the slave girls and boys turned to Al-Ma'mun, each holding a gift of the aromatic plants of their season, and groups of them holding cups containing types of drink. He drew them near and began taking a greeting from this one and that one, having been enamored by what he saw of them—and there was none among us but was in this state. During that, he was drinking and the music was playing. Then he ordered the bringing out of those with him of his sash-wearing (Christian-style) maidservants. Twenty maidservants came out to him like full moons, wearing brocade, with gold crosses on their necks, holding palm leaves and olives in their hands. He said: 'O Ahmad, you have said verses about these; sing them to me.' They are: 'Gazelles like dinars... beautiful in the chambers. Palm Sunday revealed them... to us in belts (Zunnars). They have arranged side-locks... like the tails of hornets. And they approached with waists... like the waists of wasps.' Then he brought out Ni'am, his slave girl—she was a young servant—and she sang: 'You claimed that I am unjust so you abandoned me... and shot into my liver a penetrating arrow. Yes, I wronged you, so forgive and overlook... This is the station of the one seeking protection and refuge.' He was delighted, drank, and asked for the song to be repeated several times. Then he said to Al-Yazidi: 'Have you seen anything better than what we are in?' He said: 'Yes, O Commander of the Faithful: That you thank the One who granted you this, so He increases it for you and preserves it for you.' He said: 'May Allah bless you, for you have reminded in the place of remembrance.' Then he ordered thirty thousand dirhams, and gave it as charity immediately. Beside this monastery is the shrine of Amr bin al-Hamiq al-Khuza'i, and a mosque built by the Banu Hamdan connected to the grave. Amr bin al-Hamiq had companionship [with the Prophet] and was one of the companions of Ali bin Abi Talib, Allah's blessings be upon him, and witnessed all his battles. Muawiyah sought him for a long time while he moved from place to place. Then he was found in Mosul; he had developed dropsy and his illness intensified. Abdul Rahman bin Umm al-Hakam al-Thaqafi, Muawiyah's nephew, guided [soldiers] to him. They found him in a cave in Mosul and killed him, and carried his head to Muawiyah. It was the first head carried in Islam from one city to another. His body was buried in this place.

His wife, Amna bint al-Sharid, was in Damascus, and Muawiyah imprisoned her for a long time. When Amr's head was brought to him, he sent it to Amna in the prison and said to the messenger: 'Throw it in her lap and memorize what she says.' When he came to her, she was terrified by it and bent over kissing it. Then she said: 'O loss! In a house of humiliation, you exiled him for a long time and gifted him to me killed. So welcome to one whom I did not despise, and I am not forgetful of him. Tell Muawiyah: May Allah orphan your child, make your family lonely without you, and may He not forgive your sin!' The messenger returned with what she said. He [Muawiyah] ordered for her, so she was brought. With him was a group including Iyas bin Shurahbil, who had a protrusion in his jaws from the bone of his tongue. Muawiyah said to her: 'O enemy of Allah! Are you the owner of the speech?' She said: 'Yes, not retracting it, nor apologizing for it, nor denying it. And, by my life, I strove in the supplication, and I strive, Allah willing. Allah is behind the servants, and Allah is behind you with vengeance.' Muawiyah refrained. Iyas said: 'Kill this one, for her husband was not more deserving of killing than she.' She said: 'What is wrong with you, woe to you? Between your jaws is the body of a frog, yet you order him to kill me as my husband was killed yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land, and you do not want to be of the reformers.' Muawiyah and the group laughed, and shame appeared on Iyas. Then Muawiyah said to her: 'Get out away from me, and let me not hear of you in any part of Sham!' She said: 'I will leave you, for Sham is not a homeland to me, and I will not turn in it to a close friend or a dwelling. My calamity in it has been great, and my eye has not been refreshed in it. I am not returning to you, nor praising you where I was.' He signaled to her with his hand to leave. She said: 'Wonder at Muawiyah! He extends against me the edge of his tongue and points at me with his finger.' When she left, Muawiyah said: 'Carry to her what will cut her tongue from me and hurry her to her land.' She received what was ordered for her and left intending Kufa. When she reached Homs, she died there. 

**Dayr Yunus bin Matta (Monastery of Jonah son of Matthew)**
This monastery is attributed to Jonah son of Matthew the Prophet, peace be upon him, and was built in his name. It is on the eastern side of Mosul, between it and the Tigris are two farsakhs. Its location is known as Nineveh, and Nineveh is the city of Jonah, peace be upon him. Its land is all flowers and anemones. It has a beautiful, elegant appearance in the days of spring, and it is a destination. Below the monastery is a spring known as the Spring of Jonah. People visit this place for several reasons: among them recreation and play, among them seeking blessings from its location, and among them bathing in the spring beneath it. The Jews, in the days of Al-Husayn bin Abdullah bin Hamdan, infiltrated one of them who entered the temple and desecrated it. The news reached Ibn Hamdan, so he gathered every Jew in Mosul and confiscated a large amount of money from them. Abu Shas Munir said about it: 'O Monastery of Jonah, the rains have watered your direction... until you are seen fresh, smiling with blossoms. Water in Najir [hot summer] never cured a thirst... as your cold water cured the heat of my heart. Nor did a sorrowful one with illness settle in it... except that illness dissolved from him. I seek forgiveness from Allah for a sudden attack by a coquettish one... about whom the pen ran against me in your quarter.' This Abu Shas was among the most natural of people, with beautiful poetry, frequently describing wine, sticking to monasteries, throwing himself into them, and fascinated by their monks and those therein. From his poetry in which he described wine and was witty is his saying: 'Forbearance and dignity lent you... a robe of silence that is not returned. So rise to the wine and test it... when the abodes settle with you. And the birds sang in gardens... whose branches were adorned with greenness. From that which kings preserved... they are the great masters. When it appears while darkness resides... the place of darkness becomes day. As if they, with the wine, are a caravan... led in the darkness by a fire.' And from his beautiful poetry is his saying: 'Do not turn away from the daughter of the vine... by my father! For in it is the health of the body. And know that if you are fond of other than it... clouds of worry will pour upon you. And if you drink, be alert to it... so that the goodness of the taste becomes clear. If there were no rest in drinking it... except deliverance from the hand of grief.' He also said: 'O blamer, there is no way against the likes of me... and your blame regarding wine is impossible. O blamer, do not blame us for loving it... for our reproach regarding it is long. Both of us claim knowledge in wine... so leave me, I will not speak and you do not speak. Is not my mount the waist of a boy... and the connection of my fingertips a cup of chilled wine?'

'If the daughters of the vine are my drink... and my snack is his beautiful handsome face. I am safe with these two from the outcome of nights... and what the blamer says is easy on me. And one apologizing to me with half an eye... having a messenger from the break of its glance. I turned the cup away from him when he sang... although his tongue was heavy from it. Give me rest, for the Pleiades have risen... and every night of yours has been taken by a ghoul [calamity] from you.'

**Dayr al-Shayatin (Monastery of Devils)**
This monastery is west of the Tigris, in the district of Balad, between two mountains, at the mouth of the valley. It has a beautiful view and a majestic location. Its air is thin and gentle, its cells are populated and full of trees, and its land has many gardens. It has a wall surrounding it, and a lookout on the roof of its altar overlooking the Tigris and the mountain. People visit it to drink there, and it is one of the places for idle people and locations for those of licentiousness. Al-Khabbaz al-Baladi said about it: 'Monks of a monastery gave me pure wine to drink... like the devils in the Monastery of Devils. They walked to the wine the walk of the Rook [in chess] and turned away... and the wine walked with them the walk of the Queens [Farazin].' Ubadah, when Al-Mutawakkil exiled him to Mosul, used to go to Dayr al-Shayatin and drink there, and he would not leave it. He fell in love with a boy from the monks in the monastery, who was one of the most beautiful people in face and figure. He became infatuated with him and mad about him, and stuck to the monastery for his sake. He kept deceiving him, treating him gently, and giving to him until he stripped the monk from the monastery and left with him. The monks of the monastery realized what Ubadah had done in corrupting the boy, so they wanted to kill him by throwing him from the top of the monastery into the valley. He realized their intent and fled, never returning to the place. Ubadah was among the most pleasant of people, lightest in spirit, and quickest in wit. His father was one of Al-Ma'mun's cooks, and he was with him, so he turned out skilled in cooking. Then his father died, so he became effeminate (Mukhannath) and became a leader in rogueries and licentiousness. He was described to Al-Ma'mun, while he was then a youth, so he summoned him. When he stood before him, he made jokes, imitated, and jested, so Al-Ma'mun found him agreeable. He said: 'Take him to Zubaydah so she can see him and laugh at him.' So they took him to her. When he entered upon her, he found her on a saddle of a Takhtaj (palanquin/seat), and at her head was a maid shooing flies with a palm-leaf fan. Ubadah said: 'O my lady, it is as if you are from the nougat of the pool!' She laughed at him and found him agreeable, so he stayed with her for days. She gave him gifts and clothed him, and she could hardly bear to be without him. He said: Al-Ma'mun sat one day and ordered the meats, animals, and what is needed of cooking utensils to be brought. He said to the drinking companions: 'Let each one of you cook a pot.' He also cooked a pot, and his brother Abu Ishaq cooked a pot. Scents wafted from it that overcame the scents of their pots in goodness and aroma. They were amazed at that, and Ubadah was present, so he envied him. He said: 'If you want to increase the goodness of your pot, pour into it a saucer of caper sauce (Kamikh Kabar).' So he took a saucer of caper sauce and poured it into the pot. The moment he poured the saucer, foul smells wafted from it. Al-Ma'mun said: 'Woe to you! What is this foul smell?' Ubadah said: 'The smell of your brother the cook's pot!' He said: 'What did you throw into it so that it returned to this smell after goodness?' He said: 'A saucer of caper sauce which Ubadah indicated.' He said: 'Did you not know that if you introduce a dead body to a living body, it corrupts it?' Al-Mu'tasim held a grudge against Ubadah for this. When Al-Mu'tasim took power, he ordered his killing, then said: 'This dog does not have the worth to be killed, but exile him.' So he was exiled. When Al-Wathiq took power, he returned him, so he was with him and then with Al-Mutawakkil after him. Then Al-Mutawakkil got angry with him and exiled him to Mosul. Abu Hazim the Jurist said, when Ubadah was mentioned: 'How witty he was.' It was said: 'And how?' He said: 'Al-Mutawakkil had exiled him. When he arrived in Mosul, his creditors followed him and demanded payment, and brought him before Ali bin Ibrahim al-Ghumari, who was the judge of Mosul. He swore to one, then to another, then to another. Ali bin Ibrahim said: "Woe to you! Do you think these people conspired to wrong you? Fear Allah and return to yourself. If it is hardship, then there should be a respite." He said: "You spoke the truth, may I be your ransom! Not all of them claimed falsehood, nor did all of them claim truth, but I pushed away with [swearing by] Allah what I cannot bear."' Then Al-Mutawakkil brought him back. He was among the quickest of people in wit and fastest in answer. Al-Mutawakkil said to Ubadah one day: 'Leave effeminacy so I can marry you off.' He said: 'Are you a Caliph or a matchmaker?' Ibn Hamdun said to him: 'O Ubadah, if you performed Hajj, you would earn reward and people would see you with such a blessed face.' He said: 'Listen, woe to you, to this rogue: He wants to exile me from Samarra on a camel!' Di'bil said to him one day: 'By Allah, I will satirize you!' He said: 'By Allah, if you do, I will bring out your mother in the shadow play!' Sa'd bin Ibrahim the Scribe said: 'I said to him one day: Can there be an effeminate man without prostitution?' He said: 'Yes. But he won't be cute. He would be like a judge without a skullcap!'

He said one day to Abu Harmala the Barber: 'Shave me skillfully.' He said: 'O effeminate one, shall I put my hand on your face when I put it on the face of the Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'You also put it on the opening of your anus five times every day!' He said: Ubadah entered the bathhouse one day without a waistcloth, exposed and unashamed, and in the bathhouse was a dignified sheikh. He said: 'Woe to you! Do you not feel shame? Cover yourself with your hand!' He said: 'What should I cover? It is but the gift of Mecca: two eyeballs and a toothpick!' Ali bin Yahya al-Munajjim said: Ubadah said one day to Al-Mutawakkil, while Yahya bin Aktham the Judge was present: 'O Commander of the Faithful, tell Yahya to teach me the obligatory duties of crucifixion (Solb - pun on crucifixion/backbone/loins).' Al-Mutawakkil said to Yahya: 'You hear him.' He said, knowing that Al-Mutawakkil had winked at Ubadah to joke with him: 'He asked for the impossible, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'How?' He said: 'Because the poet says: "Indeed, he whom you educated in boyhood... Is like the wood watered during its planting." And this is an old man; education will not succeed with him. But if he has a young male son, let him bring him to me, I will teach him.' Ubadah looked at him and said: 'O Judge, if you were from the people of our trade, no one could overpower you.' He said: 'I am not of the people of your trade, and no one has power over me.' He said: Ubadah went out one day at dawn to the bathhouse and met a boy from the children of the Turks. He gave him ten dirhams and said: 'Cut your uncle's affair!' While the boy was upon him behind the alley, an old woman looked down from a room of hers, saw them, and shouted: 'Thieves!' Ubadah said: 'O old woman of evil! The breach is in my anus, what are you shouting about?' Abu Hazim the Judge mentioned, saying: I was staying in Damascus with Ibn Mudabbir, and no letter would come to him except he read it to me. A letter arrived from Sa'id al-Rasah, a deputy of his in Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra). He read it, smiled, and did not give it to me. I asked him about what was in it. He said: Sa'id wrote to me mentioning that he was standing at Al-Mutawakkil's door, when Musa bin Abdul Malik came out, his face changed. He said to his servant: 'Carry one thousand dirhams to Ubadah and say: Do not repeat increasing your meddling.' I asked about the news, and it was said: Musa entered upon Al-Mutawakkil while he was sitting by the Pool of the Lions, and Ubadah was before him speaking and jesting. Al-Mutawakkil said: 'O Musa, Ubadah has given me a headache, will you not relieve me of him?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, throw him into the lion's pool!' Ubadah said: 'Yes, throw me into the lion's pool, and carry him to the Lion of Damascus so he can extract the money from him.' Musa's face changed and calamity befell him, so he sent Ubadah money to silence him. 

**'Umr al-Za'faran (Saffron Monastery)**
This monastery is in Nusaybin, facing its eastern side, in the mountain, and the mountain overlooks the town. It is among the described monasteries and locations mentioned for goodness and beauty. Around it are trees and vineyards, and in it are gushing springs. It has many cells and monks. Its wine is described and carried to Nusaybin and elsewhere. It is never devoid of people of revelry and play, so it and its surrounding areas are populated by those who visit it. In this mountain are three other monasteries, in a single row, the most beautiful thing in view and majestic in location, which are: 'Umr al-Za'faran, Mar Awji, and Mar Yuhanna. The Great Monastery ('Umr al-Kabir) in the place is one of the parks of the world. Below the mountain is Al-Harmas, which is the river of Nusaybin, and springs gushing from the base of the mountain; the place is known as Ras al-Ma (Head of the Water). This mountain is the beginning of Tur Abdin, and it is three farsakhs from Nusaybin. This river runs between two mountains. On its banks are vineyards and trees. When it reaches Nusaybin, it splits into two branches. One passes by the Sinjar Gate, watering the gardens there and pouring into the Khabur. The other turns to the east of the town, turning mills there and watering the gardens and what is there. Mus'ab the Scribe has [poetry] regarding the Monastery of 'Umr al-Za'faran: 'The plots of 'Umr al-Za'faran were populated... by noble, excellent youths. With every youth yearning for youthful passion... loving the drinking of aged jars. With every youth inclining towards amusements... and the sounds of the third and second strings. We remained circulating the cups in it... on a garden like the engraving of Khosrow's carpets. And branches leaning with fruits... close to the picker, hanging low. The winds bend them as... the gazelle of my garden bends with the beauty of his stature. And rivers flowing sequentially... whose whiteness shines like pearls. And birds, if they sing to you, they suffice... instead of Ibn al-Mariqi and Banan. We answer them when they wail with sorrow... with the laughter of jugs and bottles. And gazelles whose pastures are my heart... saddened me from them what has saddened me. And their sons, and Yuhanna and Sha'ya... possessors of beneficence and beautiful forms.'

'I was satisfied with them as my share of the world... I became rich through them without the fair maidens. I kiss this one and kiss the cheek of that one... and this is a helper, compliant in rein. This is life, not [the lover's] basin and distance... nor describing landmarks and dwellings.' This Mus'ab was among the most openly dissolute people, most excessive in licentiousness and obscenity, infatuated with beardless boys, and throwing himself into taverns and monasteries. His poems are all about boys, not crossing this meaning to another. We present from that what is considered witty and salty of his meanings. From his poetry is his saying: 'I am the sodomite rogue, my religion is one... and I am desirous of earning sins. I sodomize and do not commit adultery; so whoever is a sodomite... I am a companion to him until the Resurrection. I follow the religion of the Sheikh Yahya bin Aktham... and I deviate from the religion of adulterers. And [I love] one like a willow branch in the garb of a rogue... when he appears to the eye, the mind wanders away. He has a snort; if I say: Connect me with a visit... the forelocks turn gray for it, O son of the noble. I invited for him a gang from the people of Lot... to whom difficulties submit in calamities. He said, while the tuning peg choked in his throat... the saying of one upon whom paths were difficult: A generous one whom time struck with a misfortune... and which generous one have misfortunes not struck?' From his poetry also: 'Advice from one who possessed an ear and an eye... came to you, and you will be happy if you do it. You must, when you meet [boys], have a good cheerful face... and be of the most dignified bearing among mankind and jinn. Do not leave fingers without rings... and ply people with traditions (Hadith) deeply. Admonish them and forbid them from abominations... and do not leave crying when you admonish. And be a brother to the father of the one you love so that... it is said: The brother of his father, and you have succeeded. And if you see your condition among people... and cannot be patient, then you are a thief if you look. And if they notice, look down then think... as if you did not intend a look. And treat the beardless boys with good gentleness... and do not leave the creeping [touch] if you get drunk. My advice, O Sa'id, do not leave it... for you are among the philosophers if you accept it.' He also said: 'I abandoned my licentiousness so I rested from blame... and I was, in persistence, without equal. O Ibn Yaman, have you heard of a lover... counted among the ascetics among those who passed before me? Did you not see me when I went out glorifying [God]... with the bearing of Abu Dharr and the debauchery of Abu Jahl? I am humble in my walk and turn away my gaze... and my prayer rug on my face is like the Baghle dirham [mark of prostration]. I enjoin good, not out of piety... how could I, when my deeds do not verify my words? I say when I meet people: Fear God... and if they knew my state, my killing would be lawful for them. My inkwell is the head of hypocrisy, and my notebook... and my sandals at dawn or going are my feet. I aim for a jurist, his jurisprudence is not my concern... but the beardless boys are with him, the gathering of my union. O how many a deceived one I deceived with my notebook... but when prudence turned him, my deeds opposed him. And how many a beardless boy whose father said to him... Stick to this one, for he is of the people of intellect. He flees with him from associating with a rogue... like one fleeing from the heat of wounds to death. So I gave him ample sodomy and was not found incapable... and I was to him in lowering [wings] and softness like a husband. And I softened him with kindness after hardness... just as the trainers soften the difficult camel.' He also said: 'And a woman saying, hoping for my righteousness: Until when? ... I said to her: As long as there is a beardless boy on earth. She said: You have worn out in error, striving... mounts of debauchery in which you go back and forth. Do you weep for a young one after a young one? I do not see... your weeping ending until time ends. O blamer, were it not for the beardless boys, I would have become a worshiper... they destroyed my religion upon me and corrupted it. People called me an ascetic when they saw... my humility; nay, in asceticism I have become most ascetic. I set up traps for them under humility... and gentleness sometimes has praiseworthy consequences. I resembled the ascetics, and war is deception... and I showed off with the rosary while the palm is tied [in contract/betrothal?].' He also said:

'Every life without religion is corrupt... and the beardless boys, O Ibn Yaman, corrupted my religion. How many repentances, followed by another I repented... so my time is not safe regarding my religion. If you secured me from what my soul fears... from them in Baghdad one day, I would seek refuge in China. I have asked an expert among their merchants... and he remained informing me with good description. He said: In China are colors [of boys] for which... hard hearts soften, and a matter not lowly. A sayer said: Take refuge in the House of Allah. I said to him... Who will save me from the beardless boys in Ihram? If mounds [hips] appear with waist-wrappers twisted on them... standing as a target for one who shoots me with a glance. Who is for me if they crowd me in their Tawaf... there my conscience reveals every hidden thing. I have no protection from the beardless boys except Allah... Lord of the Mathani [Quran verses], Ta-Ha, and the Ta-Sins. I was before today immersed in asceticism... my love for them mixed with the bearing of Ibn Sirin. I approach with the eye of a pious man, the filling of whose eye... is love for every pure-cheeked, soft one. So now I have repented, so my share of them is my look... I seek forgiveness from Allah, and kissing at the time.' He also said: 'I wept for my body in its diminution... I did not weep for a trace, nor a quarter, nor a house. And a rogue, haughty in his disdain... like a branch, associating with debauchees and rogues. I did not cease with him with my plotting and deception until... his recognition of the truth became denial. I assassinated the boy's mind with the cup, knocking it... with wine, following it with poetry and night-talk. Until when the night lent his soul... and sleep seized hearing and sight. I crept walking on palms touching him... like the walk of one stealing secrets to hear. And my pen returned moving quickly on his parchment... while the night cast curtains on the horizons. He said when slumber cleared from his eye... and he saw a waistband untied and traces: O sleeper of the night, happy at its beginning... indeed accidents may knock at dawn.' And he also has: 'And one dozing over the cup from his drunkenness... I violated what he preserved of his back. I kissed him two hundred kisses... and I was not satisfied except on his mouth. And how difficult it is for me, despite what pleased me... of the power over his affair. When he woke up, I saw him out of... rage coming out of his skin. He had plotted against me in pouring drink... but it was returned to his throat.' And he also has: 'O beardless boys, I have advised you... Fear from Allah the excess of His vengeance. If a beardless boy attacks and is haughty over... his lover, the outcome of his attack is: That Allah sends upon his beauties... hair, extinguishing the light of his splendor. The punishment of the beardless boy whose sins multiplied... is in the emergence of his beard. People deny him after knowing him... and they have advised each other of his long rejection. This is the Prophet of God before you... the eyes of his brothers denied him. And after him, where is the beauty of Abu... Bakr's face and his glances with his temptation? The temple hair has curled over his cheek... upon whiteness from beneath his redness. He became to people, after his glory... like Qu'ays at the door of his aunt.' 

**'Umr Ahwisha**
The interpretation of Ahwisha in Syriac is 'The Recluse'. This monastery is in Sa'irt (Siirt), and Sa'irt is a large city in Diyar Bakr, near Arzan, and the monastery overlooks Arzan. It is large and great, containing four hundred monks in cells. Around it are orchards and vineyards. It is the ultimate in construction, good location, and abundance of fruits and wines. Wine is carried from it to the mentioned cities. Near it is a great spring that turns three mills. Beside it is a river known as the River of the Romans. This monastery is intended from every place for picnicking and drinking. Libertines and those seeking pleasure prevail over it more than its inhabitants. Al-Labbadi the poet has [verses] about it: 'And youths like your concern from people... light in going early and returning. I rose with them, while the curtain of night was cast... and the light of morning had clipped wings. We intend, in the monastery of Ahwisha, a gazelle... strange in beauty like the bright moon.'

'We endured the night journey longing for him... so we met the morning with the morning. We settled in a beautiful, elegant dwelling... populated in its regions with what we desire. We divided the time in it for an evening drink... upon the beautiful face and for a morning drink. We remained between basil and wine... and strings helping us, eloquent. And time aided us with what we wanted... so we returned with success and victory.' This Al-Labbadi was nicknamed Abu Bakr Ahmad bin Muhammad, among the wittiest and funniest of people, and those of obscenity and licentiousness. He was named Al-Labbadi because he always wore red felt over his clothes. Abu Ali al-Awaraji mentioned that he was in charge of Ardabil. He said: 'I assessed twenty thousand dinars justly upon them according to their conditions at one time. Al-Labbadi was among those upon whom the assessment fell. Twenty dinars were written in his name.' He said: 'While I was sitting in the Diwan collecting, a man entered upon me whose face was plastered with red clay, wearing red felt, a red turban, a red staff in his hand, and red boots on his feet. He greeted, stood, and began reciting a poem he had composed, saying in it: "If the Emir is in need... of poets in noble lineage. Days have destroyed him until... he sought Iraq from the dogs." I said: Who is this? They said: This is Abu Bakr al-Labbadi the poet. I raised his status, then asked him about his poem regarding Ahmad bin al-Hasan al-Madharai and his news with him. He said to me: I sought him and found him traveling towards Qazvin. I stood for him on his way behind a stone, in this attire you see on me. When he approached me, I came out to him. I said: As you see, [time] has made me. He said: What? I said: ........... ... My cutting across the desolate wastes. I cut them time and time... again, by night journey, they cut me. I travel by night on a surpassing [beast]... in her journey, she did not betray. She knows no humiliation nor... was she tied by the fold of a halter. I run with her, traversing blindly... to you, O son of Al-Hasan. Seeking help, so help me... against the vicissitudes of time. For, by the Lord of the Corner... my walking has weakened my corner (strength). How many a gulp has it made me gulp... and a choking has it made me choke. As if it seeks me... in its bitterness with grudges. Praise be to Allah who... turned the turn from my lowly time. O you from whom the fruits... of generosity are picked by the picker. Your generosity from the highest peaks... calls with a declared voice. Come to the son of Al-Hasan... Come to the brilliant full moon. Come to the one whose generosity... is like the downpour of rain water. So I came running, by the One who... from His Throne granted me success. For the love of the family of the Chosen One... and their love saved me. Take them, rhymes... in which I exercised my wits. Your wearing them is better than... wearing the weave of Aden." He said: So he ordered ten thousand dirhams for me, and mounted me on a beast with its saddle and bridle.' Abu Ali said: 'So I signed to the collector to give him a clearance for what was assessed upon him. He took the clearance, thanked me, and left.' Al-Labbadi praised Abu al-Qasim Yusuf bin Diwdadh bin Abi al-Saj, so he went to his house. When he entered the vestibule, the doorkeeper spoke to him, denying his attire and felt: 'What thing are you?' He said: 'A poet, and I have praised the Emir.' He said to someone before him: 'Zabtara!' So he 'Zabtara-ed' him (mocked/dismissed him with a noise), and he left. He wrote to Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Ahmad, scribe of Al-Afshin: 'I praised the Emir Abu Qasim... and my soul was waiting for his gift. With praise like the weaving of spring gardens... which the dew covered when it came early. They said: A magnanimous one, abundant in structure... abundant in favors, yet I did not see him. When I reached his house... I was rewarded for his praise with "Zabtara". I denied my prize from them... and it was, by my father's life, objectionable. I enabled myself for accidents... and became certain I was a victim of greed. So weep for poetry and noble deeds... and call out to them from the graveyard. For Allah has heated the eye of a man... who is told today "How poetic he is!" So is there, O Muhammad, any gift... that moistens the uvula or the throat? Whoever does good, sees good... and whoever does evil, sees evil.'

Abu Bakr said: 'Yes, by Allah, and with honor!' He sent him a note for fifty dinars to the treasurer. The treasurer refused to hand over the payment unless he stayed with him. So he stayed with him, and he gave him the fifty dinars and five from himself. Then Abu Bakr took him to Abu al-Qasim Yusuf and told him his story. He laughed at it, heard his poetry, gave to him, mounted him, and clothed him. 

**Dayr Fiq (Monastery of Fiq)**
This monastery is at the top of the Aqaba of Fiq, between it and the Lake of Tiberias, in a mountain connected to the Aqaba, carved into the stone. It is populated by those in it and those Christians who visit it due to its great status among them; others visit it for picnicking and drinking there. The Christians claim it is the first monastery built for Christianity, and that the Messiah, peace be upon him, used to seek shelter there, and from there he called the Disciples. In it is a stone they mentioned the Messiah used to sit on. Everyone who enters the place breaks a piece from that stone for blessing. This monastery was made in the place in the name of the Messiah, peace be upon him.
