Abu Nuwas mentions it: 'By your Hajj intending Mar Sargis... then the Monastery of Nawbahar, then the Monastery of Fiq.' It is a witty poem, addressing a Christian boy he loved. Its beginning is: 'By the baptism of the Old Monastery... by its Metropolitans, by the Catholicos. By Simon, by John, by Jesus... by Mar Sargis, by the interceding priest. By the birth of the Messiah, by the day of Epiphany... by Ba'una, by the payment of rights. By Ashmuni and seven you advanced... and they did not deviate, all of them, from a path. By Saint Mary and by the day of Easter... and by the Eucharist and the old wine. And by the crosses raised by spears... shining when they flash with lightning. By your Hajj intending Mar Sargis... in the Monastery of Nawbahar, then the Monastery of Fiq. By the altar of the Church of God, the ransomed... and priests who came to it from afar. And by the bell in the churches which... prayer is established in them at sunrise. By Mary, by the Messiah, and every cub... a disciple on a firm religion. By the monks of the hermitages in its peaks... they stayed there in effort and distress. By the Gospel of Palm Sunday, the ransomed... and the play of Christians in the road. And by the great crosses when they appear... and by the belt (Zunnar) on the slender waist. And by the beauty composed in you, unless... you have mercy on my burning and the drying of my saliva. Nay, by the closeness after distance... an oath of a youth who is a lover to his sayer. You have become the adornment of every monastery... and a feast, despite your cruelty and disobedience. And your lovers have called to the Christians... announcing leaving Islam entirely.' 

**Dayr al-Tur (Monastery of the Mount)**
Al-Tur is a round, elongated mountain, wide at the bottom and tapered at the top. No other mountains are attached to it, and there is only one path to it. It is between Tiberias and Al-Lajjun, overlooking the Ghor and the meadow of Al-Lajjun. The monastery is at the very peak, with a spring flowing there, and around it are vineyards that are pressed, so wine is abundant with them. It is also known as the Monastery of the Transfiguration, because the Messiah, peace be upon him, according to their claim, transfigured himself to his disciples after he was raised, until he showed them himself and they recognized him. People visit it from every place, staying there and drinking in it. Its location is beautiful, and it is among the pleasant places. Muhalhil bin Yamut bin al-Mazra' has [poetry] in it: 'I rose to the Tur among youths... quick to rise to what I love. Like your concern, of youths who spent... their inherited wealth in the path of delight. Noble of ancestors, handsome of faces... mature of minds, young of play. So which time with them did not please... and which place with them was not pleasant? I made the camels kneel at its monastery... and fulfilled what was due of its right. I settled them amidst its grapes... I give them juice of the grape to drink. And I brought them a shining moon... with whom branches sway in the dunes. We urge the cups with his songs... and the controlled Ramal [melodies] with wonder. And between that is speech that pleases... and their wading into the arts of literature. So whatever you wish of a proverb current... and of rare, selected news. O goodness of that life, if only it did not cease... and O beauty of that happiness, if only it did not vanish.'

Muhalhil was among those naturally gifted in poetry, engrossed in licentiousness and play, throwing himself into places of amusement and delight, sticking to taverns and monasteries. We present of his poetry what befits this book of ours. From his beautiful poetry describing gardens and urging drink is his saying: 'To the madness of love I gave my heart... so leave me, O two blamers. My delight is increasing, so in heat is the one who... blamed me for licentiousness or forbade me. The gardens have revealed to me of the flowers... strange varieties and colors. The opening narcissus appeared gazing... from eyelids of camphor with saffron. Like eyes staring in bewilderment... looking at beautiful faces. The peridot of its stalks bends... out of delight for silver and gold. The dew stood in the eye sockets of it... then died and poured down like pearls. O boy, give me drink, for the time has laughed... and the goodness of this time is complete. Bring the jars near me, line up the pitchers, urge the cups, line up the bottles. Seize the time and take advantage of life's opportunities... and do not lie, for life is fleeting.' From his beautiful poetry in this meaning is his saying: 'The time of gardens is an elegant time... and the life of licentiousness is a delicate life. The time has combined their two states... so who wakes up and who becomes alert? O you who are the request for me and the wish... and who is worthy of love from me. Turn the glance of your eye, let it graze in... the meadows of gardens, for all is pleasing. Scattered bubbles and pure water... and fresh garden and elegant flower. It has copies edited and illuminated... so majestic calligraphy and delicate meaning. Your face laughs at a beloved face... and your nose meets fragrant musk. If the flower laughs at the flower of gardens... then how is escape and where is the road? Ox-eye daisies dazzled others with it... compassionate towards narcissus and anemone. So this is a fearful, timid lover... and that is shy, and likewise the beloved. You are pleased by eyes from it that please... with their glances, and cheeks that excite. Close ones carrying the dew of moisture... so those are gold and these are carnelian. Its leaves contained its pearls... and scattered from it what it could not bear. The breeze sways its branches... so some are drunk and some are sober. So hasten with us [against] the accidents of time... for the face of accidents is a thick [shameless] face.' From his beautiful poetry is his saying: 'Repeat your drinking of the cup in what you repeat... and help, for happiness has encompassed us. And urge the morning draught by the light of the morning... for accidents are asleep away from us. Shall we not thank the deed of our day... and boast of what we are in of eternity? A sky that is generous and arranged garden... and fresh flower and swaying branch. And incense wafting and wine relaxing... and a handsome cupbearer and flute and oud. And a voice that excites and a gentle flute... and elegant life and happy luck. May God perpetuate our life for us... and may the envious not attain his wish from us.' He said in this meaning, and it was sung: 'Burdens have arrived for joy... and Shawwal urged the month of fasting [to leave]. And the cloud approached wearing robes... musk-scented having no tails. Its garden brocaded the earth so it began... spreading in it, and the earth struts. An oud shook and a flute moaned from delight... and rotls [large cups] gulped the wine. And promised fear out of caution... and hopes came near to hearts. Our days in life are a loan... urged to annihilation by terms. So seize the opportunity of time and do not... neglect, for time is an assassin.' And of what is salty in it is his saying: 'A time like youth or like mutual satisfaction... after long rejection and avoidance. The rain impregnated every land so it became... in childbirth, and some in labor. O boy, give me drink, for life has laughed... to us and smiled after contraction. And I see the pearls of bubbles competing with... the pearls of dew upon the flowers of gardens.' He also said: 'I entrust to Allah one who did not deviate from my sight... when a thought passed, while the buttocks attract him.'

'Resembling him of the movements of the branch are the most similar... and of the breeze of fragrant musk the best.' He also said: 'And a wondrous one whom the mind is unable to describe... due to the excessive bewilderment of eyes. He is like the thought whose meaning became fine... so it became roaming in ideas.' He also said: 'As if his eyelids were composed from the body of his lover... so they resemble him in illnesses. In his temple hair is a scorpion stinging the body... the antidote for its sting is in the saliva of his mouth.' He said about a Christian boy he loved: 'He tied his belt (Zunnar) on the slenderness of the waist... and tied hearts in the belt. And he let side-locks flow over a cheek... I am, due to his love, stripped of constraints (Khali' al-'Idhar). And a forelock appeared from him reminding the looker... of a night shining over a day.' He is Abu Nadlah Muhalhil bin Yamut bin al-Mazra' bin Yamut bin Musa bin Hakim bin Jabala al-Abdi. Hakim is the martyr at Basra who prevented Aisha, Talha, and Al-Zubayr from entering it and fought them until he was killed. Of his news and killing: When Talha and Al-Zubayr took control of Basra, and killed the guards of the treasury, who were seventy men without sin or cause, and took Uthman bin Hunayf al-Ansari, the governor of the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, blessings of Allah be upon him, plucked his beard and wanted to kill him, Hakim stood among his people as a preacher and said to them: 'O people, Ibn Hunayf is preserved blood and a trust to be returned. By Allah, even if he were not an Emir over us, we would have defended him for the right of neighborhood and his place with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. How then when he has the right and authority? However, the living dies and the dead is questioned. So either you die as nobles or live as freemen.' They responded to what he called them to. Abu Umayya al-Asamm, who was the knight of the people, said regarding that: 'O assembly of Abdul Qays, die for that which... pleases Ali, and beware the shame of treachery. And do not fear in Allah the blame of a blamer... and die as nobles, for it is more honorable for memory.' Hakim went out in the morning with three hundred men of his companions to the enemy, which was Aisha. Talha and Al-Zubayr came out, and they carried Aisha on the camel. That day is called the Day of the Lesser Camel. Hakim fought a fierce battle, and began saying: 'You only want to obtain a share of the world. O Allah, kill them by whom they killed, and do not give them what they asked, and do not let them reach what they hoped, and do not forgive them ever.' He charged at them, while they were twelve thousand against his three hundred. He defeated them until he drove them into an alley. A man from Azd attacked Hakim while he was heedless and struck him on his leg, cutting off his foot. Hakim took his foot and struck the Azdi with it, knocking him down, then came and killed him, and began reciting: 'O soul do not fear... Indeed with me is my arm... even if my leg is cut.' He and three of his brothers were killed, and they expelled Rabi'ah from Basra and evacuated them from it. From the poetry of Yamut bin al-Mazra' about his son Muhalhil: 'Muhalhil, your youth preceded me... and your difficulty made my tears flow. At the borders of their Sham... I die so your trace is erased. If I were pardoned in my life... your danger would be great to them. O my sorrow for a lock of hair... to which your journey is long. And if I perish, then Allah... other than creation, is your shelter.' His poetry and the poetry of his son Muhalhil is abundant in all arts of poetry. We only mentioned what the book could bear and the condition required. 

**Dayr al-Bakht (Monastery of the Bactrian Camels)**
This monastery is in Damascus, two farsakhs from it. It is a large, beautiful monastery. It used to be called the Monastery of Michael (Dayr Mikha'il), then it was named with this name because of Bactrian camels belonging to Abdul Malik bin Marwan stationed there, so it became known by them. Ali bin Abdullah bin Abbas had a small garden in that place, the size of four jaribs. He used to go out to it and picnic in it during the days of his stay in Damascus.

Ali bin Muhammad bin Abi Sayf al-Mada'ini mentioned, on the authority of his men, saying: Abdullah bin Abbas bought a yellow Berber slave girl in Medina. She gave birth to a boy in Abdullah's house, and he named him Salit. He grew up in his house and turned out robust and witty. Then he traveled with Ali bin Abdullah to Syria. He remained in his service until Abdul Malik died and his son Al-Walid took power. He showed prejudice against Ali bin Abdullah and criticized him in the presence of people. A group of Ali's enviers and people of oppression strove and corrupted Salit, adorning for him the claim of being Abdullah bin Abbas's son, saying: 'You resemble him in your beauty and appearance.' So Salit claimed he was the son of Abdullah bin Abbas and disputed with Ali before Al-Walid. Al-Walid ordered them to be raised to the judge of Damascus. Salit brought people who testified for him regarding his lineage, and that was reported to Al-Walid, so he attached him to Abdullah bin Abbas. He disputed with Ali over inheritance, and his conflict with him dragged on until Ali approached him and placed him in his household. He used to attend to Ali's needs and affairs. Ali went out one day to his garden at Dayr al-Bakht. He had people working there, among them Abu al-Dunn, from the descendants of Abu Rafi', the client of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. A quarrel broke out between them and Salit, so they jumped on him and killed him, after Ali bin Abdullah had left for Damascus. They dug a hole for him in the garden and buried him in it. Salit was missing from his mother, so she became suspicious. She went out looking for him and was informed that he entered the garden and did not come out. She came to Al-Walid's door screaming. He said: 'Whom do you accuse?' She said: 'Ali bin Abdullah.' He said: 'Bring me someone who testifies to his entering the garden with him.' She brought witnesses to that. Al-Walid sent to the garden to look if they could see anything or a trace. They dug up several spots but saw nothing. A tiller who was in the garden said to them: 'Run water over it so it becomes clear to you.' They ran water over it, and the spot collapsed. They dug it up and extracted Salit. Al-Walid sent for Ali, rebuked him, spoke harshly to him, and said: 'By Allah, if it is proven to me that you killed him, I will kill you for him!' He swore that he did not kill him nor ordered his killing. So Al-Walid imprisoned him. He wrote to the emirs of the cities and their jurists about his story, what he was accused of, and what was testified against him. Umar bin Abdul Aziz wrote to him from Medina: That he should be flogged, dressed in a wool cloak, and paraded. Al-Walid called for Ali bin Abdullah, flogged him sixty-one lashes—and it is said one hundred—then paraded him, stood him in the sun, dressed him in a hair cloak, and poured water on his head. That reached Abbad bin Ziyad, who was a friend of Ali bin Abdullah and favored by Al-Walid. He came, threw his clothes over Ali, entered upon Al-Walid, and spoke to him about him, saying: 'O Commander of the Faithful, is Ali accused of murder? Ali is more God-fearing and virtuous than to kill anyone!' Al-Walid ordered him to be sent to Dahlak. When he was taken out of Damascus, Sulayman bin Abdul Malik spoke about him and said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, return him and imprison him!' So he sent a messenger, and he was imprisoned where he was overtaken. He was overtaken at Al-Far'a, so he was imprisoned there in a village of it until Al-Walid died and Sulayman took power; he returned him. He settled in Al-Humayma in Al-Sharat of Al-Balqa, and sold his garden at Dayr al-Bakht to Fatima bint Abdul Malik. He said: Abdul Malik, at his death, advised Al-Walid regarding three people: He said to him: 'Ali bin Abdullah, regarding his lineage, kinship, and devotion to us: honor him and know his right. And your brother Abdullah: keep him over Egypt and do not remove him from it. And your uncle Muhammad bin Marwan: keep him over Al-Jazira and know his position.' The first thing he started with regarding his brother: He removed him from Egypt replacing him with Qurra bin Sharik. He removed his uncle from Al-Jazira. And he flogged Ali with the whip twice! When the Banu Abbas took power, they found in the treasuries of Banu Umayya a letter from Sulayman bin Abdul Malik to Al-Walid, asking him regarding Ali bin Abdullah and acknowledging his right. This letter was the reason for leaving Sulayman in his grave at Dabiq, and they did not exhume him as they exhumed his brothers and the Banu Harb.

Abu Muslim, the leader of their propaganda (Da'wa), claimed that he was from the descendants of Salit bin Abdullah bin Abbas! It was among the things Abu Ja'far [Al-Mansur] rebuked him with: 'And you claimed that you are the son of Salit son of Abdullah son of Abbas.' This was the first thing he began his address with, then informing him of his sins. 'So you wrote to Abu al-Abbas saying: Indeed Ibrahim the Imam acknowledged what Muhammad bin Ali entrusted to him regarding your lineage and Abdullah bin Abbas begetting you, and that you are Abdul Rahman bin Salit bin Abdullah bin Abbas, and that he promised you, if Allah completes this mission and kills the infidels of Banu Umayya, to marry you to Umm Ali daughter of Ali bin Abdullah. So what were you saying to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, while you are of unknown lineage: A lout from the louts of Isfahan.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, your brother Ibrahim bin Muhammad told me this.' This dialogue occurred between them in a long address before he killed him. 

**Dayr Zakka (Monastery of Zakka)**
This monastery is in Raqqa on the Euphrates. On its sides is the Balikh river. It is among the best positioned monasteries and most pleasant in location. Kings, when passing by it, would stay in it and reside there, because it gathers everything they want of its construction, the value of its buildings, and the goodness of the places in it. Its exterior is a picnic spot, for it has wondrous remnants. In its vicinity are gazelles, hares, and similar things that are hunted with birds of prey, such as waterfowl, bustards, and types of birds. In the Euphrates, before it, are spots for casting nets for fish. So it gathers everything kings and commoners want. It is never devoid of pleasure-seekers due to its goodness, especially in the days of spring: for it has a wondrous view at that time. Al-Sanawbari has [poetry] in it: 'A southerly wind poured its buckets on the two Raqqas... noisy on both sides. And gave to the pavement a pavement of rain... visited repeatedly by the edge of the two forelocks. Monuments, rather remaining familiar places... in the most generous two institutes and two familiar places. It laughs with them at the Euphrates in every gap... so it laughs revealing gold or silver. As if the earth, of yellow and red [flowers]... is a bride displayed in two suits. As if the embrace of the two rivers of Dayr Zakka... when they embrace, is the embrace of two lovers. That Balikh protected the hand of the nights... and that Nile is of two neighbors. They stood like two bracelets, circling... on its sides or like two armlets. O picnicker in Dayr Zakka... was not my picnic with you two picnics? I repeat a glance between the rose of your dew... repeated between the rose of the two cheeks. And a smiling one like my arrangement of chamomile... revealed by the dew between two anemones. O ships of the Euphrates where you fall... the falling of birds between the two sides. Chasing each other coming and going... in haste, chasing two armies. You see us continuing with you as we promised... a connection we do not spoil with separation. O my two companions, take my rein... my passion, you are safe from two companions. The fifty [years] have usurped my youth... and stood between my pleasures and me. Amusement was to me like a brother... so we became after that for two causes.' From his beautiful poetry describing the two Raqqas: 'As for the gardens, their colors have appeared... their branches have crafted arts of their ornaments. Their meanings softened, and their breeze softened... and their beauties appeared and their time became good. They arranged necklaces of their flowers like jewels... arranging their emeralds to their gold. This is its lavender, and this its southernwood... this its anemones and this its ranunculus. If the pools of the clouds were connected... pouring, then its pools would be connected. The eye of every cloud weeps over it... its eyelids never tire of weeping. Led obediently by the south wind when it appears... as if its rein is in the hand of the south wind. Woe to the Southern Rafiqah, a locality... whose rivers and gardens were beautiful. O town whose worth continues to be great... in every quarter, and whose status is great. As for the Euphrates, it is its shallow water... as for the Hani, it is its garden. As if the days of youth are its days... and as if the times of love are its times. Whenever we hunt its gazelles one day... its gazelles continue to hunt our hearts. Urge the cups, for this is their time... Connect the gardens, for this is their season.' And he has: 'Time has become grim-faced... after we used to see it cheerful.'

'Days I drag the train of the days of youth... in the shade of a life that continues to be elegant. In the White Raqqa, when the oryx graze... my rights, and I do not observe rights for them. I go early to pleasures unobserved... by prevention, nor fearing obstruction. Among youths who removed their reins, so they... do not hesitate in the paths of righteousness to exit. I contended with them for its cup, as if its breeze... is musk diffused in the vessel, open. It tore the mask of night when... the hand of the boon companion left its mask torn. It dyed the blackness of its darkness with the redness of its color... so it was as if it was obsidian returned as carnelian. And I say to my two companions: Do pray... for me with the morning draught on the Euphrates a night drink. Indeed the Euphrates is the nectar, and you... are only exchanging nectar upon nectar.' And he has: 'The rose has surrounded the anemone... amidst your elegant garden. As if around it are faces... overlooking a fire. So drink upon this anemone a cup... you drink carnelian upon carnelian.' He also said: 'A groan of longing, and for the lover is a moan... when the eyelids overflowed upon the cheeks. Ah from a sigh created by longing... and a disease buried between the ribs. How can the aggrieved take comfort, or how can the lover forget... or how can the sad one be distracted? Do not blame me for the two Raqqas and leave me... for my heart is held hostage by the two Raqqas. O my boon companion, do you not yearn for revelry... for this is a time when yearning appears. Do you not see the side of the prayer-ground, and... its hills and bellies have shone from it. Chamomile, lily, and anemone... and spring flowers to be picked and calendula. Saddles of rain were saddled in its gardens... and its plains and rugged grounds became pleasant. Indeed March did not leave under the belly... of the earth anything that January had hidden. And the wondrous narcissus appeared like... eyes gazing at eyes. Do you not see the side of Al-Hani, and... the gilliflower and eglantine have shone in it. The nightingale shouted in it, the dove wailed in it... the turtle dove sang in its atmosphere. For this is its southernwood and its lavender... and this is the rose in it and the jasmine. And as if the Euphrates between them is a spring... of silver in which ships swim. Like the bellies of snakes or like the backs of Mashrafi... swords purified by smiths. No year has come to people like this year... no, nor has come the like of this time. A time of a land shining with flowers... and a cloud abundant in downpour, pouring. Waters meet: water from the cloud... and water flowing and spring water. How many a sound heart went towards Dayr Zakka... and returned while it was sad. If you stopped by the Monastery one day, arts would distract you... and arts would delight you. My blamer regarding my passion, enough, slowly... do not blame me, for blame is madness. How many a gazelle in whose palm the rose is offered... and in his cheek is a preserved rose. So if I move my glance in his cheeks... thoughts roam in my heart. No one is happy who is not aided by... a happy grandfather and an auspicious bird. And a tongue like the sword and a heart... true in determination and a firm opinion.' He also said: 'Who is the judge between Time and me... It did not cease until it tamed me with separation. As for my two quarters that became desolate... I did not marvel after them at two quarters. Why did I distance myself from Al-Hani, and I was... unable to distance from it the blink of an eye. O Dayr Zakka, you were the best familiar place... Time bestowed with it upon two friends. And by my soul, the meadow whose sides... smiled at us revealing gold and silver.'

'If the two weights (Jinn and Mankind) were burdened with what I was burdened of... longing, it would be heavy for the two weights to carry.' He also said: 'And to the two Raqqas I fold the villages of the desert... with a submissive mount folded by the back. Hail to Karkh, hail to Al-Umr, no rather... hail to the Monastery, hail to the two Cypresses. Spring has manifested in robes of flowers... and the doves fashioned the jewelry of songs. The hand of spring clothed them with colors... a cloak like the Yemeni Athami. O my two friends, give me, cure me... give me the dark wine, do not ward me off. Remove the water, remove the water, rise... bring near, bring near the daughters of the jars. Give me drink of every color of wine... upon all these colors. Green color like emerald in red... clear of skin like purple. And chamomile like moist pearls... separated between carnelian with coral. And spring flowers like dinars surrounded... by the flower of gilliflower and ranunculus. As if Al-Nu'man untied upon them... robes of the anemones of Al-Nu'man.' Al-Rashid has [poetry] mentioning this monastery: 'Peace upon the displaced stranger... the greeting of a lover depressed by it. A gazelle whose pastures are at Balikh... to Dayr Zakka, then Qasr al-Khashab. O you who aided against himself... by leaving behind, willingly, the one he loved. I will conceal, and concealment is of my nature... the love of the one I love from the one I do not love.' Upon his journey from Al-Rafiqah to Baghdad, he left behind Maridah, the mother of Abu Ishaq Al-Mu'tasim. He missed her, so he wrote to her with these verses. He said: When Al-Rashid's letter reached her, she said to someone who composes poetry: 'Answer him!' So he said on her behalf: 'Your letter came to me, O my master... and in it, along with grace, is every wonder. Do you claim that you are a lover of me... and that you are madly in love and ardent for me? If this were so, you would not have... left me as an opportunity for grief. While you are in Baghdad grazing in it... the gardens of pleasure with whom you love. O you who shunned me while I did not shun him... and O you who saddened me with what is in the books. Your letter has increased me in passion... and ignited the fire of flame in my heart. So grant that yes, I concealed the love... so how with concealing a flowing tear? And were it not for fearing you, O my master... the salvation she-camels would have brought me to you.' He said: When he read her letter, he immediately sent someone to bring her down to him. Salih al-Turki mentioned, and Al-Mu'tasim was in his care, saying: Al-Rashid loved Maridah with an excruciating love, so he said about her: 'And if you look at her beauties... then for every place is a look of an arrow. And she attains from you with the edge of her glance... what the blade does not attain with its edge. She distracted you, and she is a distraction for everyone with sight... who met the beauties of her face. Her heart has a clemency that distances her... from the lover, and her glance has ignorance. And for her face from her face is a moon... and for her eye from her eye is kohl.' Al-Rashid has good poetry, and single verses, which used to be quoted. Most of his poetry is about his slave girls and his love for them. From his poetry: 'She owned the one who became an owner to me... but she is unjust in her ownership. If I wished, power would drive her to me... but the rule of love is binding upon me. I loved [her] from among this mankind... while she is knowledgeable news of my love. Ugly is the action of one whose face is beautiful... the blamer is excused in the likes of him. The most beautiful of what a seer saw... if only he were merciful in his beauty.' And he has: 'Love has turned me to what you see... it wasted my body and seared my heart. Love has written on my forehead... This is a slain one in the path of passion.' He said: Al-Rashid had favored Haylanah, the slave girl of his brother Al-Hadi. He loved her intensely. He left her in Baghdad during some of his travels, then missed her, so he said these verses: 'The beloved sent his peace with the south wind... so return peace to him with the north wind. And know with your heart what his heart contained... and circulate the days with your love. Whenever you weep for him, be certain that... his eyes will overflow with pouring tears. So hold your tears out of mercy for his tears... if you preserve or guard a covenant.'

From his poetry about his three slave girls: 'I distributed my love willingly... between Shajw, and Diya, and Khunath. They contend for love from a lover... secure in a knot that does not unravel. And if Shajw comes visiting... she removes from me the grief of every sorrow.' He said: Al-Rashid was born in Rayy, at the beginning of the year one hundred forty-eight. Al-Fadl bin Yahya was born seven days before him, so Umm al-Fadl suckled him. Allegiance was pledged to him for the Caliphate on Saturday night, with fourteen nights remaining of the month of Rabi' al-Awwal, year one hundred seventy. In this night, Abdullah al-Ma'mun was born from a slave girl named Marajil. So in this night a Caliph died, a Caliph took charge, and a Caliph was born. This is one of the curious coincidences. Al-Rashid died in a village called Sanabadh, of the district of Tus. He was forty-five years old, on Saturday, four days passed of Jumada al-Akhira, year one hundred ninety-three. His caliphate was twenty-three years and a month and a half. 

**Dayr Masarjis (Monastery of St. Sergius)**
This monastery is in Ana. Ana is a populated city on the Euphrates, and this monastery is in it. It is large, beautiful, with many monks. People visit it from Hit and elsewhere to picnic in it. There are vineyards, presses, orchards, and trees there. The place is of ultimate beauty, gathering what the people of music and recreation need. Ibn Abi Talib al-Makfuf al-Wasiti has [poetry] in it: 'Many a reddish wine from the daughters of the Magians... Babylonian, ancient wine. I sipped it with a flute and oud... before the deacon struck the bell (Naqus). And a kohl-eyed gazelle of coquetry... with enchanting glance, Samaritan, a bride. His religion is announced as the religion of the Christians... but when he is alone, it is the religion of the Magians. We secluded with a gazelle looking at him... a Saturday to the morning of Thursday. Between roses, narcissus, and spring flowers... in the middle of the garden of Dayr Masarjis. Bending with the beautiful neck of a gazelle... possessing a silvered ebony cross. How many times did I kiss the cross on his neck... like a crescent crowned with suns.' In this place is the grave of the mother of Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid bin Barmak. When Al-Rashid traveled from Raqqa to Baghdad intending Hajj, the Barmakids traveled with him, and Umm al-Fadl died. She had suckled Al-Rashid with Al-Fadl's milk. He used to love and revere her. Al-Fadl's birth was seven days before Al-Rashid's birth. So Al-Rashid ordered, and ten jaribs of an orchard at Wadi al-Qanatir on the bank of the Euphrates were bought for her, and she was buried there and a dome was built over her. It is known as the Barmakid Dome. 

**Dayr Ibn Maz'uq**
This monastery is in Al-Hirah, in its center, near Dayr al-Hariq. It is a monastery with many monks, beautiful architecture, one of the intended parks and described places. Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman al-Tharwani has [poetry] in it: 'I said to him while the stars were rising... on the night of Easter at the beginning of dawn: Do you have a desire for Mar Fathion and... the monastery of Ibn Maz'uq, unshortened? This breeze overflows from the direction... of Sham, and the pearls of dew are on the trees. And we ask the earth about its vegetation... and its covenant with spring and rain. O what goodness and smelling of a scent... like musk coming with the breath of dawn. In drinking wine and listening to a proficient woman... distracting you between the tongue and the string.' This Al-Tharwani was a Kufan, naturally gifted in poetry, engrossed in idle pursuits, throwing himself into taverns, addicted to drinking wine, and excessive in following beardless boys. He knew nothing other than that. He was not found in any worldly matter except in it. His end was that he was found in a vintner's tavern between two wineskins, dead! From his beautiful poetry is his saying: 'Al-Mihrajan has come to you upon entering... escorted by musical instruments and singing girls. And the pure wine was carried towards you... the jars travel with it and carry it. For this day there is a clear merit... over the days, known and having status. If you revere it, you have honored Khosrow... and the noble Hormuzan has honored you. And Bahram Gur has purified love for you... and Al-Fayruzan hastened in your satisfaction. For the glorification of what they glorified... and their ancestors professed it and they professed. So leave dispute, and "No" and "Until"... and "I will come to you" and "Yes" and "Now". Your dispute is not permissible against the drinking companions... and Al-Mihrajan is not pleased with that.' He also said:

'You turn the glance of your eye from afar... resembling affection and threat. You acknowledge a connection with the glance of your eye... but your action towards me admits denial. You make me doubt, yet I know that this... is love between affection and rejection. Your love is a love renewed by the nights... and does not wear out with the passing of epochs.' From his poetry also: 'Repeat the drink to an intoxicated morning drinker... who woke up to drink it while the rooster had not crowed. And the night is in an army with many lightnings... of stars, and the light of dawn had not cleared. And life is no life unless you approach it early... a reddish wine that kills the soul's worry with joy. Until the one who drank it since he spent the night remains... with no liveliness in him, strutting like liveliness.' 

**Dayr Sargis (Monastery of Sargis)**
This monastery was at Tiznabadh, which is between Kufa and Qadisiyah, on the edge of the road; between it and Qadisiyah is a mile. Its land was surrounded by palm trees, vineyards, trees, taverns, and presses. It was one of the intended spots and described parks. It is now ruined and void, its traces effaced and its wells demolished. Nothing remains of all its traces except ruined domes and a stone on the main road, which people call the Press of Abu Nuwas. Abu Nuwas has [poetry] in it: 'They said: You will become pious after the Hajj! I said to them: ... I hope for God and fear Tiznabadh. I fear a vine branch disputing with me... the head of the halter even if I hastened the pace. For if I am safe—and my soul is not confident... of safety—I will not be safe in Baghdad. How far is guidance from a heart contained by... Qatrabbul, then the villages of Banna, then Kalwadh.' This monastery was among the best constructed monasteries and most pleasant in location. Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak has [poetry] in it: 'My two brothers, come to the morning drink in the morning... wake up and do not bypass the boon companion going. As long as a helper stays for the morning drink... and for the evening drink, I will not want departure. Return to our habit of yesterday morning... for return is more praiseworthy as a start and a return. Do you excuse a companion at Dayr Sargis... for sobriety, or do you see that as a sin? I seek refuge for you by a familiarity between us... that you drink pure water in the villages of the Euphrates. Our jugs roared and our priest hallowed... chanting, and we made the chickens clamor with shouting. For the Jashariya is its merit, so hasten... if you see that as right. O Lord, one with heavy eyelids from sleep... I alerted him with wine when he rested. As if the aroma of the cup when I called him... to the cup raised a wing in his gut. So he answered stumbling in the folds of his robe... hasty, mixing stumbling with liveliness. So I tore the veil of his licentiousness with my licentiousness... in every distraction, and I revealed and he revealed. He kept laughing at me and making me laugh at him... he does not wake up from jesting and joking.' 

**Dayyarat al-Asaqif (Monasteries of the Bishops)**
These monasteries are in Najaf, outside Kufa, which is the beginning of Al-Hirah. They are domes and palaces called the Monasteries of the Bishops. In their presence is a river known as Al-Ghadir. To its right is the Palace of Abu al-Khasib, client of Abu Ja'far, and to its left is Al-Sadir, and between that are the monasteries. This palace of Abu al-Khasib is one of the parks of the world. It overlooks Najaf and that ridge. One ascends from its bottom on a staircase fifty steps long to a beautiful roof and sitting place, so the viewer overlooks Najaf and Al-Hirah from that spot. Then one ascends from it on another staircase fifty steps long to a spacious roof and wondrous sitting place. This Abu al-Khasib is the client of Abu Ja'far al-Mansur and his doorkeeper. Al-Sadir is a great palace from the buildings of the kings of Lakhm in ancient times. What remains of it now are monasteries and churches for Christians. Ali bin Muhammad al-Himmani al-Alawi mentions these places: 'How many a stop you had at Al-Khawarnaq... not equaled by stops. Between Al-Ghadir to Al-Sadir... to the Monasteries of the Bishops. The paths of the monks in... worn clothes, fearful female and male. Ruins whose gardens seem... to be clothed in marked robes. And as if their pools... contain tithes in Qurans. And as if their flowers... shake with the stormy winds. The forelocks of servant girls meet... in them with the forelocks of servant girls. You meet their beginnings... and their ends with colors of ornaments. Marine in their winters... desert-like in which are summer resorts.'

'Pearl-pebbled, camphor-like... are the high lookouts in it. Then she burst pouring like... a weeping woman with four flowing [tears].' Abu Nuwas mentions his days at Al-Sadir: 'Days of revelry returned to me at the Monastery... and joy with boon companions and music. And the eyes of gazelles gazing at us... blessed with every kindness and gentleness. And soft of steps, almost from... delicacy making every limb bleed blood. The cross settled from him in the place of the neck... indeed it specialized him over every intimate. We turned the mill of bliss three times... and connected bliss palm to palm.' He said: When Al-Rashid stayed at Al-Hirah, at the time of his return from Hajj, Ja'far bin Yahya rode to Al-Sadir, toured it, and looked at its construction. Then his eye fell on writing at its top, so he ordered someone to climb to the spot and read it. He said to himself: 'I have made it an omen for what I fear from Al-Rashid.' It was read, and behold it was: 'Indeed the Banu al-Mundhir passed away in a year... where the monk built the church. They became such that no hoper hopes for them... one day, nor does a monk fear them. They became food for the worms of the earth... and the sought and the seeker were cut off.' So Ja'far grieved at that and began reciting the verses and saying: 'By Allah, our matter is gone!' Among these buildings: Al-Masqatat. It is a palace with long roofed corridors east of Al-Hirah on the pilgrim road. Then Al-Qasr. Then Kuwat al-Baqqal. Then the Palace of the Adasis. Then Al-Aqsa al-Abyad. Then the Palace of Banu Buqayla. This palace belonged to Abdul Masih bin Buqayla al-Ghassani. He was named Buqayla (Little Sprout) only because he came out one day to his people in two green suits, having wrapped one as a waistcloth and cloaked himself with the other. His people said: 'He is nothing but a Buqayla.' So he was named that. This Abdul Masih is the nephew of Satih the Soothsayer. Khosrow had sent him to Satih because of the vision he saw. He came to him while he was dying, and said: 'Is the Noble of Yemen deaf or does he hear?' in verses. Satih opened his eye and said: 'Abdul Masih, on a striving camel, came to Satih, while he is on the brink of the grave, from the King of Banu Sasan, due to the shaking of the Iwan, the extinguishing of the fires, and the vision of the Mobadhan.' The news is famous; we left it for its fame. When Khalid bin al-Walid camped at Al-Hirah, Abdul Masih came out to him. Khalid said to him: 'From where is your furthest trace?' He said: 'From my father's loins!' He said: 'I did not ask you about this!' He said: 'And I did not answer except what you asked about!' He said: 'What are you?' He said: 'Arabs who became Nabateans!' He said: 'So what is the matter of these fortresses?' He said: 'We built them to protect ourselves in them from the ignorant until the wise comes and deters him!' He said: 'Do you understand?' He said: 'Yes, and I lead!' He said: 'What is your age?' He said: 'Bone!' He said: 'How much has come upon you?' He said: 'If anything came upon me it would kill me!' He said: 'How much of your life has passed?' He said: 'Four hundred years!' He said: 'So what wonders have you seen?' He said: 'I saw ships docking in this place, and I saw a woman going out from Al-Hirah to Sham with her spindle in her hand and her basket on her head, no one frightening her. And it is now a ruin and wasteland; and that is Allah's habit with His creation.' In his hand was something he was turning over. Khalid said: 'What is this in your hand?' He said: 'Instant poison!' He said: 'What will you do with it?' He said: 'If you give me what I like, [good]; otherwise, I will kill myself with it. I will not be the first to bring humiliation upon his people and drive to them what they hate.' Khalid said: 'Give it to me.' He handed it to him. He threw it in his mouth, said: 'In the name of Allah,' and swallowed it. A swoon overtook him, then he recovered, as if he was released from a shackle. Abdul Masih returned to his people and said: 'I came to you from a man who drank instant poison and it did not harm him.' He carried money to him, made a peace treaty with him, and left them. After it: Dar Awn, then Qubbat Asr Kadha, which is what is next to Najaf. These are the palaces of Al-Hirah remaining now. 

**Qubbat al-Shattiq (Dome of al-Shattiq)**
It is among the ancient buildings in Al-Hirah, on the pilgrim road. Opposite it are domes called Al-Shakurrah; all of them belong to the Christians. They go out on their feast day from Al-Shakurrah to the Dome, in the best attire, wearing crosses, with censers in their hands. The deacons and priests are with them, chanting holiness in one tune, agreed in melodies. A large crowd of Muslim pleasure-seekers and idle people follow them until they reach Qubbat al-Shattiq. They offer sacrifices and baptize, then return in the same manner. It is a beautiful sight. A poet said about it: 'And the virgins tightening the belts... upon them every firm ornament. Walking from the domes of Sha'anin... to the courtyard of Qubbat al-Shattiq. O my friend, do not blame me on a day... you see play in it in reality.' And for Bakr bin Kharija:

'O my two friends, turn with me to Al-Hirah... how long, how long will you watch the stars? And give me drink from the house of Sijum... wine, a coffee-colored wine, do not bargain with Sijum. A tavern whose filling is beautiful gazelles... they agitated a sick heart with coquetry. And when you give me drink... old sealed wine. Then head for Qubbat al-Shattiq and a gazelle... inhabiting the monastery, who captivated me, soft-voiced. The knot of his belt connected to the heart... so it became pierced within the vitals.' This Bakr bin Kharija was from the people of Kufa. He was among those engrossed in wine, infatuated with throwing himself into taverns and monasteries. Most of his poetry was about that. From his poetry also: 'He went from the tavern drunk... so he increased my worry and sorrows. The tavern of Sijum which made... from her love fires in the heart. A wide-eyed fawn gazes with two eyes... you think him drowsy from drunkenness. The two eyes never saw a likeness to him... among humans if counted nor Jinn. The knots of the belt on his waist... tortured me with love in varieties. I concealed my love and passion for him... for an age, and conditions, and times. Until my body turned to decay... so I cannot bear concealment today.' 

**Dayr Hind bint al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir (Monastery of Hind daughter of al-Nu'man)**
Hind built this monastery in Al-Hirah, became a nun in it, and dwelt in it for a long time, then went blind. This monastery is one of the greatest and most populated monasteries of Al-Hirah. It is between the Trench (Khandaq) and Hisn Bani Bakr. When Al-Hajjaj came to Kufa in the year seventy-four, it was said to him that between Al-Hirah and Kufa is a monastery belonging to Hind bint al-Nu'man, and she is in it, and possesses opinion and intellect. So look at her for she is a remnant. He rode with the people until he came to the monastery. She was told: 'This is the Emir Al-Hajjaj at the door.' She looked out from a side of the monastery. He said to her: 'O Hind, how wonderful is what I saw!' She said: 'The going out of the likes of me to the likes of you! Do not be deceived, O Hajjaj, by the world, for we became morning while we were as Al-Nabigha said: "I saw you as one for whom the rope of protection is tied... by people; his herds are safe where he pastures." And we did not reach evening except that we are the lowliest of people. Rarely does a vessel fill except it overturns.' Al-Hajjaj left angry, and sent someone to evict her from the monastery and demand the land tax from her. She was brought out with three of her maidservants. One of them said upon her exit: 'Exiting ones driven from the Monastery of Hind... submissive in humiliation and disgrace. I wish I knew, is this the beginning of the Gathering [Judgment Day]... or has Time wiped out the jealousy of young men?' A youth from the people of Kufa charged on his horse, rescued them from Al-Hajjaj's police, and went into hiding. Her poetry and the youth's action reached Al-Hajjaj. He said: 'If he comes to us, he is safe; and if we catch him, we will kill him!' The youth came to him. He said to him: 'What induced you to do what you did?' He said: 'Jealousy!' So he gave him a gift and released him. Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, when he conquered Iraq, came to Hind at her monastery. She came out to him, so he honored her and offered her himself for her needs. She said: 'I will greet you with a greeting our kings used to be greeted with: May a hand that attained poverty after wealth not touch you, nor may a hand that attained wealth after poverty touch you. May Allah not make you have a need from a miser. And may Allah not strip a blessing from a generous one except He makes you a cause for returning it to him.' Then Al-Mughira came to her, when Muawiyah appointed him governor of Kufa. He asked permission to enter upon her. She was told: 'The Emir of this town is at the door.' She said: 'Say to him: Are you from the children of Jabala bin al-Ayham?' He said: 'No!' She said: 'Then from the children of Al-Mundhir bin Ma' al-Sama'?' He said: 'No!' She said: 'Then who are you?' He said: 'Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba al-Thaqafi.' She said: 'So what is your need?' He said: 'I came to you as a suitor!' She said: 'If you came to me for beauty or status, I would have answered you. But you wanted to honor yourself by me in the gatherings of the Arabs, saying: "I married the daughter of Al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir!" Otherwise, what pride is there in the meeting of a one-eyed man and a blind woman?' Then he sent to her, saying: 'How was your affair?' She said: 'I will shorten the answer for you. We reached evening one evening and there was no Arab on earth but he desired us and feared us; then we reached morning and there was no one but we desire him and fear him!' He said: 'So what did your father say about Thaqif?' She said: 'Two men of them disputed before him regarding something; one traced his lineage to Iyad and the other to Bakr bin Hawazin. He judged in favor of the Iyadi, and said: "Indeed Thaqif was not Hawazin... and did not relate to Amir and Mazin."' Al-Mughira said: 'As for us, we are from Bakr bin Hawazin, so let your father say what he wishes!' 

**Dayr Zurara (Monastery of Zurara)**

It is a beautiful monastery, between the Bridge of Kufa and Hammam A'yan, away from the road on the right of one leaving Baghdad for Kufa. It is a pleasant picnic spot, with many taverns and drink, populated by those who visit it, never devoid of those seeking play and preferring idleness. It is one of the locations suited for that. He said: Yahya bin Ziyad and Muti' bin Iyas went out for Hajj. When they neared Dayr Zurara, one said to the other: 'Would you like to send our baggage ahead and go to Zurara, drink in its monastery for our night, and provision ourselves from its beardless boys and wine enough for the return, then catch up with our baggage?' They did so. The people marched on, and they stayed. That remained their habit until the pilgrims returned. When they arrived at Kufa, they shaved their heads, rode two camels, and entered with the pilgrims. Muti' said: 'Did you not see me and Yahya when we performed Hajj... And Hajj was of the best trade. We went out seeking Hajj and religion... but the road turned us to Zurara. So the people returned having gained and performed Hajj... and we returned burdened with loss.' Then he also said about it, and it has a melody. It is said the verses belong to Abu Ali al-Basir: 'We went out seeking Mecca... as pilgrims and visitors. When the camel driver reached Al-Hirah... my camel became confused. And the star almost set... for the morning or had set. So I said: Put down my saddle here... and do not care about who marched. So we renewed covenants... that had passed from us and traces. And we fulfilled needs of ours... that were, and desires. And we accompanied in it a monastery... and a priest and a vintner. And a gazelle tying between... the dune [hips] and the waist a belt. We explained news to you... and we integrated news.' Abu Nuwas has [poetry] in this meaning: 'And a sayer: Do you want Hajj? I said to him: ... Yes, when the pleasures of Baghdad are exhausted. By Qatrabbul from it where we see... then the Dome of Al-Fark from the sides of Kalwadh. Then Al-Salihiyya, then Al-Karkh where... the deviants of Baghdad gathered for me with deviants. And how is Hajj for me as long as I am immersed... in the house of a procuress or the house of a winemaker. And granting that you save me from the revelry of Baghdad... how is the escape for me from Tiznabadh?' Among those who did the act of Muti' was Sulayman bin Muhammad al-Umawi. He had prepared the Bactrian camels for Hajj and attended to them all year. When he reached Kufa, he changed his mind and stayed, saying: 'My greed for Hajj spoiled the intellect... since I found no escape nor refuge. I repented to Him from sins and from... an innocent honor satirized with abomination. So He returned me disappointed to my cup... and saying poetry, while His pardon is hoped. Where the wineskins become submissive... you think them from their blackness Zanj. When we placed a vat for the skin... and untied its bond, it spilled. My provision for Hajj became a snack... when I sipped the slippery wine. And my sleeping place became my wineskin, I enjoyed it... full, never leaving the saddlebag. Thus is he who seeks reward but... does not rise except with a lame intention.' Abu al-Madrahi, Salam bin Ghalib bin Shammas, and Abu al-Basir the poet went out wanting Hajj. When they reached Kufa, Abu al-Basir and Salam changed their minds, then Abu al-Madrahi continued. Abu al-Basir said addressing Salam: 'Take the head of the sandgrouse and seek... Allah's choice towards the house of the singing girl of Al-Rammah. Where musical instruments and wine are not denied... and the placing of hands on vulvas.' Muti' bin Iyas was among the wittiest of people, best in poetry, most abundant in jokes, and most intense in licentiousness and debauchery. He did not cease drinking and playing, engrossed in loss, and throwing himself into places of pleasure. Muti', Yahya bin Ziyad, Hammad Ajrad, and Hammad al-Rawiya never separated. All of them were on one path in licentiousness, and all of them were accused of Zandaqa (heresy)! Al-Utbi mentioned from his father, saying: An old man from the people of Kufa came to us; I never saw one better in speech than him. He used to tell me about Muti', the two Hammads, and the wits of the people of Kufa and their wonders. He did not tell about any of them better than what he told me about Muti' bin Iyas. I said to him: 'By Allah, I desired to see Muti'.' He said: 'By Allah, if you saw him, you would have met a great affliction from him!' I said: 'How?' He said: 'You would see a man whom a wise person cannot bear to be without if he sees him, and no one accompanies him but gets exposed by him!'

Ibn Habib mentioned, saying: I saw a man from the people of Kufa, so I asked him about Muti', as he had accompanied him. He said: 'You do not want to ask about him.' I said: 'Why is that?' He said: 'What is your question about a man who, if he attends you, he owns you; if he is absent from you, you miss him; and if you are known for his company, he exposes you!' Muti' was among the veterans of the two dynasties, the Umayyad and the Abbasid. He praised Al-Walid bin Yazid, drank with him, praised his brother, and was favored by him. He said: Muti' bin Iyas, Shura'a bin al-Zandabudh, Yahya bin Ziyad, Waliba bin al-Hubab, Abdullah bin Ayyash al-Mantuf, and Hammad Ajrad attended the gathering of an Emir in Kufa. They all gathered against Muti', plotted against him, and satirized him. He overcame them all, then improvised against them, saying: 'And five who have shown me their enmity... and a frying pan and pot have burned for them. If they could, my flesh would be divided by... a monkey, a dog, its two puppies, and a pig.' So he silenced them, and they acknowledged him. He said: They gathered drinking and remained like that for days. Yahya bin Ziyad said to them one night, while they were drunk: 'Woe to you! We haven't prayed for three days. Stand with us so we may pray.' They said: 'Yes!' Muti' stood up, called the Adhan and Iqama. Then he said to the singing girl: 'Step forward and lead us in prayer.' She stepped forward; she was without trousers, wearing a thin tunic. When she prostrated, her private parts were exposed. Muti' jumped to it and kissed it, then said: 'And when her thing appeared crouching... like a shaven head and she did not lean. I prostrated to it then kissed it... as the diligent worshiper does.' So they cut their prayer with laughter, then returned to what they were doing. He said: Yahya bin Ziyad wrote one day to Muti': 'I am energetic for drinking. If you are free, come to me. And if you have good date wine and singing, I will come to you!' The note came to him while Hammad al-Rawiya, Hakam al-Wadi, and a beardless boy were with him. He answered him: 'Yes, we have date wine... and we have Hammad. And we have our Wadi... and he is no pillar ('Imad). And our good is plentiful... and good is sought for increase. And our amusement is delicious... worshippers have not distracted it. Or do you desire mounting... then we have corruption. Or do you desire a boy... then our Nad (friend) is Ziyad. He has no twisting... away from us nor distance.' When he read the note, he went to them, and they completed the rest of their day. Yahya bin Ziyad said to him: 'Go with us to So-and-so the singer'—he loved her—'for there is anger between us. Perhaps you can reconcile between me and her, though you are a wretched reconciler, by Allah!' They entered upon her. Yahya began reproaching her, and Muti' was silent. He said to him: 'What silences you? May Allah silence your breath?' Muti' said: 'You are acting coy with him while he has... ceased not to debase himself in your love.' Yahya liked what he said, beamed at him, and said: 'Go on!' He said: 'So leave him, and connect with Ibn Iyas... I have made his soul this morning your ransom.' Yahya stood up to him with a cushion to beat his head with it, and said: 'Is it for this I invited you, O son of a whore?'

He said: In Kufa, there was a man named Abu al-Asbagh. He had a son named Asbagh, considered the handsomest among people. Mutai’ ibn Iyas, Yahya ibn Ziyad, and Hammad Ajrad would sneak into his house and were infatuated with his son but could not approach him. Abu al-Asbagh decided to have breakfast one day with Yahya ibn Ziyad, so he sent him gifts during the night: a kid, chickens, fruits, and drinks. Abu al-Asbagh told his servants: 'Yahya ibn Ziyad is with us, prepare everything he desires.' After the meal, there was no messenger to deliver his gifts except his son Asbagh. He said to him: 'Do not leave unless Yahya is with you.' When Asbagh arrived, he told the servant: 'Let him in, you stand aside and close the door. If Asbagh tries to leave, stop him.' When Asbagh entered and delivered the message, Yahya tried to seduce him, but he resisted. Yahya struggled and tried to force him, but could not, and finally cut off his attempt. Afterward, he gave him forty dinars which were under his prayer mat. Asbagh accepted them. Yahya said: 'Go, I am following you.' Asbagh left, and Yahya washed, adorned himself, and perfumed. Mutai’ entered, saw him, and asked: 'How are you this morning?' Yahya ignored him, lifted his nose, and frowned. Mutai’ asked: 'Where are you going?' Yahya did not reply. Mutai’ said: 'What is wrong? Did revelation descend on you? Did angels speak to you? Were you pledged to caliphate?' Yahya gestured: 'No, no!' Mutai’ said: 'You are perplexing us by not speaking, as if Asbagh son of Abu al-Asbagh has pierced you.' Yahya said: 'Indeed! Just now, I gave him forty dinars.' Mutai’ asked: 'Where are you going?' He said: 'To my father’s invitation.' Mutai’ asked: 'What about your wife if you leave? Will she come to you?' Yahya revealed her to him, and he accepted. Mutai’ asked how he managed it. Yahya explained, then prepared to go to Abu al-Asbagh’s house. Mutai’ followed, waited an hour, then knocked and sought permission. The messenger said: 'He is busy today and cannot see you.' Mutai’ sent a note with ink and paper, writing: 'O Abu al-Asbagh, you remain high and distant … do not make me like those … who are cut off, achieving what they desire without end … or neglecting rightful duty … If you saw Asbagh humble beneath … embarrassed, submissive, receiving punishment … you would call him and see a shameful matter.' Abu al-Asbagh asked Yahya: 'Did you do it, son of the woman?' He said: 'No!' He struck his son’s pedestal and found it cut, confirming the scandal. Yahya said: 'What happened has happened. Mutai’ son of the woman approached you. This is my son, more worthy than yours. I am Arab, son of an Arab woman, your son is Nabati, son of a Nabati woman. Take my son ten times for the act against your son, gaining the dinars, eleven in total.' Abu al-Asbagh laughed and gave the dinars to his son, who received them shamefacedly. Yahya said: 'Mutai’ son of the woman has no share!' Abu al-Asbagh and his servants said: 'Let him enter; we are exposed!' He entered, sat with them, drank, while Yahya cursed him, and Mutai’ laughed. Mutai’ had many witty stories, which were not included to avoid length and boredom. He wrote beautiful poetry and sang. Among them: 'Alas for the gazelle whose pursuit I longed for … until its will bent to me, softening … enticing me … until I said I have it and it left.' Also: 'My beloved Khalili is always distant … he promises tomorrow and the day after … and it never ends.' Another: 'Remove your modesty in love … and drink aged wine, join the singing girls openly … for life in their company distracts you only from what you desire, though life is fleeting.' Mutai’ disliked and satirized his father. He was from Banu Kinana. Once, he mentioned the tribes of Quraysh and Arabs, describing each. Someone asked: 'Where is Banu Kinana?' He replied without pause: 'In Palestine, they ride swiftly,' alluding to the poet: 'Circle around me, Banu Kinana … in Palestine they ride swiftly.'

**'Umr al-Anbar (The Monastery of Anbar)**

This monastery is in Al-Anbar, on the Euphrates. It is a large, beautiful monastery with many cells and monks. It has a strongly built wall, serving as a fortress for it. The congregate mosque is adjacent to it. It is never devoid of picnickers and those affecting wit. It has a beautiful exterior and a wondrous view, especially in the days of spring, because its deserts and all its lands become like robes due to the abundance of rare flowers and artistic blossoms. Whoever among the Caliphs and those below them passes by Al-Anbar stays there for the duration of his residence. Poets have described it and mentioned it in their poems.

Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak said about it:
'The bell announced the dawn to you... and the monk chanted in the monastery.
Your eyes wandered in a garden... laughing with red and yellow [flowers].
And a drunkard yearned for his wine... and the cup came according to measure.
So turn away from sleep to drinking it... as you would turn away from death to resurrection.'

And Kushajim said about it:
'Go early, my friend, to Al-Anbar... drink wine in the prime of the day.
Populate the monastery with pleasure and revelry... urging the cups and the strings.
Do you not see that Time has come to you with a face... cheerful after frowning and turning away?
Wearing a suit of flowers that was... before hidden from eyes.
Narcissus like eyes watching the one it loves... without a watcher or caution.
And when the anemones appear in it... the onlookers think it a flame of fire.
Or as if red robes were spread... for a prince in a massive army.
As if the fresh violet in it... is the trace of a pinch on the cheeks of maidens.
And the sky-colored lavender appeared in it... like rubies arranged in winnowing forks.
And as if the stock is a robe of embroidery... the likes of which merchants' chests never contained.
Woven in the borders of spring, but... the hand of rains embellished its embroidery.
Chamomile and lily of beautiful blossom... and embellished mugwort with buphthalmun.
So seize the negligence of time and hasten... and snatch the pleasure of short nights.'

Kushajim is Abu al-Fath Mahmoud bin al-Husayn the Scribe; he had beautiful poetry, a delicate nature, and good description. He has many books and novel compilations. From his poetry regarding a boy he used to associate with:
'Who will excuse me regarding the cheeks of a fawn... who exposed the heart to causes of destruction?
A moon, the bliss of beauty roamed in... the water of his cheeks upon the water of luxury.
He has a line of downy hair written by... the splendor of glory with the pens of honor.
Wisdom in softness, embroidered... with an embroidery that did not pass the limit of the earring.
It pinched his cheeks then bent... Ah, how beautiful is that bending.
The hair knew that he who hastened it... was unjust to him, so it stopped.
So in its stopping, it confesses... to reaching the limit in transgression and excess.'

He has in the description of an Oud:
'She came with an oud whose tone is like... the voice of a girl complaining of a youth's separation.
Surrounded, souls surrounded it... as if flowers grew around it.
Its pegs turned in it and differed... like the difference of palms when interlaced.
If you moved it behind a defeated man... on a post-horse, he would turn back.'

'O the beauty of their voices, as if they are... two sisters in a craft corresponding with each other.
And he, upon this, substitutes if she falls silent... from her, and she substitutes from him if he falls silent.'

He has regarding that:
'And a female singer leaning over a crooner... who has a loud voice but no hoarseness.
If you contemplate the gut from it, you think it... contains satiety while it is perforated, empty.
He has tones that lead from every listener... to where wine does not lead its drinker.
If she strikes it with fingertips and there meets... upon its body from her body the chest and the bosom.
It wept with joy, so amusement laughed towards it... and the bonds of causes were broken and patience stolen.
And the right hand grants it a detailed accounting... so it carries in it the five, the six, and the ten [musical intervals/rhythms].
So die a victim of drunkenness, the best death... for clemency is nothing but that drunkenness makes you foolish.'

From his beautiful poetry:
'They say: Repent, while the cup is in the hand of a lithe one... and the voice of the second and third strings is loud.

I said to them: If I had harbored repentance... and saw all this, it would have appeared to me [to break it].'

He has describing a harp (Ma'zifa):
'Suspended of strings, noisy... it has a yearning like the yearning of a stranger.
It exceeded the lute in goodness and has... wandered from the flute with a wondrous creation.
Its insides are clothed in a skin... white, from the skin of a raised gazelle.
As if its nine strings... set up traps to hunt hearts.'

He has regarding a plectrum:
'O arrogant one, coquettish with his beauty... be generous to the lover, for you are worthy of generosity.
By accepting a plectrum that resembled you in its beauty... good of bending, slender, shaped.
Resembling you when you step playfully... and sway between bodies and necklaces.
Do not let the envious gloat at me by rejecting it... may every envious female and male ransom you.
I did not gift it to you, O my desire, but... I gifted it seeking closeness to the Oud.'

He has elegizing a cup of his that broke:
'I have tragedies for calamities... but not like our tragedy with the cup.
The vessel of wine and the crown of fingertips... and the friend of joy and banisher of sorrow.
It returns his image to the person... so if you took it as a mirror, it would serve.
It almost, with the water if it touched it... due to what is in it of resemblance, flows away.
So a persistent creditor of Time... caused me to lose it despite [my] stinginess with it.
As if he has an eye that selects... so he does not intend other than the witty.'

So do not go far, for how many a gut... is wounded over you, and a heart ulcerated.'

He has regarding the Nile:
'As if the Nile when it came to Egypt... and overflowed in it and the canals were broken.
And surrounded the villages from every side... skies whose stars are lost.'

He said regarding the melon:
'And a good one who gifted us a good thing... so the gift guided us to the giver.
O picker of the melon from its planting... you picked the fruit of praise from it.
It did not come to us until there came with it... scents that sufficed instead of incense.
As if the knife reveals from it... saffron mixed in honey.
As if inside it is wine... in which Indian aloe is soaked.'

In what we have brought of his novel poetry and strange descriptions is sufficiency that fulfills the condition and does not exceed the limit.

**Dayr Qunna (Monastery of Qunna)**
**Also known as Dayr Mar Mari al-Salih**

This monastery is sixteen farsakhs from Baghdad, descending on the eastern side. Between it and the Tigris is a mile and a half, and between it and Dayr al-Aqul is a post-stage (Barid). It is a beautiful, pleasant, populated monastery. In it are one hundred cells for its monks and those devoted to worship within it; each monk has a cell. They buy and sell these cells among themselves for from one thousand dinars to two hundred dinars to fifty dinars. Around each cell is a garden containing all fruits, palm trees, and olives. Its yield is sold from two hundred dinars to fifty dinars. There is a great wall surrounding it. In its center is a flowing river. Its feast where people gather is the Feast of the Cross. Poets have described it.

Ibn Jumhur said about it:
'O abode of amusement at Dayr Qunna... my heart has yearned for those hills.
Hail to your days when we were... gathering pleasure and beauty from you.
Days, no life was softer than ours... when we got intoxicated and sobered up, we returned.
And if a jar finished, we broached a jar... until it was thought we had gone mad.
And a helper [cupbearer] in all we wanted... resembling for us the moist, flexible branch.
The most beautiful of God's creation performed a melody... and plucked the high string of his oud and sang.
By God, O priest, O Ma Qunna... when did you see the nasal-voiced fawn?
When did you see my temptation, John (Yuhanna)... Ah, when he sways or bends.
O wish of the heart when it wishes... you assassinated the lover tormented by you.
Then you turned the shield in love... you tortured him with love, art by art.
And the earth became a prison upon him... so his eyelid does not meet an eyelid [in sleep].
I ransom you, do not abandon a wasting lover... who was safe from your treachery.
I did badly when I thought good of you... and my heart became a pawn in your hands.'

He also said about it:

'And how many a stand at Dayr Qunna I stood... flirting in it with a charming, wide-eyed one.
And how many an impulsive act of mine in it I have not forgotten its goodness... I killed a custom with it and revived a forbidden act.'

He is Abu Ali Muhammad bin al-Husayn bin Jumhur al-Qummi. His father was among the narrators of the People of the House (Ahl al-Bayt), peace be upon them, and carriers of traditions from them. Abu Ali was witty, literary, with beautiful poetry and writing. He traveled in search of knowledge, threw himself into places of play, associated with people of licentiousness, and visited taverns and monasteries. Then he resided in Basra, his condition improved there, and he acquired much wealth.

From his poetry regarding a slave girl who was among the singing girls (Qiyan), known as Zad Mahr, the slave girl of Al-Mansuriyah—and he had witty stories with her among the Qiyan, then it became possible for him to buy her—is his saying:
'Perhaps a matter is considered difficult and unlikely... while it is near.
Man gets what he desires... in the purity of time.
So the humbled, despairing one sees... the attainment of wishes.
He has engaged what he hoped for... in envy and safety.'

He also said:
'How much the vicissitudes of time have shown us of wonder... and of a lover severe in illness and pain.
Time cleared for him until he attained his desire... from the one he loved with the easiest request.'

His stories with her and other singing girls are amazing. This Zad Mahr said to him once, while she was among the Qiyan and he had invited her: 'Take the omen for me regarding something I have concealed.' He took the stamp (or geomancy instrument) and cast it, saying: 'You asked about a man sick of heart, severe in distress, constant in thought, long in bewilderment, who is on the brink of a great matter in obedience to a dear human.' She laughed, then said quickly: 'Upon the clitoris of the mother of the liar! By God, I asked only about the solid cloth you promised me, when will you send it to me?' He was ashamed and sent it to her.

He once embroidered a handkerchief with these verses and sent it to her:
'I am a messenger from a lover... whose tears are flowing on his cheek.
This is Ibn Jumhur, so be generous to him... with yourself as he desires, O cruel one.
For the soul, even if your love has wasted it... O its mistress, is not forgetting.'

She returned the handkerchief, having embroidered in its center: 'Is it one who mocks us until his adulterer fucks us!'

He wrote to her, after she had shunned him:
'O mistress of her slave, by God, what reached you is false, but I admit it in obedience to you, and I say as Rabi'ah al-Asadi said:
"Consider me a man who committed a sin out of ignorance... and I did not come to it intentionally, and the forbearing one may be ignorant.
God forgave what has passed, I am not returning... and here I am withdrawing from your anger."

And I also said:
"My hope, if I missed... my right guidance in your love.
Indeed, I have kept an eye awake... that was sleepless at your sleep.
So forgive me and be generous... I have made myself your ransom."'

She signed on the back of the note: 'Why do you distress yourself and be pedantic in writing poems? Send the tunic (Ghulala), and we have reconciled!'

He has regarding her:
'Your enemies spent the night as I spent it... and your envier met what I met.
O you whom I was miserable by loving... connect, may I not be miserable as I was miserable.
I did not betray your covenant as long as I lived... nor cut off nor forgot.
Be how you wish, for I... observe your affection as long as I remain.'

He said to her one day: 'O whore!' She said to him: 'O son of two whores!' He said to her: 'Woe to you, I say to you O whore, and you say to me O son of two whores?' She said: 'Yes! I am refractive (Shamus), I return with the pair (double)!'

We used to attend his assembly in Basra, and he would dictate the news of the People of the House, peace be upon them. When he finished dictating, his slave girls would begin and recite with melodies, then recite ascetic poems. When they finished that, whoever left would leave, and he would detain those he was familiar with, and singing and drinking would take place.

He said: Abdun bin Makhlad, the brother of Sa'id bin Makhlad, upon the death of his brother and his release from prison, went to Dayr Qunna, stayed there, and worshipped. This Abdun was lacking in craft, severely backward. Yet he reached a great status in the days of his brother. He said: Riq the singer gifted Abdun early fruit, including figs, pomegranates, and others. He said to his scribe: 'Write her the answer to her note in verse.' He swore that he had never said poetry! Abdun got very angry and said: 'You have been before me for years and do not do well with the seven odes? O donkey, write to her:
"Your two gifts came to us... on your festival day (Mihrajan).
And we ate of your pomegranates... because you are our Janjan and we are your Janjan."'

Sa'id was among the leading men in determination, control, competence, generosity, and nobility. He performed many charities and prayers night and day. During his vizierate for Al-Muwaffaq, he would ride to Al-Muwaffaq's house, stay in his presence for four hours, then return to his home to look into people's needs and the affairs of the present and absent until noon. Then he would have lunch and sleep. Then he would sit in the evening to look into the Sultan's works until the last evening prayer, not leaving until he tallied all funds: what was brought to us, what was spent, and what remained. A report of that was made for him every day and presented to him, and nothing of what happened in the works every day was hidden from him. Then he would order regarding his estates and causes, and instruct his agents and retinue with what was needed. Then he would occupy himself after that with a boon companion, engaging in his conversation and finding comfort in him. Then he would sleep, and rise in the last part of the night, praying until the dawn rose. Then he would permit people to enter and greet him, then ride to Al-Muwaffaq's house.

He said: When Sa'id returned from Fars, Al-Muwaffaq complained to him about the matter of Amr bin al-Layth, the lack of funds, and what was needed to mobilize the army. He requested him to scheme for money to send Rashid out to Al-Saffar. He said: By God, I have no trick other than restricting expenses and withholding from the mercenaries. Al-Muwaffaq said: 'Where does that fall regarding what I need? What I want is for you to take a loan from the merchants and impose a tax on them, on yourself, on the scribes, and the workers, money we can use to send Rashid out. When we have abundance, we will return it to them.' Sa'id was distressed by that and wanted to use a trick to distance himself from him. He said: 'As for in Wasit, it is not possible for me. But if the Emir permits me to go to the City of Peace (Baghdad), I hope to scheme for what he wants.' He said: 'Resolve on that.' And he wrote to his son Abu al-Abbas to seize what belonged to Sa'id in Surra Man Ra'a and Baghdad and all his causes.

Ishaq bin Ibrahim the Scribe said: I saw Sa'id on the day he was arrested, reluctant to go to Al-Muwaffaq. I kept at him until he sat in the boat (Tayyar) while he was extremely hateful of it. He arrived at Al-Muwaffaq's presence. Al-Muwaffaq had agreed with Rashid to march to Sa'id's house upon his arrival before him, and seize what was in it, his son, and his causes. When Sa'id saw the army on the bridge during his march, he said: 'What is this, may God strengthen the Emir?' He said: 'Rashid asked my permission to review his men who are going out with him to Fars, and he has gone to review them.' He said: 'Then I will stand and go towards them and attend the review of the camels with him.' He said: 'Do so.' Sa'id jumped to go, but was diverted to the room prepared for him, and guards were set over him. What he had in Wasit was seized, and his brother Abdun and all their wealth were seized in one day. The yield of the estates seized from him, his brother, and his son amounted to one million dinars. And of goods, clothing, perfume, jewelry, furnishings, and instruments, what had no value due to its abundance was found for them, and about four thousand heads of beasts and mules, and four thousand slaves between stallion and servant. Only about two hundred thousand dinars of apparent money were found for him. Then he laid his hand on uncovering their funds, deposits, and confiscating their causes; it was a huge affair. He remained imprisoned until the year two hundred ninety-five, then was moved to the house of Ibn Tahir, where he died from a diarrhea that afflicted him. He was buried opposite the house known by him. His brother Abdun died, while being a monk at Dayr Qunna, in the year three hundred and ten.

**'Umr Kaskar (Monastery of Kaskar)**

It is below Wasit, on its eastern side, in the village known as Barjuni. In it is the Seat of the Metropolitan. It is a large, great monastery, well-built, firmly constructed. Around it are many cells; each cell is for a monk, and their way is the way of the cells in Dayr Qunna. Many gardens surround the place containing trees, palm trees, and all fruits. Every witty person visits it, and every sad person finds solace in it.

Muhammad bin Hazim has [poetry] in it—he had intended it during the stay of Al-Hasan bin Sahl in Wasit, and he praised Al-Hasan bin Sahl, and he has a story with him we will mention after the poetry:
'At 'Umr Kaskar amusement and joy were good... and mementos, rounds, and selections.
And youths who sacrificed themselves for the cup... and obligated for the foster-brother of the cup what is obligatory.
They spent in the path of revelry what they found... and plundered what they had in it and what they earned.
