Preservers, if you sought their help they paid... and generous, if you asked them for gifts they gave.
I drank with noble masters among them... refined, to whom noble masters gave lineage.
We did not cease in the gardens of the monastery populating them... with revelry, and pleasures and joy overwhelmed us.
The flowers laugh and the stars are weeping... and the flute aids and the strings clamor.

And the cup in the orbit of pleasures is circling... running, and we are poles to it in its rotation.
And Time, its eyes have turned away from us... so events and calamities do not frighten us.'

Muhammad bin Hazim was one of the naturally gifted poets; he excelled in every art he rode and came up with meanings that were closed to others. Most of his poetry was on contentment, praising preservation, and dispraising greed and covetousness.

Muhammad bin Hazim mentioned, saying: A need arose for me in the camp of Al-Hasan bin Sahl, so I came to him, having recited poetry in the ship. I entered upon Muhammad bin Sa'id bin Salim al-Bahili, introduced myself to him, so he knew me, lodged me, and honored my stay. Then he said to me: 'What did you say about the Emir?' I said: 'I haven't said anything yet.' A man who was with me in the ship said: 'Yes, he has said verses.' He asked me to recite them to him, so I recited:
'They told me you praised a generous youth... I said: And how can I get a generous youth?
I have tested people for fifty years... and the experienced one is sufficient for you as a knower.
No one prepares for a day of good... nor does anyone return [favor] to an intimate friend.
And a youth impresses me and I think good... then I uncover from him a mean man.
They resembled each other so they became... sons of two parents, cut from one leather.
People circled Al-Hasan bin Sahl... their circling of Zamzam and Al-Hatim.
And they said a master who gives abundantly... and removes the distress of the suppressed man.
I said my poetry went in blaming the people... and the healthy might be approached from the sick.
And news interpreted by conjectures is not... more healing than the witnessing of the prudent.
So if what spreads about him is true... I return with the equipment of the resident man.
And if it is other than that, I praise my Lord... and doubt is removed about a prudent man.
It is not money that turns me to him... but the generous is the brother of the generous.'

When I recited the poetry to him, he said: 'With the likes of this you meet the Emir? By God, if he were your peer, it would not be permissible for you to address him with this.' I said: 'You spoke the truth, and that is why I said I did not praise him. But I will praise him with a praise that befits him.' He said: 'Do so!' He entered upon Al-Hasan, told him the news, and recited the poetry to him, and he marveled at the quality of the last verse. He ordered my admission to him without praise. I was admitted. He ordered me to recite the poetry, so I asked to be excused. He did not excuse me, and said: 'I have accepted this excuse, since you did not include me in the group you blamed! And with this, we owe you a good reward.' I recited it to him, so he laughed and said: 'Woe to you! What is it with you and people that you encompass them with satire? Enough of this pattern now, and spare them.' I said: 'I have gifted them to the Emir!' He said: 'I have accepted, and I demand fulfillment from you, the demand of one who was gifted a gift and accepted it.' Then he gave me a gift and was generous. So I said about him, and recited to him:
'I gifted the people to Al-Hasan bin Sahl... so he compensated me with abundant reward.
And he said: Leave satire and speak beautifully... for the goal is closer to correctness.
So I said to him: I am innocent to you of them... would that they were at the end of the dust.
Were it not for the favor of Al-Hasan bin Sahl... upon me, I would have subjected them to evil torment.
I plot against them the plotting of enemies... and trick them the tricking of wolves.
They were not transformed into dogs, except that I... saw the people as likenesses of dogs.'

He laughed and then said: 'Woe to you! Just now you started satirizing them; they haven't escaped you yet.' I said: 'This is a remnant that overflowed on my heart, and I will refrain from them as long as God keeps the Emir.'

He said: Muhammad bin Hazim had become ascetic and left drinking wine (Nabidh). He entered one day upon Ibrahim bin Shakla, conversed with him, and ate with him. Ibrahim sat to drink and asked him to drink with him. He refused, and said:
'After fifty I yearn?... And gray hair is a war to ignorance.
Age, gray hair, and ignorance... is a matter, by your life, difficult.
O son of the Imam, why not... when the days of my wood were moist?
And the gray of my head was little... and the spring of love sweet?
And when my arrows were hitting the mark... and the blade of my sword sharp?
And when the cure of beautiful women... from me was talk and closeness?
So now, when the blamers saw in me... what they liked.
And a people sensed guidance from me... I am blamed if I yearn.
I swore not to drink a cup... as long as a caravan performs Hajj for God.'

Hamdan bin Yahya mentioned, saying: The last thing I parted from Muhammad bin Hazim upon was that he said to me: 'Nothing of pleasures remains for me except selling cats!' He said: I said to him: 'May God heat your eye! What pleasure do you have in selling cats?' He said: 'The foolish old woman pleases me when she quarrels with me, saying: "This is my cat, it was stolen from me," so I say to her: "You lied," then she insults me and I insult her, and she quarrels with me and I quarrel with her!' He said: And he recited to me:
'Connect a wine with a hangover... and connect a hangover with a wine.
And take your share of it... as provision to where you know.'
I said: 'To where, woe to you?' He said: 'To the Abyss (Hell), you fool!'

From his beautiful poetry is his saying:
'O son of Sa'id, you passed the limit of kindness with me... and burdened me with what I cannot bear of thanks.
And if a man gave you the effort of his thanks... and passed away without reaching your extent, he is excused.
A state changes for a youth after a state... and free favors remain for a free youth.'

From his good poetry is his saying:
'And I am possessor of affection for the one whose affection lasts... and harsh to the one who desires harshness, easily bored.
And indeed a man who takes shelter in a house of humiliation... where hope enslaves him is humiliated.
And in despair from the humiliation of ambitions is rest... and among people, for those you do not like, is a substitute.'

He said regarding contentment:
'I praise God, thanking... for His trial is good and beautiful.
I became covered, healthy... roaming among His blessings.
Empty of sorrows, light of... back, the little satisfies me.
No greed makes me miserable, nor... covetousness, nor long hope.
Equal to me is the wealthy... waster and the miserly man.
And I banished wishes with despair... from me, so the resting place became pleasant for me.
And all people, to the one... whose burden is light, are friends.'

Muhammad bin Hazim said: Some of the Tahirids sent me—and I had exaggerated in satirizing him and exceeded the limit—one thousand dirhams and a chest of clothes, and said: 'As for what has passed, there is no way to return it, but I would like you not to add anything to it.' So I returned the dirhams and clothes, and wrote to him:
'I do not wear favors from a man... whom I clothed in shame forever.'
Then I refrained from satirizing him.

He said: Sa'id bin Mas'ud al-Qatrabbuli was a friend of mine. I asked him for a need, but he turned me away from it. So I cut him off. He sent me one thousand dirhams and tried to please me. I returned them and wrote to him:
'Wide of chest, spacious for what... the changing, turning [heart] narrows from.
He returned with favor so I accepted it... and perhaps the sinner makes amends.
Yes, time fulfilled, despite that it is... entrusted with separation, being asked for favor.
Hail and care to a time passed... from me, and the arrow of the gloater is the most disappointed.
A little money came to me from you, but I did not... expose myself to it, and the free man does not lie.
My taking money from you after what... you bestowed upon me is a mount that is difficult.
I refused to drink at satisfaction... and anger except a drink that is sweet.
Despair strengthened me and enriched me, so I do not... hope for other than God nor fear.
Korah (Qarun) to me, in wealth, is destitute... and my ambition is a doctrine above that.
So with which of these two do you see me... yearning for your money or desiring?'

From his poetry on contentment is his saying:
'Whoever employs despair, despair makes him... magnified forever in the eyes of people.
And whoever throws the eye of the covetous at them sees... humiliation, and sips the bitterness of denial in a cup.
Despair is better, and people have no fruit... bring a man who was humiliated before people after despair.'

He said in this meaning:
'I made despair the mount of hopes... so it sheltered me to a spacious side.
That mount of hopes is unmarked... without a saddle tied nor straps.
By your life, for the little I protect my face... with it among the solitary and among the group.
Is more beloved to me than my asking for much... to which the necks of submission are stretched.
So live by nourishment day by day... like the sucking of the child at the times of the udders.
And do not desire from anyone with greed... neither high among mankind nor lowly.
Youth has departed and gray hair has settled... so do you have any return to your youth?'

Muhammad bin Hazim said: I entered upon Al-Ma'mun. When I stood before him, he said: 'How is your insight into the days of people and the news of the Arabs?' I said: 'I am on the racecourse, let my rein be released!' He said: 'Recite whatever appears to you.' So I left what he hinted at and worked on fixing my own affair, saying [to myself]: 'A Caliph's assembly, and I am not safe from a mishap.' So I recited to him:
'I was granted intellect but was not granted its chivalry... and chivalry is nothing but the abundance of money.
If I want to soar, the thinness of my condition holds me back... from what praises my name.'

Al-Ma'mun said: 'The Sheikh complains of the thinness of his condition; let one thousand dirhams be given to him,' and he smiled. I said: 'Behind the smile is nothing but good,' so I recited to him:
'You are a sky and my hand is its earth... and the earth may hope for the rain of the sky.
So plant a hand [favor] with me that is praiseworthy... you will harvest with it among people good praise.'

He said: 'This meaning is stronger than the first,' and ordered two thousand dirhams for me. Then he said: 'You deceived me!' I said: 'Two verses on deception have come to me.' He said: 'What are they?' So I recited to him:
'And if you come to the generous one with a deception... and you see him hastening in what you desire.
Then know that you did not deceive an ignorant one... indeed the generous one feigns deception by his action.'

He said: 'They are, by God, better than the first.' And he ordered for me the like of what he had ordered. He asked me to recite to him, so I recited:
'Let not annoyance from a solicitor burden you... for the best of your time is to be seen as asked.
Do not meet with prevention the face of a hoper... for the survival of your glory is to be seen as hoped for.
And know that you are shortly becoming... news, so be news that pleases, beautiful.
The generous is met and his cheerfulness indicates him... and you see the frown on the mean as an indicator.'

He said: 'How excellent you are! How beautiful are your meanings! Boy, write a check for him for the like of what we gave him.'

He has in this art and others everything beautiful. Were it not for the book exceeding its drawn limit and the fear of lengthiness, I would have presented of the best of his poetry and beauties what the listener would delight in. In what we have presented is sufficiency.

**Monasteries of Egypt intended for drinking and picnicking, among them:**

**Dayr al-Qusayr (The Little Palace Monastery)**

This monastery is at the top of the mountain, on the surface of its peak. It is a monastery of beautiful construction, sturdy craftsmanship, pleasant spot. Monks reside in it. It has a well carved in stone from which water is drawn for it. In its altar is the image of Mary with the image of the Messiah, peace be upon him, in her lap. People visit the place to look at this image. At its top is a room built by Abu al-Jaysh Khumarawayh bin Ahmad bin Tulun, having four windows to four directions. He used to visit this monastery frequently, admiring the image in it, drinking while looking at it. The road to this monastery from the direction of Egypt (Cairo/Fustat) is difficult. As for from its southern side, the ascent and descent are easy. Beside it is a hermitage that is never without a recluse in it. It overlooks the village known as Shahran and the desert and the river (Nile/Sea). This mentioned village is a large populated village on the bank of the river; they mention that Moses, peace be upon him, was born in it, and from it his mother threw him into the river in the ark. So this Dayr al-Qusayr is one of the intended monasteries for the beauty of its location and its overlooking of Egypt and its districts. The poets of Egypt have spoken about it and mentioned its goodness and pleasantness.

Abu Hurayra ibn Abi al-Isam has [poetry] in it:
'How much revelry I had at Dayr al-Qusayr... with every person of youthful passion and wit.
I played in it with a coquettish fawn... description falls short of his novelties.'

He also said in it:
'You reminded me, O monastery, of those who passed... of my people of affection and sincere friendship.
How much good days and nights I had... in you and among them together.
I complain to God of my calamity regarding them... and our loss of the people of chivalries.'

Muhammad bin Asim has, in this monastery:
'Indeed Dayr al-Qusayr stirred my remembrance... the amusement of my beautiful short days.
And a time that passed praiseworthy, fast... and a youth like the borrowed robe.
Its quarters knew me after denial... so I knew the quarters by denial.
If dwellings complained of longing... they would have complained of my harshness and the distance of my visiting.
And they would have almost walked towards me because of what... I had sent of my poems in them.
As if I, when I visited it after abandonment... had not been of my homes and dwellings.
When my ascent was on horses to it... and my descent in the embracing ships.
With hawks thirsty for blood... and dogs predatory against wild beasts.

A home, I cannot count what my heart... and my soul have of desires in it.
A home, from its height like a sky... and the lamps around it are like shining stars.
And as if the monks in black hair... are black crows in nests.
Its west has seas and rivers... in clothes of green silk.
The birds trilled between us so they flew... with the heart of the enraptured lover.
How often did I cast off restraint in it and did not... observe gray hair in my parting and cheeks.
How often we drank to the pictures in it... with small [cups] urged and large ones.
An image by a painter in it remained... a temptation to hearts and eyes.
It delighted us without singing... so it sufficed instead of hearing lutes and the flute.
The body languishes when she shoots it with beauty... with arts from her enchanting glance.
And her gestures to whoever sees her... with submission, humility, and brokenness.
No, by the beauty of the two eyes and the dark lip... of hers and her anemone cheek.
I would not hold back from my visit to a monastery... she is in, even if my visiting place is far.
So shorten your blame of me today, for I... am not of solace nor refraining.
So may God water the land of Helwan, then the Palms... then Dayr al-Qusayr with the pouring of rain.
How often I woke from the pleasure of my sleep... by the chanting of monks at dawn.
And the bells shouting, calling... Come alive, O sleeper, early in the morning.
Before the new day and night wear out the new ones... with a night succeeding a day.
Indeed this life is borrowed things... and the borrower must return the borrowed.'

Ibn al-Zanbaqi al-Misri has, in Dayr al-Qusayr, from a long poem:
'O heartbreak in the heart, how killing it is... as if it is the tips of spears in the heart.
How much, how much, and how much of a night I revived... O my friend, in the monastery, in the best place.
Dayr al-Qusayr, unique in its attributes... O one who saw Paradise on the head of a mountain.
I drink it, a wine, chilled, trembling... creeping in the body, my morning and evening.
A coquettish one circulates it with his wit... he revives whom he wills, and whom he wills he kills.
As if he is a willow branch and has... increased upon it with the moderate stature.
Lisping, the death of the soul is in his lisp... he was haughty with it over people, the haughtiness of a pamperer.
If he says Nar (fire), he says Nagh, or says... Nur (light), he says Nugh, with coquetry and flirtation.
And a monk struck the bell in it... a strike with slowness and a strike with haste.
So urge the cups of wine, O our cupbearer... and seize the time, for time has turns.
Before separation knocks on us, so... neither "would that" nor "perhaps" is useful at separation.'

**Dayr Mar Hanna (Monastery of Saint John)**

This monastery is on the bank of Birkat al-Habash (The Lake of the Abyssinians), near the river. Beside it are gardens, some of which were established by Emir Tamim, brother of the Commander of the Faithful Al-Aziz Billah, peace be upon them both. And a sitting room on columns, of beautiful construction and pretty craftsmanship, painted, established by Emir Tamim also. Near this monastery is a well known as Bir Najati, upon which is a sycamore tree; people gather at it and drink by it. This place is one of the places of play and spots of amusement and joy. It is pleasant in the days of the Nile [flood] and its increase and the fullness of the lake, beautiful in view, pleasant in spots, and likewise in the days of cultivation and blossoms. It is hardly devoid of those throwing themselves [into leisure] and picnickers. Poets have mentioned its beauty and goodness.

Ibn Asim has [poetry] in it:
'O goodness of days I poured with youth... obedient to passion in them at the foot of Al-Manzar.
And the lush Lake, and the Monastery which... has stirred the excess of my passion and thinking.
So urge your cups, O boy, and excuse me... for I have become drunk and the wine of your glance is my intoxicant.
And I see the Pleiades in the sky as if they are... a crown whose sides are detailed with jewels.
So drink to the beauty of the gardens and sing to me... Look at the nasal-voiced, wide-eyed cupbearer.
For perhaps the days of life are few... and perhaps I estimated what was not destined.'

He also said:
'Turn my mounts to the sycamore of Al-Arja... at the foot of Helwan and stop at the two berries (Al-Tutat).

'And stop at the palace of Ibn Bistam, for perhaps... I was happy in it in my days and nights.
And read peace to Dayr Mar Hanna, for... its remembrance has shown my passions.
And Birkat al-Habash (Lake of the Abyssinians), by whose joy... I attained what I wished of my amusement and pleasures.
As if its mountains around it are clouds... that cleared after rain from skies.
As if the tails of what was a catch for us... of Abramis and Ray [fish] at Al-Shubaykat.
Are spears whose tips were dyed with blood... or a hand-hilt pulled from wounds.
Dwellings I used to frequent and knock on... and they were of old my brothels and taverns.'

He also said:
'O my days at the shore of the two lakes... may the rain star of the two Mirzams water you.
You have reminded me of my joy and amusement... and entrusted the heart with two sorrows.
Do you think our past days in you... their union will return after separation?
May God water the spots with a pouring rain... and make thirsty a dwelling at the two Jalahas.
And dew the Taylasan with a pour of drizzle... to the palms and the two sycamores.
And circle the circuit and the pouring of clouds... moving to the gardens of the two cypresses.
And single out the two hills, for how many a gazelle... raised between those two hills.
Dwellings we witnessed amusement in... in the most noble two institutes and two familiar places.
How many a church was held for revelry... and music in the gardens of the two spots.
And how many a lovesick one possessed union... and attained his wish in the middle of the two desires.'

Al-Abbas bin al-Basri has, from a poem:
'O carrier of the cup, circulate it and give me drink... longing has frightened my heart so it panicked.
Do you not see the Lake, how beautiful it is... when the birds call in it and whistle?
Do you not see its blossoms, do you not see... the beauty of its water flow when it descends?
As if yellow dinars in it... are scattered, with no trader in it.
As if jewels in their colors... were scattered in those sides and scattered.
As if the hand of a generous one was fond... in that garden of scattering coins (badra).
And the white of narcissus, in its eyelids... is a tear of dew, were it not for holding back, it would drip.
And the look of the rose to its peers... is the look of a beloved with a broken glance.
Leave me, for I perish only by passion... the life of the lover is nothing but in distress.'

Salih bin Musa, client of Tamim, mentions the Lake:
'Suffice you the Lake as a sight not bored
Displaying embroidery that is not hackneyed
Connected in sides, not separated
From the bank of the Nile to the foot of the mountain
How noble is that dwelling for one who dismounted
Its birds have become active after laziness
And cooed and echoed slowly
Between the heavy, the light, and the Ramal [meters/rhythms]
As if they are in dispute and argument
They wail not for sadness but for joy
Reminding us of our first noble days.'

He also said, mentioning the Monastery and the Lake:
'I am an advisor to the likes of you... so lean towards me and do not be deceived.
Go early to Dayr al-Ma'afir... the time of early mornings has come.
Do you not see the beauty of the gardens... and what they have clothed themselves in of flowers?
The face of Spring, and hail to... the face of Spring when it appears.
Brocade is spread, and sheets... and embroidered robes, and ink [color].
This violet in mourning... without sadness has appeared.
And the buphthalmun came with yellowness... so for every beauty it has dazzled.
And as if its calendula... are cups of wine racing.
And as if the stock is a necklace... spread in its sides.
And the chamomile is laughing... revealing gold in which are pearls.
And the anemones are like... flags then to one who looks.
And the fragrant rose blushed... and smelled like musk at dawn.
And the birds of the branches answered... with every famous melody.
So a warbler, of good singing... sang, and another played the reed.
And we stole our breaths... with the breeze of the dawn breaths.'

**Dayr Nahya (Monastery of Nahya)**

Nahya is in Giza. Its monastery is one of the best monasteries, most pleasant and good, populated by its monks and inhabitants. It has a wondrous view in the Nile [flood], because the water surrounds it from all its sides. When the water recedes and it is cultivated, its lands show strange blossoms and varieties of flowers. It is one of the described parks and famous spots. It has a canal to which all birds gather, so it is also a good hunting ground. Poets have described it and mentioned its beauty and the goodness of its location.

Al-Abbas bin al-Basri has [poetry] in it:
'O you whom, when the boon companion gets drunk with his cup... his glances are seduced by the drunkenness of the awkward one.
The morning rose, so give me drink of that which... was wronged, so its color was likened to the lily.
And meet the morning with the light of your face, for it... the joyful one does not meet until he meets.
My heart in which nothing of your love remains... except a remnant of a fire of longing that remained.
Do you not see the face of spring, and its flowers... have boasted in its shining day?
And its birds answered each other and its trees... smiled revealing the mouth of an elegant flower.
The dew of the drizzle did not feed it with its cold... until every closed eyelid opened.
And the full moon in the middle of the sky is as if... it is a beautiful face in a blue mask.
O for the beautiful monasteries and what is in them... of a good day passed for me with yearning.
Days I was, and I had occupation with them... and the captive of the longing of my passion was not released.
O Dayr Nahya, I did not mention you for an hour... except I remembered the youth in my parting.
And time was fresh and the era aiding... and our stay and our overnight were in the pavilion (Jawsaq).
O Dayr Nahya, if you are mentioned, then I... strive towards you the extent of racing horses.
And if you are asked about the birds and their hunting... and their genera, speak truth even if you are not believed.
The coot, the curlew, the farur when... it grieves you in its circling flight.
I witnessed the war of birds in its thickets... when every grouper grouped from it.
And the angry zammuj (bird of prey) in a group of his... swoops down between thundering and flashing.
And I saw for the hawk the power of a rich man... and for others the humiliation of the destitute poor.
How often I played in my youth in my zeal... and cut my times by shooting pellets.
And I cast off my ropes in seeking licentiousness... until I was attributed to the deeds of the clumsy.
And a shunner, arrogant, averse... the heart is anxious because of him even if he is not anxious.
If the apple saw the redness of his cheek... it would yearn for the brocade of that splendor.
O carrier of the sword in the morning, and his glance... is sharper than the drawn cutting sword.
Be gentle with your slave, do not prolong his sorrows... and be gentle with him, O owner of the pure mouth.'

He also said:
'Are you active for drinking, O my master... for this day of yours is fine of seams.
I have for you today two roast chickens... I stole them from the old woman's chickens.
And fifty eggs like stars... she hid them from me inside a jug.
So I tricked her and took them... and she did not benefit from the guarded place.
Are you active at my place for two lotus fruits (nabq)... for two almonds, for a jar.
And we head to Nahya and a monastery of hers... in it is the place of roses and marjoram.
And we drink in it with a rotl and a cup... and a goblet and drafts with a mug.
As for the birds, due to excess joy... they are between the gardens and the planted shoots.
This one shouts at accidents: ... Step aside, and this to us: Do not pass.
And a fawn came to us, soft of coquetry... grew up in bliss and wore silks.
He loves boon companions and their poems... and hides their deposits in treasures.
And he wins from me a witty sheikh... elegant, literary, laughing, joking.
So visit me, you will find me according to the speech... otherwise, kiss my ass today!'

This Ibn al-Basri was one of the dissolute libertines. He has poetry that runs the course of jest and humor. He served Abu al-Qasim Unujur bin al-Ikhshid, so he treated him well, clothed him, and he began to ride with him. He used to wear a blue shawl (Taylasan), resembling the judges. Unujur had mounted him on a thick yellow packhorse, slow of pace. Whenever he rode with groups of his brothers, he would say to them: 'Describe your location to me so I can catch up with you!' He was pleasant in companionship, frequent in jokes. He used to sell pharmacy goods in the Mosque of Abdullah in Egypt.

**Dayr Tamwayh (Monastery of Tamwayh)**

Tamwayh is in the West (Giza side) opposite Helwan. The monastery overlooks the river (sea), and around it are vineyards, orchards, palm trees, and trees. It is pleasant, populated, inhabited. It has a beautiful view in the Nile [flood]. When the land turns green, it is between two carpets of the river and the crops. It is one of the mentioned parks of Egypt and its famous places of amusement.

Ibn Asim has [poetry] in it:
'Shorten your blame of me today, for I... am not of solace nor refraining.
So may God water Dayr Tamwayh with rain... with morning clouds connected to night clouds.
How many nights I was awakened from the sleep of my drunkenness... by the chanting of monks at dawn.
And the bells shouting, calling... Come alive, O sleeper, early in the morning.'

He also said in it:
'And drink at Tamwayh of a pure wine... surpassing the wine of the villages of Hit and Ana.
Upon gardens of blossoms shining... streams flow from them between gardens.
As if the growth of the safflower anemone in it... is cups of wine appearing after cups.
As if its narcissus in its beauty is pupils... secretly conversing with signals.
As if the Nile in the passing of the breeze on it... is clad in coats of mail.
Dwellings I was fascinated by as a lad... and they were of old my brothels and taverns.
Since I do not cease persisting in the morning drink to... the striking of bells, fond of the monasteries.'

**The Monasteries Known for Wonders, according to what their people mentioned and described about them. Among them:**

**Dayr al-Khanafis (Monastery of the Beetles)**
It is between Mosul and Balad, large, with many monks. It has a day in the year when people gather to it from every place. Beetles appear in it that day until they cover its walls, ceilings, and ground, and all of it turns black from them. When it is the second day, which is the feast of the monastery, they gather to the altar, consecrate, offer sacrifice, and leave, and the beetles have disappeared so that nothing of them is seen until that time [next year].

**Dayr al-Kalb (Monastery of the Dog)**
It is between Mosul and Balad. In it, whoever is bitten by a rabid dog is treated. Whoever is bitten by a rabid dog hastens to it, they treat him, and he is cured. Whoever has passed forty days since the bite, the treatment does not succeed.

**Dayr al-Qayyarah (Monastery of Bitumen)**
It belongs to the Jacobites, four farsakhs from Mosul, on the western side, in the district of Al-Haditha, overlooking the Tigris. Beneath it is a bitumen spring, which is a spring gushing with hot water pouring into the Tigris, and bitumen comes out of it. As long as the bitumen is in its water, it is soft and stretches; if it leaves the water and cools, it dries. There are people who gather there and collect this bitumen, ladling it from its water with baskets, and throwing it on the ground. It has large iron pots, and sand is sifted for it. It is thrown onto it in a measure they know and fire is lit under it until it melts and mixes with the sand, while they stir it constantly. When it reaches the limit of its firmness, it is turned onto the ground in solidified pieces, hardens, and is carried to the cities. Ships and baths are coated with it, and other things in which bitumen is used. People frequently intend this place to picnic in it and drink. They bathe in that water which comes out with the bitumen, because it stands in the stead of thermal springs in removing pimples. It has a caretaker (Qaim). Every monastery for the Jacobites and Melkites has a caretaker. As for the monasteries of the Nestorians, they have no caretaker.

**Dayr Barquma**
This monastery is in Mayyafariqin, two farsakhs from it on a high mountain. It has a feast to which people gather, and it is intended for that. Vows are vowed to it and carried to it from every place. People of idleness and licentiousness intend it to drink in it. Beneath it are cisterns in which rainwater collects. Barquma is the witness (saint/relic) in it; the Christians claim he is seven hundred years old, and that he is one of those who witnessed the Messiah. He is in a wooden cabinet having doors that open on the days of their feasts. His upper half appears; he is standing, and his nose and upper lip are cut off. That is because a woman used a trick until she cut off his nose and lip and left with them, and built a monastery over them in the desert on the road to Tikrit.

**Dayr Bata**

This monastery is in the East. It is a beautiful monastery, populated in the days of spring. It is also called Dayr al-Himar (Monastery of the Donkey). Its witness (saint) is known as Mariks. It is far from the Tigris and the city. It has a stone door; the Christians mentioned that this door is opened by one and two [people] until they exceed seven. If they exceed seven, none of them can open it, and it is not opened then except by seven. They also mentioned that there are two crows in it, breeding there, never devoid of them. Perhaps thieves raid it and enter it. If anyone gets inside, the two crows ascend to the meadow of the monastery. If someone approaches it who raids it or intends it [for harm], the two crows meet him screaming in his face as if warning him, so he knows there are people in the monastery, and returns. If there is no one in the monastery, they do nothing of that.

**Dayr Mar Sham'un (Monastery of St. Simon)**
In the regions of Al-Sinn. In this monastery is the seat of the Bishop. There is also a well in it. Whoever is afflicted with vitiligo (Bahaq) intends it and washes from the well; he does not leave until it disappears from him.

**Dayr al-Ajjaj**
This monastery is between Tikrit and Hit. Populated, with many monks. Outside it is a water spring pouring into a pool there. In the pool are black fish, good and sweet in taste. Around it are farms and vegetables watered from that spring.

**Dayr al-Judi**
Al-Judi is the mountain on which the Ship (Noah's Ark) settled. Between this mountain and Jazirat Ibn Umar are seven farsakhs. This monastery is built on the peak of the mountain. It is said it was built since the days of Noah, peace be upon him, and its building has not been renewed to this time. They claimed there is a wonder in it. Some Christians of Jazira told me about it: that its roof is measured by hand spans (Shibr), and it is twenty spans. Then it is measured again, and it is eighteen spans. Then again, and it is twenty-two spans. Every time it is measured, its number differs. And that he tested that and measured it and found it as mentioned.

**Kanisat al-Tur (Church of the Mount)**
Tur Sina (Mount Sinai) is the mountain where He transfigured to Moses, peace be upon him, and he fell unconscious. The church is at the top of the mountain, built with black stone. The width of its fortress is seven cubits, and it has three iron doors. In its west is a small door with a stone of theirs before it; if they want to lift it, they lift it, and if someone intends them [harm], they drop it so it covers the place and the place of the door is not known. Inside it is a water spring and outside it is another spring. The Christians claimed that in it is a fire of the type of the New [Fire] (Holy Fire) that was in Jerusalem; they light from it every evening. It is white with weak heat, not burning, then it strengthens if lamps are lit from it. It is populated with monks, and people intend it because it is one of the described monasteries.

Ibn Asim has [poetry] in it:
'O monk of the monastery, what is this light and illumination... for it has shone in your monastery, Al-Tur?
Has the sun settled in it without its towers... or has the full moon disappeared in it so it is hidden?'
He said: 'Neither sun nor moon settled in it... but flasks [of wine] were offered in it today.'

**Biya'at Abi Hur (Church of Abu Hur)**
This church is in Siryaqus in the province of Egypt. Populated, with many monks. It has feasts which people attend. In it, according to what its people mentioned, is a wonder: whoever has scrofula (Khanazir) intends this place to be treated in it. The head of the place takes him, lays him down, brings a pig, and sends it to the place of pain. The pig eats what is in it, not exceeding that place. When the place is cleaned, ash of a pig that did the same action before and oil from the church lamp are sprinkled on it, and it heals. Then that pig is taken, slaughtered, burned, and its ash prepared for the like of this case.

**Dayr Yuhannis**
This monastery is in Damanhur, in the province of Egypt. When it is its feast day, its witness (saint) is brought out of the monastery in a coffin. The coffin travels on the face of the earth; no one can hold it or detain it until it reaches the river (sea), dives into it, then returns to its place.

**Biya'at Atrib (Church of Athribis)**
Its feast is the twenty-first day of Ba'una. They mention that a white dove comes to them on that feast. It enters the altar—they do not know where it came from—then they do not see it until a day like it [next year].

And in the regions of Akhmim is a large, populated monastery, intended from every place. It is near the mountain known as the Mountain of the Cave. In a place of the mountain is a cleft. When it is the feast day of this monastery, not a single bird known as Buqir remains in that place—and they are many there—until it comes to the spot. It is a great matter due to their abundance, gathering, and screaming at that cleft. Then they do not cease, one after another, inserting its head into that cleft, screaming, and coming out, and another comes and does like its deed, until the head of one of them gets stuck and caught in the place. It struggles until it dies. Then the rest disperse and return to their places, and not a bird remains of them. And Allah knows best.
